name: Zahra, Christian, MP
text:
—I welcome the opportunity to continue my contribution to the debate on the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Amendment Bill 2002 and the Superannuation (Financial Assistance Funding) Levy Amendment Bill 2002. Mr Speaker, I am not sure whether you heard me yesterday when I was talking about this particular legislation, but I made the point that, when we talk about superannuation, we cannot forget that what we are talking about in relation to a fair proportion of people in the Australian community is all the savings that they have—that, when it comes to retirement, that is all they have. This is why we need to be particularly careful about what regulatory measures we take in relation to superannuation. We also need to be particularly vigilant in protecting these people's savings from shonks and from the shameful conduct that some people within the financial services sector get up to when trying to take away the hard-earned savings of these people.
Yesterday I also made the point—and I want to elaborate on it today—that people who work in physically tough occupations can anticipate a shorter life. That means that we need to be very careful about what we do in relation to things like the superannuation preservation age so that we do not end up with a situation whereby people in certain industries live for only five or 10 years after they retire. I have consulted the Australian Bureau of Statistics and I have some figures which I will mention. The figures for 2001 show that 5,124 people aged between 55 and 60 died, 6,661 people aged between 60 and 65 died and 9,046 people aged between 65 and 70 died. It is important for us to understand this, because if we get into a situation in which people are talking about increasing the superannuation preservation age, it will have a disproportionate effect on those people who, because of the occupation that they have been in, will not be able to enjoy the fruits of their labour and will not be able to enjoy a long, healthy and prosperous retirement. 
In my electorate we have a lot of people who work in these very physically demanding industries. We have people in the Latrobe Valley who have been employed in construction. I think it would be fair to say that the Latrobe Valley has been one of the construction centres of Australia, and particularly of Victoria, over the course of the last 50 years. We have had an ongoing work force employed by the SEC, and also by the contractors to the SEC, who have been involved in very tough construction work for a long period of time. We have also had people employed in the forestry sector, which is one of the most physically demanding sectors of the economy. 
I am not sure whether you have been to a timber mill, Mr Speaker—I am sure you probably have—but I know that other members in the House today would have been to a timber mill on many occasions. It is a very tough workplace. The work is very physically demanding and it takes a toll on people's bodies. This is borne out by the major health studies that have been done into the occupational risks associated with certain industries and sectors. It is also borne out by the incidence of occupational injury in those sectors, as documented by WorkCover in Victoria and other agencies elsewhere. 
It is a similar case with milk processing and with dairy manufacturing more generally. This is an industry in which a lot of tough physical work has been involved over the years. We have seen some changes in that industry, particularly over the course of the last 10 or 15 years, as the production process has become more and more mechanised. But in the McMillan electorate we still have a large number of people who were employed in that industry at a time when the production process was not mechanised, which means that their bodies have had the full impact of having to do a lot of very heavy lifting and a lot of difficult work involving the inhalation of certain fumes and powders and all sorts of things associated with the production of milk and other dairy products.
The point that I am making is that we need to be very careful about what we do with superannuation. We need to be conscious of the fact that we are talking about people's savings. For a substantial section of society, we are talking about all their savings. I want to make the point deliberately that, when it comes to a certain group of industries, the people employed in those industries are unlikely, because of the trades that they have been in and the work that they have done in their working lives, to live as long as, say, a bank manager. Someone who might have worked in the banking sector for 30 or 40 years, whilst probably having a guilty conscience, is unlikely to have the same occupational injuries as someone who has worked in the construction industry for that same period of time. We need to think carefully about that.
In addressing this legislation, I make the point that the opposition is particularly concerned about what happens to people who get caught out in superannuation scams. There are a few people out there who have been doing the wrong thing with superannuation, and we need to protect workers and their families from the conduct of shysters and people who set up scams to try to take people's hard-earned savings away from them. We think it is appropriate to put in place the strongest governance that we can for the superannuation industry. And we think it is the right thing to do.
We are very concerned that the government has not taken measures to provide the 100 per cent compensation which is permitted under legislation for people who have their superannuation money taken away from them in cases of theft and fraud. We need to be very careful about this, because we are talking about a group of people who, if they happen to get themselves involved in a scam and get cheated of their money, will have nothing. I made the point yesterday, and it is worth repeating today, that this is particularly important for people who live in country districts. 
There are a few members in the House today who represent country electorates, and they would know that property prices in rural districts are not the same as they are in Melbourne and Sydney. One of the forced savings that people in Melbourne and Sydney have, through paying off their home loans during their lifetime, is that at the end of their working lives they own their house. If you have worked hard during your life and you own your house at the end of it, in Melbourne or in Sydney it is likely that your house will be worth half a million or a million dollars. That is not unrealistic at all. But if you have worked hard during your life to pay off your home loan and you live in the Latrobe Valley, Wonthaggi, Korumburra, Mirboo North or Leongatha it is likely that your house will be worth $100,000 or $200,000. In that situation, if something goes wrong with your superannuation and people take money away from you, you do not have your house to fall back on.  
This is an important thing which we must consider. We must always be aware that the most vulnerable people are those people who, because of the circumstances of their working lives, do not have any savings other than superannuation. We need to be conscious of the fact that the people about whom we are particularly talking are those people who do not have any savings other than superannuation as a result of hard work during their working lives and who also do not have an asset, in the form of their house, worth half a million or a million dollars to fall back on. This is an important point to make in this debate. It is important that we do not forget about these people.
It is my view that the government have a secret agenda to increase the preservation age for superannuation. After reading carefully some of the statements that have come from the government, I think they have a secret agenda to increase the preservation age of people's superannuation to 65 or to 70. This would have a devastating effect on the people I am talking about—the people who, because of the hard work they have done in their working lives, are unlikely to live for 30 or 40 years after turning 65. We need to be very careful that measures that are taken in relation to superannuation do not lead us to a circumstance whereby these people end up not being able to enjoy the superannuation they have worked so hard during their lives to get.
A leaked department of finance document which was produced in April 2002 proposed increasing the superannuation access age and the age pension age to 70. You can imagine what the impact of that would be on the type of people I am talking about. This document recommended a number of measures that are now government policy, including changes to the PBS and disability support pension. On that basis alone, it is likely, given that so many things in that document have already been implemented by the government, that they will now move on to increasing the preservation age of superannuation.
The Treasurer, Peter Costello, in his address to the Australian Financial Review's so-called leaders' luncheon on 7 August 2002 said:
The decline in participation projected in the IGR is also driven by the fact that many Australians seem to stop work shortly after they turn 55.
...	...	...
More flexible working arrangements, training and re-training, and raising the preservation age for superannuation would all be positive moves to address this issue.
John Howard has had a bit to say about this as well. He said to a Financial Planning Association conference in November 2002:
We have to recognise that the cult of early retirement that we encouraged so enthusiastically as a community a generation ago, it should be changed.
When asked about this issue in Senate question time, the minister directly responsible for superannuation, Senator Coonan, refused to rule out increasing the preservation age to 65 or, even higher, to 70. So the claims I make in this House are not without some justification.
People who are looking forward to getting their superannuation when they turn 55 or 60 are right to be worried about this. The government has the power to change this legislation, to change the rules in relation to superannuation preservation age, whenever it wants. It has the power to do that. For my part—and I know this is a strong view taken by the opposition—I will oppose increases to the preservation age. We view it as an attempt to force Australians to work longer. When it comes to superannuation policy, we think the government has failed. Its solution for retirement incomes is to try to force Australians to work until they drop. To some people, that might sound like a dramatic thing to say, but I would say that those people do not really understand the nature of the sectors of the economy that we are talking about. 
I know there are some people in this place who have had experience with people who have worked in the coalmining industry and the mining industry more generally. Occupational health and safety is a lot better now than it used to be. There are a lot of people working in the coalmining industry now who have worked in that industry for 30 years. They have not had the benefit over the whole of their working lives of the safe—or, certainly, improved—occupational health and safety practices which they have enjoyed for the last five or 10 years. Their bodies have taken the full impact of the physical toughness associated with working in that sector, and that will mean something when they retire at 60 or 65. It will mean, for at least some of the people in that industry—and certainly for a larger proportion of people from that industry than the proportion of people employed in the banking industry who might be affected—that they are unlikely to enjoy a long retirement. This is something which we need to be very careful about.
The occupations that I am talking about are very physically demanding. The timber industry, the dairy manufacturing industry, the coalmining sector and the construction sector are very physically tough and demanding industries. Because of that, it is unrealistic to expect people in these industries to work until they are 65 or 70, which seems to be what the Prime Minister is trying to do. If that happens, we may end up with a large number of people employed in those industries and other physically tough and demanding industries being unlikely to make it to an age at which they can access superannuation. If this is the case, those people's hard work and labour will have been in vain. Those people's hard work and the contribution they have made during their working life will not deliver them a dividend at all—it will not deliver the dividend they have worked so hard to eventually get. So we need to be careful, when we talk about this, not to allow a circumstance to arise whereby the government can get away with secretly increasing the preservation age of superannuation.
In the last few minutes that I have to make my contribution to the debate on this legislation, I make this point as well: we think that, when it comes to superannuation, the government should find it in its heart to provide 100 per cent compensation for people who, through no fault of their own, have had their superannuation moneys taken away from them through theft and fraud. It is not their fault that they have been subject to trickery and deceit on the part of the shysters involved in scams in the superannuation industry. We think that it is within the power of the government to provide for those people and to make sure that they do not lose all of their life's work and their contribution to their savings through superannuation just because of the misbehaviour of some people involved in scams and shonky behaviour in the superannuation industry. If the government understood a bit better how vulnerable some people are when it comes to their superannuation—that is, that it is the only savings they have—they would understand a bit more how important this is. (Time expired)

name: Slipper, Peter, MP
text:
—Listening to the contributions made by honourable members of the opposition, one could overlook the fact that these bills are actually supported by both sides of the House. The amendments contained in the Superannuation (Financial Assistance Funding) Levy Amendment Bill 2002 and the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Amendment Bill 2002 are designed to improve the workability of the levy collection processes that underpin the provision of financial assistance to superannuation funds that have suffered loss due to fraudulent conduct or theft.
Over the past year, the government has provided assistance to 465 superannuation funds formerly under the trusteeship of Commercial Nominees of Australia Ltd and has also provided financial assistance to the Australian Independent Superannuation Fund. These funds have suffered a substantial diminution in assets as a result of fraudulent conduct or theft. This assistance was provided in accordance with part 23 of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act, which provides that a levy can be charged on superannuation funds to provide the funds necessary to pay for financial assistance. This levy is imposed under the Superannuation (Financial Assistance Funding) Levy Act. While these provisions were enacted in 1993, during the tenure of the former Labor government, they have never previously been used.
Preliminary work on designing levies to recoup the cost of financial assistance has shown that the collection process as set out in the legislation is somewhat flawed, and the purpose of the bills before the chamber is to improve matters with respect to these points. These bills are designed to remedy these problems and distribute the burden of levies across the superannuation industry on a more equitable and administratively efficient basis. The bills enable a reasonable upper and lower limit to be imposed on levies charged. The existing arrangements would impose a heavy burden on larger superannuation funds, while the charge on smaller funds would be too small to be collected in an administratively efficient manner.
The bills will also reduce the administrative burden on funds through enabling a single levy to be struck covering the aggregate amount of financial assistance provided in one financial year. As the legislation currently stands, a levy would have to be imposed for each individual grant of financial assistance to a superannuation fund. These measures are designed to reduce compliance costs for all superannuation funds and, as you would imagine, are supported by the industry. It is proposed that regulations be made pursuant to the Superannuation (Financial Assistance Funding) Levy Act 1993 to recoup financial assistance paid by the government prior to the end of this financial year. I take this opportunity to call on all honourable members to ensure that the levy charged can take into account these changes and reduce the administrative and cost burden that would eventuate under the current provisions.
As my friend the member for Kingston is so apt to do, even though he says that he does not want to deny the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Amendment Bill 2002 a second reading, he has moved a pious second reading amendment to it. As I have said to him over and over again during debates on various pieces of legislation, the government cannot be expected to accept such a second reading amendment when its terms are so patently unreasonable. As I said, the member for Kingston did agree with the provisions of the bill designed to improve the administrative efficiency of the levy collection process, and that is a good thing. However, the second reading amendment referred to a whole raft of matters, including the safety of superannuation and a condemnation of the government for what the member for Kingston believed was a mean-spirited approach in providing less than 100 per cent compensation. The honourable member for McMillan, who spoke a moment ago, also referred to that issue of 100 per cent compensation. The member for Kingston in his second reading amendment also called on the government to expand the definition of eligible loss to provide compensation in circumstances beyond fraud and theft. 
Let me educate the honourable member for Kingston. In relation to superannuation safety, superannuation is a key element of the strategy of the government to address the long-term consequences of an ageing population. The government considers that it is imperative that the community has full confidence that the prudential regulatory framework applying to superannuation is strong and robust. The trustee of a superannuation fund bears primary responsibility for the viability and prudent operation of the fund under the current system of prudential regulation set out in the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act of 1993. The government has established a prudential regulatory framework to increase the safety of superannuation, and APRA is responsible for supervision under this framework. 
In 2001 the government increased funding to APRA to support its more proactive approach to the supervision of superannuation. In an industry of over $500 billion—and that is a lot of money in anyone's terms—the industry's non-investment losses have been minimal to date, totalling less than 0.01 per cent of total assets. Notwithstanding this, the government has taken steps to improve the safety of superannuation and establish the Superannuation Working Group to undertake industry consultations and report to the government with legislative options for improving the prudential framework. On 28 October last year the government released its response to the SWG's report. Legislation will be introduced into parliament as soon as possible to give effect to these proposals. They will further improve the safety of superannuation, including requiring all trustees to be licensed, all APRA regulated funds to be registered with APRA, and all trustees to have in place a risk management plan for the trustee and each fund under its trusteeship. 
The member for McMillan and others, including the member for Kingston, referred to the question of compensation of less than 100 per cent. The opposition's continued attempts to increase the amount paid in compensation to 100 per cent of the eligible loss clearly indicates that the Australian Labor Party does not understand the basics of internationally recognised financial regulation principles. Standard internationally recognised practice is to place a cap on payments or to provide a percentage based level of compensation. Notwithstanding comments from the opposition, the policy of the government is entirely consistent with that adopted by the former Labor government. In this case, the opposition has moved away from the policies espoused by the predecessor government to the government currently in office. 
In 1991 the then Labor government introduced legislation to enable compensation in the life insurance industry after the failure of two life insurance companies due to fraud—Occidental and Regal. The member for Barton, sitting opposite, would recall the introduction of that legislation. He would also recall—because he is someone who does indeed look back in history at what has occurred before—that the then Labor government, with its legislation, limited restitution to 90 per cent. So what we are doing in this bill is entirely consistent both with the approach of former governments and with sound, internationally recognised appropriate practice.  
I would like to refer to the question of the expansion of the definition of an `eligible loss'. The Superannuation Working Group examined the expansion of the definition of an `eligible loss' for the purposes of part 23 of the SI(S) Act. The Superannuation Working Group recommended that no changes be made to part 23 until the first determinations were made under the provisions and a full review could be undertaken of the provisions. The government has announced that it will be reviewing part 23 and will be consulting with all interested parties in this process. One of the hallmarks of this government is that we have a very sound consultation process, because we want to make sure that we get things right. 
The member for Braddon raised his concerns that the government may be contemplating rises in the preservation age for superannuation. The government provides substantial tax concessions for superannuation in order to promote self-provision for retirement. Appropriate restrictions on the release of superannuation moneys are required to ensure that superannuation is used to provide for genuine retirement income and is not dissipated earlier. Superannuation benefits must generally remain preserved until preservation age, which is currently 55. The government has increased the preservation age from 55 to 60 on a phased basis between the years 2015 and 2025. This phased increase was announced in the 1997-1998 budget. So perhaps the member for Braddon ought to catch up with what has occurred before. 
The government understands that working Australians look forward to, and make plans for, their retirement. Such a phased introduction is intended to minimise disruption to such plans and to enable time for adjustment. Many Australians are also choosing at present to continue working after reaching preservation age, while looking forward to their retirement years. In recognition of this, Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins, you will be pleased to hear that the government has increased the maximum age limit for personal superannuation contributions from 70 to 75. This measure commenced on 1 July last year. Of course, many Australians also have savings in vehicles outside of superannuation which will assist in self-funding retirement, such as shares and real estate, and which are not subject to preservation rules. 
The member for Blaxland, the successor to the former Prime Minister, Mr Keating, raised a number of points in this debate. He claimed that the government has consistently overplayed its contribution to reducing government debt and that all governments have historically relied on debt to finance their activities. I do not think the Australian public these days accept that you can run a government in a way differently from the way that you would run your own household financial affairs. People expect governments not to spend more than they earn. People expect governments to pay their way. That was one of the reasons why the budget delivered by the Treasurer this week was so responsible. Despite very difficult economic circumstances, despite September 11 and all of the problems which flowed from the challenges to security, despite the drought, and despite the costs of the war in Iraq, the government was able to achieve a budget surplus of $2.2 billion and return to the Australian people $2.4 billion in tax cuts. 
Some people have wrongly criticised the magnitude of those tax cuts. Any tax cuts are good—the bigger the better. What the government has done is to return a financial dividend to the Australian people as, in effect, a reward for the sound economic management of this government. We had some money that we could return by way of tax cuts and we have given that money back to the Australian people—and I think that is a very appropriate way to go.  
I think it is sad that the member for Blaxland seems to think that high levels of debt are the way to go. He seems to think that deficit budgeting is a great idea. I think he is out of touch with what ordinary decent Australians are now saying. They expect this government—and future governments in Australia—not to spend more than they raise. He also claimed that the government's HECS and Medicare policies are stupid. And he made an absolutely bizarre comment—that the Keating government did not renege on the l-a-w tax cuts. I can see that the member for Barton is smiling as I speak. The member for Blaxland claimed that the Keating government simply repackaged them into an alternative delivery vehicle—that is, government contributions to super—and that this was knocked on the head by the Howard government. The member for Blaxland is not a bad sort of guy; he is just entirely out of touch on these particular issues. My response to him is that members opposite are attempting to play down the significance of the program of debt reduction undertaken by the Howard government. For the benefit of the honourable member for Blaxland I remind him that, by June this year, we will have reduced the $96,000 million debt burden left by Labor by around $63 billion.
This is not some idle technical comment. This means that the interest paid is so much less than would otherwise be the case and, as we pay off those Labor debts, it means that we are able to spend money on productive activity. By reducing the government's interest bill by billions of dollars each year we now have more money to invest in better things like health and education. We saw that extra moneys were being spent in relation to both of those areas as announced in the Treasurer's budget earlier this week. Not only is our debt repayment record outstanding, so too are our budget management credentials. 
This can be contrasted with the appalling mess left by the Keating and Hawke Labor governments. We all know that Labor left a $10 billion black hole in the budget, with waste and extravagance a hallmark of their economic management. In the 1996 election campaign, the then Keating government was claiming that the budget was in surplus and that everything was in the black; yet just after the election we got the bad news that there was a $10 billion black hole in the budget. That was why this government had to make some rather difficult economic decisions. We did not create the problem but we did accept the responsibility for fixing the problem, and that is what we have continued to do. On economic management, the numbers speak for themselves. Interest rates are around their lowest levels in 30 years, unemployment is around its lowest rate in 10 years, and more than one million jobs have been created since March 1996. The government is proud of its debt payment record, its budget and its economic management.
So while one always expects in a robust parliament like the Australian parliament that members of the opposition will endeavour to make cheap political points and to huff and puff, this government has not only rhetoric but also runs on the board. Since we were elected to office in 1996 we have provided sound economic management. We are a responsible government. On Tuesday the Treasurer brought down a responsible budget, and the feedback which I have received from around the community is that the budget has been welcomed as an economically responsible document. As I said at the outset, these two bills are supported by the opposition. The government welcomes that support. We look forward to the passage of these two bills through the chamber. I just reiterate that we will be rejecting the second reading amendment moved by the honourable member for Kingston. 
 (Mr Jenkins)—The original question was that this bill be now read a second time. To this the honourable member for Kingston has moved as an amendment that all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting other words. The question now is that the words proposed to be omitted stand part of the question.
Question agreed to.
Original question agreed to. 
Bill read a second time.

name: McClelland, Robert, MP
text:
—The opposition is opposing a second reading of the Workplace Relations Amendment (Termination of Employment) Bill 2002. It is a significant bill. It proposes to override state unfair dismissal laws insofar as those laws apply to corporations. Any instance where this parliament seeks to override state laws is of significance because we are here as part of a federal system of government and we should not ignore the significance of this parliament attempting to override state laws. That is the first reason of significance.
The second reason of significance is the cost implications that this bill will have. I note that the explanatory memorandum refers to and acknowledges the fact that there will be an increase in unfair dismissal cases to be dealt with by the federal commission; the budget papers refer to about a 75 per cent increase. The explanatory memorandum notes that appointment of additional members to the commission may be necessary. In fact, the budget papers indicate that the cost of appointing additional commissioners—and I suppose registry staff, accommodation and the like—will be some $16.8 million over four years. That is a significant expense and one that we believe cannot be justified because it is duplicating resources which are already spent in the state system. In particular, there will still be cause for state jurisdictions to engage state industrial commissioners and judges, many of whom have security of tenure, and there will still be residual jurisdiction in those states resulting from the need to continue to deal with unfair dismissal claims in small business, partnerships, charities and other institutions. 
So we are seeing again a duplication of resources. In terms of resources, we are not simply talking about personnel; we are also talking about registries and registry staff. The state systems tend to have quite sophisticated registry outlets—certainly more sophisticated than the Commonwealth's Industrial Relations Commission registry structure—with the ability to undertake circuits in their regional areas, taking their services to the people, for instance. So, regrettably, one of the significant downsides of this bill is that we will lose not only expertise that exists in the state systems but also access to those resources.
Having said that, establishing uniformity in industrial relations is an issue which is of significant importance to the nation. All political parties in the federal system, as I understand their positions, think that is something we should work towards achieving. My concern is that the methods adopted in respect of this bill leave a lot to be desired and are quite contrary to achieving that long-term outcome of greater uniformity of the industrial relations system generally. It is acknowledged that we are a country of 20 million people, and it is silly, quite frankly, to have six disparate industrial relations systems, and the Labor Party recognises that. There are ways of achieving uniformity without having an arrogant federal override of state laws but rather by working towards achieving cooperative schemes. It must be acknowledged that we are in some part there, with many instances of state commission judges and commissioners receiving dual commissions on the federal body.
These things are not impossible; cooperative schemes can be achieved without a state override. But, when you look at the options considered in the explanatory memorandum on page 5, you see that no option of establishing such a cooperative scheme based perhaps on uniform principles was considered. Nor was there consideration given, in the implementation stages of this bill, to holding negotiations with the states perhaps with an appropriate reference of unfair dismissal powers and with appropriate safeguards in place, such as those that exist in respect of the Corporations Law where the states have said, `Look, these are the parameters on which we agree to refer powers to the Commonwealth.' These things were not explored as options and were not considered. That is regrettable. I think it is rude and somewhat arrogant to treat state governments that way—and one must ask whether they would have been treated similarly if they were of the same political persuasion as the government? I think to ask that question answers it, quite frankly. Aside from that, it is contrary to all expert advice as to how to achieve a national uniform system or greater uniformity in this important area.
For instance, the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry—a body not known for its praise of the Labor opposition nor, indeed, for its criticism of the government—in its advocacy for uniformity has laid out a case for harmonisation of the national workplace relations system, and we have to agree with its objective. It has said, `There needs to be a nine-step orderly development phase.' At the risk of boring people by quoting the ACCI, I think what it says is worth noting. It says:
The objective would need to focus on exploring the concept with the maximum possible bipartisan national support ... 
That certainly has not occurred here. It goes on:
and in a constructive nonpolitical manner.
Again that has not occurred here. It continues:
An open-minded approach would need to be adopted ...
That has not been adopted here. Basically the legislation before us says, `Well, here you are; cop this.' It then goes on:
particularly by governments (federal and state), with a recognition by all parties of the legitimate role each jurisdiction has historically [had] and currently exercises in the system.
The state systems have operated for longer than the federal system; we did not have a federal system until about 1903. So to ignore that and, indeed, the innovations and, in some cases, the restraints that state systems have been responsible for putting in place, particularly in the area of unfair dismissal laws, is really quite short-sighted. The ACCI goes on:
The initial focus would have to be on confidence building and an objective analysis of options and models for change—
if we look at the explanatory memorandum, there has not been such an objective analysis of options and models for change—
without requiring any interested party to commit to a position or formulate definitive policy during the development phase.
I suppose that has been complied with, because they were not invited to submit to a position. Basically, it was said, `Look, here you are; cop this.' The ACCI goes on to say:
At the end of the day, the content of the system will determine whether it has acceptance by employer and employee interests.
And, I have to add, by the respective governments. What use is it having a system of industrial laws applying to unfair dismissal laws when there is inevitably going to be a challenge in the High Court as to whether it is a legitimate use of the Corporations Law or, indeed, when unfair dismissal claims commenced in a state jurisdiction will inevitably lead to an argument as to whether, for instance, a charity or a statutory instrumentality of some description is or is not a corporation and, therefore, whether the state system still has jurisdiction? All these things will be out there. All these things could have been avoided with a cooperative approach.
Professor Ron McCallum—for whom, I have to concede, I have considerable respect, unlike the ACCI—is perhaps more critical of the government than the Labor opposition, although we get a serve from him from time to time. He has argued that, if a robust national industrial relations system is to be created, governments must refrain from seeking short-term political advantage. They should instead focus on long-term, consultative strategies for bringing about a robust national labour law regime. We are committed to that object of a national robust labour law regime based on cooperation with the state systems. The way the government has gone about this is extremely short-sighted, because it is only going to impede that process. Quite frankly, it is quite annoying that the course of action has been taken as it has, because the government's actions will cause a significant retarding of that important object.
Justice Giudice, the President of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, has also been a strong and logical advocate of the need for greater uniformity in our industrial relations system. Indeed, he goes back to the well-known Hancock report that was the basis of amendments to the Industrial Relations Act. I think the Hancock report recommendations were implemented in 1988. Commenting on what was needed in the future beyond those amendments, Justice Giudice referred to the recommendations which said: 
The Australian Government should seek the co-operation of the States in establishing, in both the short term and the long term, a viable, co-ordinated, acceptable and effective industrial relations system.
Under the heading `The Long Term', the quote continues:
As to the long term, the Australian Government should initiate discussions with the States with a view to putting an integrated system of industrial relations into place. The matter is of such importance that it should be raised initially at a Premier's Conference.
We do indeed agree that it is an important matter. The quote goes on:
The matter should be treated as a priority item in the Premier's Conference and pursued through the Conference of Labour Ministers. A Steering Committee of the Conference of Labour Ministers should be established to give directions to a Working Party consisting of Commonwealth and State officials and representative of the industrial parties ...
Justice Giudice also recounted how a uniform companies law came about: by consultation and cooperation, not by legislative fiat and attempts to override state laws. 
They are three wise principles to indicate how greater national uniformity can be achieved in the important area of industrial relations. It is only going to be achieved in the long term by cooperation. Everyone has to get that straight, otherwise, as this area is so fraught with complexities, you are simply going to have years and years of constitutional challenges. It is inevitable. Lawyers will love a noncooperative approach. We should be interested in the wellbeing of our nation—and I believe achieving greater uniformity of industrial laws is a significant part of achieving national wellbeing—yet the approach taken by the government is not only rude and arrogant, quite frankly, but also extremely short-sighted.
As I understand it, there was a meeting of relevant state industrial relations and workplace relations ministers on 8 November last year, but the proposal to use Commonwealth Corporations Law powers to override state systems was not discussed. Yet, on 10 November, an article by Michelle Grattan, titled `Abbott to strip states' IR power', appeared in the Sunday Age, and indicated that a bill would be introduced in parliament on the following day. Clearly, a briefing had been provided to at least Michelle Grattan on the day that discussions were taking place with state ministers. I would submit that that is, quite frankly, unacceptable in anyone's books.
The other point we would make is that, if you are going to seek to override state laws, firstly, it should be done by cooperation and, secondly, it should be done properly, not in a piecemeal way. You should take over the jurisdiction entirely, which the government is not doing because of its ideological revulsion about using the external affairs power of the Constitution and, in particular, relying on convention No. 150 of the International Labour Organisation in respect of termination of employment. The government's revulsion goes back a long way, but it was best expressed by the Prime Minister with respect to the Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993, which first included in federal industrial legislation the unfair dismissal powers—based in part on convention No. 150 of the ILO. The Prime Minister, who was not the Prime Minister at the time but the member for Bennelong, said:
The other objectionable feature of this bill is the unnecessary use of the external affairs power of the constitution. This government has perverted and undermined the constitutional balance of this country by its remorseless use of the external affairs power.
There is some hypocrisy in the government being prepared to undermine the constitutional balance of this country using the Corporations Law but not recognising the existence of an external affairs power. There should not be an undermining of the constitutional balance without a cooperative and consultative approach. The government has done that, but in this case it has only gone the half monty, for reasons of this ideological cringe when it comes to relying on the external affairs power. That is significant and it is brought out in a very strong submission by the Queensland government to the Senate inquiry examining this bill. 
As I previously mentioned, the areas of small business, partnerships, charities and state instrumentalities are going to be left uncovered by the legislation. In other words, there will still be a need for state unfair dismissal jurisdictions. The Queensland government argued—I think correctly—that this is going to create additional confusion. They say there are:
·	two different sets of federal laws and procedures governing unfair dismissal matters, depending on the size of the respondent;
·	different federal and state unfair dismissal regimes for incorporated and unincorporated entitles;
·	different federal and state unfair dismissal regimes for incorporated entities, depending on whether they meet the definition of a `constitutional corporation';
·	concurrent but separate federal and state jurisdiction over different aspects of workplace relations in the one business, for example a federal regime governing a business' unfair dismissals and a state regime governing workplace harassment and industrial disputes; and
·	concurrent but separate federal and state jurisdiction over different aspects of the one employee's claim (for example, the federal regime for unfair dismissal and the state regime for insufficient notice or unpaid entitlements).
These things could have been resolved by a cooperative approach, with the development of an agreed code or principles to be applied in all jurisdictions. But no attempt has been made to do that.
In terms of unfair dismissal law, the Labor Party has said, and I have said, that it is inappropriate to remove from any Australian citizen—whether he or she is the Governor-General or a worker in a factory—the right to a fair go. That is what the government's previous focus—not in this bill, I concede—in the unfair dismissal laws has been.
A further Senate references committee which inquired into matters affecting small business found that this concern about unfair dismissal has been greatly overstated and greatly exaggerated by the government. There are a range of other concerns: red tape, taxes, access to facilities, management training, and selection and recruitment of talented staff. All of these things are of much greater concern to small business. Some do have concerns about small business—perhaps they have experienced an unfair dismissal claim or at least heard of those occurring—but the concerns appear to be more related to complexity and cost. We concede that there are measures that can be taken to reduce complexity and cost, and we have suggested some approaches in a private member's bill introduced by the Leader of the Opposition. 
We do recognise that there are some principles contained in this bill that are worthy of consideration. In particular, we agree with one clause of the bill which places a primary emphasis on reinstatement, and we think that requiring the commission to regard that as the major purpose of the legislation has merit.
We also recognise that there is some merit in having, effectively, a gateway procedure or a vetting process where the commission or a relevant officer vets applications to take out those matters that are clearly without merit, but we have concerns that there are not sufficient safeguards in place for an applicant there. We do acknowledge that it is appropriate for that vetting to occur, in many instances without requiring an employer to incur the expense of obtaining advice and coming along to the commission. However, we believe that an applicant whose case is going to be vetted should, if informed of the opportunity, have a right of appearance before the relevant officer to argue their case.  
We think procedural fairness dictates that that applicant be informed of the opportunity to come along and argue why they have a legitimate case. I would concede that it may be unnecessary to require the employer to come along at that point; nonetheless, we think an applicant should be given the opportunity to appear. We have to recognise that, in many cases, many workers either will not be fluent in English or will not have the literacy skills, which we would hope all workers would have in this day and age, and may not be able to set out their case in writing. But if they are given the opportunity of explaining themselves face to face, they may well establish that they do have a legitimate case.
We also recognise the validity of another principle contained in a section of the bill which seeks to take out challenge to unfair dismissal as it applies to small businesses on the basis of procedural technicality. However, the bill is expressed in terms of empowering the commission to have regard in those instances of small business to listed criteria—criteria that it shall consider and only consider. The bill then sets out relevant dot points of the only matters the commission can consider. What is left out is failure to comply with procedural requirements. We would concede, and I do recognise, that that relevant section importantly says that it operates on the basis that the employer has given the employee an opportunity to respond to the allegations against them. A basic requirement of procedural fairness is there, giving the employee who is going to be dismissed the opportunity of responding to the allegation. But it is too prescriptive, we would submit, to set out those and only those reasons. There may be other reasons why a dismissal has been unfair. 
We would concede that, in circumstances where a small business does not have a dedicated human resources manager and where they do not have the processes in place, providing a dismissal is fair and reasonable in substance, it should not be set aside or vitiated simply because of the failure of the employer to comply with some technical procedural requirement. That is a reasonable principle to uphold; but, again, we believe that the way it is expressed is too restrictive and could in those circumstances have a harsh effect.
We do, however, have problems with other provisions that seek to reduce the entitlement of employees, particularly in circumstances where, if they lose their job, they are in a vulnerable situation. We have concerns in the following areas. Firstly, the bill proposes to reduce the amount of compensation that can be awarded to an unfairly dismissed employee, in that a business with fewer than 20 employees would reduce the entitlement to compensation from 26 weeks to 13 weeks pay. Again we say that is arbitrary and may not enable the commission to perform fairness. Secondly, the bill proposes to extend the qualifying period of employment before unfair dismissal action can be brought by an employee against a small business from three months to six months. We have previously expressed our concerns about that, although we have agreed that three months is a reasonable probationary period on the basis of custom and practice. 
Thirdly, the bill proposes to narrow the scope for an employee made redundant by his or her employer in respect of dismissals arising from the operational requirements of the business, other than in exceptional circumstances. The dismissal of a large number of employees as a result of restructuring, technological change and so forth is a complex area. There are instances where it has been done very well by corporations and governments alike—for instance, BHP in Newcastle, where there was a broad consultative process. We recognise that there are others where it has just been atrocious. Indeed, the Australian Bureau of Statistics indicates that in 25 per cent of cases workers retrenched receive less than one day's notice. That is completely unacceptable. If there were a regime in place that required negotiation of procedures to be followed in identifying those employees who were to be made redundant in the situation of technological change, restructuring and the like, we would be prepared to look at that. But the simple removal of rights because an employee has lost his or her job in those circumstances is unacceptable. 
In summary, we recognise the object of this bill is to achieve uniformity, but the way it has been pursued is quite outrageous. There are some principles in the bill which people of fair mind could agree with. By sitting down and working through these with the states, I believe that we could have had agreement on them, but regrettably that has not occurred. (Time expired)

name: Randall, Don, MP
text:
—It is my pleasure this morning to speak on the Workplace Relations Amendment (Termination of Employment) Bill 2002. This bill has come before this House in some form or another eight times over the last several years. The opposition spokesman, the member for Barton, speaks of consultation: you cannot have a better consultative process than to have a bill like this brought into the chamber for debate eight times. Ultimately, the Labor Party, as a result of motions from their federal conference, are ideologically obliged to oppose this bill. Their lives depend on it. Those in the federal conference put them in this House and control them while they are in this House. So, ultimately, those opposite are obliged to oppose this proposed unfair dismissal legislation. This is the most bizarre opposition you will ever come across. In years to come people will ask, `Why did you go to the barricades over this so many times?' It is just unnecessary. This is what this bill endeavours to address. 
These amendments would extend the operation of the federal unfair dismissal system by making greater use of the corporations power in section 51xx of the Constitution, improve the operation of the federal unfair dismissal laws as it impacts on small business and make a number of other improvements to the way the unfair dismissal laws operate, and expand the federal jurisdiction dealing with harsh, unjust or unreasonable dismissals—in other words, the federal unfair dismissal jurisdiction—so that it covers all employees of constitutional corporations in addition to employees currently covered under other constitutional powers. Presently, the corporations power is not used to its full extent. The federal unfair dismissal legislation applies only to employees of constitutional corporations who are also covered by federal awards or agreements. To ensure the effective operation of these new arrangements, the amendments would also prevent employees within the scope of federal unfair dismissal jurisdiction, which include those employees excluded from seeking a remedy, from accessing remedies under comparable state unfair dismissal schemes. However, the interaction of federal unfair dismissal law with other Commonwealth, state or territory law—for example, antidiscrimination law—remains largely unaffected. It is estimated that the number of employees covered by this expanded system would increase from approximately 3.9 million to 6.8 million—almost seven million people. 
Let me point out why there needs to be uniform unfair dismissal legislation. We only have to look at Western Australia as an example—and I will give an expanded example shortly. After the Gallop government came to power in Western Australia, the state industrial relations laws were taken back almost to the sixties. The state industrial relations minister, John Kobelke, was described by Kevin Reynolds of the CFMEU as `a weak little man'. As a result, this weak little man has acceded to the wishes of the larger union movement and has put in place draconian laws covering the way business is done in Western Australia at an industrial level. The unfair dismissal law in Western Australia previously had a sunset clause—a set period of time where those who believed they were unfairly dismissed could apply to have their cases assessed or reviewed. Under the new regime of the state government—and this is a little-known fact—their new laws give unfettered access, but there is no sunset clause in any unfair dismissal case in Western Australia now. For example, in 20 years time, if you consider that you had been unfairly dismissed, you could now go to that jurisdiction and say, `Look, I was unfairly dismissed. I want my day in court.' There is now no sunset clause in Western Australia, and that is a disgrace. The statute of limitations is meant to be six years, but the legislation in Western Australia overrides that. There need to be uniform unfair dismissal laws in this country to stop this bizarre situation of state governments going off on their own little frogmarch at the behest of the unions.
I would like to give another example of a jurisdictional situation in Western Australia which has federal implications. To give a bit of history, during the last state election we warned Western Australians that they were risking a recurrence of the WA Inc. era. It has happened again after only two years of the Gallop Labor government being in office—this time not with big business, but courtesy of the militant unionists, who we warned would be controlling the Labor government's agenda. The Western Australian Minister for Housing and Works, Tom Stephens—aka `the bent priest'—has issued an edict, under instruction from his powerful union bosses in the much discredited CFMEU, that effectively destroys the notion of competition and letting contracts to the lowest and best tenderer. In his new edict, leaked last week, he freely admitted that he sought to effectively limit the ability of the best and cheapest tenderer to get Western Australian government building contracts. This has federal implications, because federal moneys are involved—and I will outline that in the moment. He unilaterally acted on orders issued from his union masters. His office is loaded with ex-union heavyweights, including Anne Woods—his close adviser and a former staffer to both Mark McGowan and Norm Marlborough—who takes her orders directly from the union heavyweights in the CFMEU. 
Most officers in the Department of Housing and Works were disgusted with the ministerial directive, and I am informed that only one officer, Mr Ian Johnson, has direct communication with Anne Woods and the minister's office and those close to the CFMEU. But most officers have been absolutely committed to providing the Western Australian building industry with transparent and accountable tendering practices, ensuring the building and construction contracts in Western Australia were awarded to the cheapest and the best tenderer, regardless of their ties to the powerful `no ticket, no start' building unions. The ministerial direction is nothing more than a contrived scheme of arrangements that is designed to discriminate against the most competitive builders in the industry, especially those who have not succumbed to union thuggery and extortion. The royal commission report, in part, reads: 
The Commission has found conduct and practices on the part of certain persons in government in the period from 1983 to 1989 which were such as to place our government system at risk.
This is the risk I am talking about. What makes this episode so intriguing is that the main players of these disastrous years are still in the background pulling the strings. Unions in Western Australia had their wings well and truly clipped by the previous coalition government. However, Premier Gallop and his faceless ALP mates promised the unions that, once they were returned to office, they would be looked after. They were a bit slow in changing the industrial relations laws as per the unions' demands, so `Big Kev' came out and gave the Premier a bit of a touch-up.
With this win the CFMEU demanded more. It wanted the big construction companies to enter into an EBA with the CFMEU. Some companies agreed—that is, Mirvac Fini, Multiplex and Doric; this comes at a cost and has to be factored into their future tenders for Western Australian government contracts—some did not. I am told, for example, that Universal, Consolidated, Cooper Oxley, Estlemont and BGC have not signed on.
Premier Gallop came to `Big Kev's' rescue: he created the Western Australia Labour Relations Advisory Council. At the first meeting last month, the first item on the agenda was that BGC was getting too much government work and that it had not signed the union's EBA with the CFMEU. They read the riot act to `Big Kev's' factional ally, Tom Stephens, who was eager to please and fell into line. With the help of Anne Woods and the other architect of this ruse, his chief of staff, John Philmore, he signed off on the ministerial directive.
The ministerial directive essentially limits the number of contracts to the value above $1.5 million that can be awarded to any one company and he retains the right, as minister, to award any contract to whoever he likes. It is mate's rates at the whim of the minister. He already has in place a process whereby any job over $25 million, for example, has to be personally approved or ticked off by him. The bottom line is that this corrupt practice by this minister, in his efforts to appease his union masters, will cost Western Australian taxpayers dearly and the costs associated with each major building project will go through the roof with this policy. The cosy, under the table arrangement between the minister and the CFMEU is in place, but it has gone horribly wrong for them because it has been leaked to the press.
I believe the minister is acting in a corrupt manner. Premier Gallop needs to sack him over this issue because it is going to have Australia wide ramifications; in fact, a flow-on is imminent. Up until now, the Western Australian government and Mr Gallop have been silent on this issue hoping that a bit of bad press will go away and that a policy that suits their union mates and political masters will continue.
I have told my colleagues in the Commonwealth that the state housing agreement that is currently being renegotiated is at risk of this scandalous policy in Western Australia due to the minister—
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a question of relevance, under standing order 145. I think continual references to the corruption in state governments are inappropriate.
 (Mr Lindsay)—The member of Canning will bring his contribution back to the bill, please. 
—I suggest that this agreement probably breaches the agreement between the states because it does not deliver best value for money. That is my issue here. We have a federal-state arrangement with the state housing agreement which is meant to deliver best value for money, particularly in the area of welfare housing.
It was reported only yesterday in the Australian newspaper that Western Australia has a five-year waiting list for welfare and Aboriginal housing. It is the worst state in Australia for waiting lists. As a result, it has been factored in, for example, that if this policy goes ahead using federal moneys from one of our ministers up to 41 homes could be excluded from being built due to lack of federal moneys.
—I rise on a question of relevance, Mr Deputy Speaker. As I understand it, this bill is about workplace relations and termination of employment. I am not quite sure where the member for Canning gets this desire to talk about state public housing agreements and give his personal views on them.
—I thank the member for Bass. The member for Canning will be relevant to the bill.
—Just to show that I am relevant to the bill, in any matters that are before this House where we are talking about state and federal jurisdictions, I am not going to sit by idly, whether it concerns the unfair dismissal laws or the misuse of federal moneys, as in this case, and allow any form of government to get away with an absolute dereliction of duty in misspending federal moneys in particular. They complain that they do not have enough money at a state level.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I believe the member for Canning is defying your ruling. This is an IR bill. There are other forms of the House where he can raise his issues about state and Commonwealth housing agreements. There are many forms that the member can use, and I suggest he does so.
—The member for Bass makes a valid point. I invite the member for Canning to come back to the substance of the bill.
—I am, Mr Deputy Speaker. This issue, as I explained, has federal ramifications and it compares with what we are talking about in terms of unfair dismissal laws. As I have said, as a federal member from Western Australia I am entitled to highlight where I see corrupt practices returning to the state jurisdiction. I have made my point and I will continue speaking on the bill before us.
—I thank the member for Canning.
—Getting back to the specific items of the unfair dismissal law as they relate to the federal government and its jurisdiction in this area, I point out that as a federal government we need to enact laws which are responsible for national needs. The economy does not consist of discrete and insular sectors of commerce within each state or even nationally. Rather, it exists within world global markets and creates competition and independence within the economies of other nations. If Australian businesses operating in different states have to comply with different and possibly conflicting standards across our nine law-making jurisdictions, they will be less likely to be competitive.
The Australian Labor Party in particular make great fuss about the use of the Corporations Law. The member for Bass, very active as she is, is from Tasmania and it was her state that probably lit the fuse under this through former Prime Minister Bob Hawke, who enacted federal laws on the damming of the Franklin River. I would imagine that, being from her side of politics, she would have been quite excited about that. So you cannot have it both ways. You cannot have it one way on one particular issue and then when we have another issue before the House decide it is not the way to do business. 
The Labor Party previously has been very eager to jump to arguments about using the corporations power in federal intervention. As I said, the prime example was the damming of the Franklin River. However, when we are trying to do something for this nation generally and its workers, the members opposite kowtow again to their union mates because, as I said, it is part of Labor Party policy. And here we go again: an apologist for their union mates.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. That was an unfair reflection on members on this side of the House, and I ask that it be withdrawn.
 (Mr Lindsay)—I do not have a problem with it. However, I think the member for Canning should be careful in his contribution to the debate.
—Obviously, this contribution is hitting the spot. Otherwise the member for Bass would not be continually on her feet. Please, go again!
—I wouldn't be on my feet if you approached the bill. It's an industrial relations bill!
—The fact of the matter is that I have addressed the bill and the need for federal intervention into this aspect of state Labor governments. I have cited the example of Western Australia, where the new labour relations laws absolutely crucify small business. For example, I met recently with one of my constituents, Rocky Porcaro, an outdoor furniture small business operator. He was almost beside himself at the cost of having to appear on a regular basis before unfair dismissal jurisdictions in that state. That took not only his time but also a good deal of money to get legal advice. Then, as he said, they always say, `You're better off paying something out and settling because eventually you'll have to pay something out.' So he then pays. This is a small business man who tells me he works at least 70 hours a week trying to keep his business together. He takes a very small stipend out of his business to keep him and his family going. But, in keeping his business going with about a dozen employees, he is continually harassed by state unfair dismissal laws.
The Workplace Relations Amendment (Termination of Employment) Bill 2002 will create uniform laws around Australia to stop this sort of thuggery in state Labor jurisdictions. The exception is, of course, Victoria because they, under Jeff Kennett, quite wisely, handed over their jurisdiction to the Commonwealth. It will stop other state jurisdictions harassing small business people in this country, and allow them to get on with their businesses and give people jobs. They are the greatest employers of people in this country. For the Labor Party to get hostile about uniform legislation is just unbelievable. We know that, as a result of their national policy, they are not allowed to oppose this, as much as they would like to. In years to come people are going to punish the Labor Party because they will say that they were never interested in the welfare and rights of workers, particularly those in small business.
The Labor Party makes a great sway and says, `We'll challenge this sort of Corporations Law in the High Court, and it will go on for a long time,' et cetera. The best possible advice from a number of eminent constitutional lawyers is that that will not be the case at all. For example, just this morning, in the Australian newspaper, Flinders University law professor Andrew Stewart said that he expected that `a constitutional challenge would be mounted against any changes if the legislation were passed', but that, `such a challenge would be unlikely to succeed'. I rest my case. So it is all mock unction from the other side that this is going to be a process of harassment and delay. That is like the harassment and the delaying tactics the Labor Party are carrying on with now in the Senate, which they have done with this unfair dismissal law seven times previously. They have obfuscated, filibustered and used their mates in the Senate to block this law—a law that small business truly wants. 
On this point, I would like to say that I am really pleased to see the Democrats taking a sensible position on this, particularly Senator Murray, who is from Western Australia. As a small business man himself, he sees the need for uniform legislation in this area. Wiser heads like Senator Stott Despoja, Senator Allison and Senator Sherry, are people who have actually seen small business in operation. I am sure that they will look at this legislation and give it the benefit of the doubt, because it is in the interests of workers in small business. It is from that point of view that the Labor Party will, again, be left out of the argument because all they want to do is block, pillory and undo any positive thing that this government wants to do for workers in this country. The greatest myth in this country is that the Labor Party is for workers. It is not for workers; it is for the Labor Party elites and the elites in the union movement. Its interest in workers in this country is absolutely defunct, and it is morally bankrupt on the whole issue.

name: Mossfield, Frank, MP
text:
—The main purpose of the Workplace Relations Amendment (Termination of Employment) Bill 2002 is to expand the Australian Industrial Relations Commission's jurisdiction over unfair dismissal to include all employees in constitution corporations. Bills Digest No. 91, relating to this legislation, states:
... its purpose is to extend federal unfair dismissal coverage from about 4 million to 7 million Australian workers, thereby excluding the State jurisdictions from hearing most unfair dismissal cases and providing a single dismissal jurisdiction for companies. The Bill also introduces separate criteria and compensation for the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to apply when arbitrating a termination application from a small business employee, as well as extending the qualifying period of employment for small business employees (to 6 months before an application for a remedy—
against unfair dismissals—
can be made).
The Bill attempts to prevent an unfair dismissal application arising where the termination was made due to `operational reasons', ie in redundancy situations. The Bill also attempts to limit compensation payable by all businesses by having the Commission consider: any contributory conduct of the employee; whether the employee has benefited from a redundancy payment and what earnings an employee to be reinstated has earned in other employment.
We are now approaching double figures in the number of times this legislation to weaken the reinstatement rights of Australian workers has been introduced by the Howard government. On seven occasions we have seen unfair dismissal bills introduced—of course, the name was changed, in an Orwellian fashion, to `fair dismissal bills'. A number of sundry other bills making it harder for sacked workers to seek reinstatement or compensation have also been introduced by this government. In fact, Minister Abbott said, on 6 March this year:
As members would know only too well, this matter has been considered at exhaustive length by this House. Some 27 times in this place and in another place this matter has been dealt with in one way or another.
You would have thought that the government would have got the hint by now. 
It could be said that this legislation and the numerous others preceding it go to the cornerstone of the policies of both major parties. In the coalition's case, it is to go flat out to strengthen the hand of the employer. Indeed, the Howard government has attempted to pervert and undermine the industrial relations laws of this country to achieve this objective. On the other side of the fence, the Labor opposition and our industrial partners in the trade union movement are remorseless in the protection of workers' rights in all aspects of industrial relations. We make no apologies for this. We will always protect workers.
We must not forget the previous minister for workplace relations, who set dogs loose on the waterfront and brought industrial mayhem to this country and who said, `Never forget which side we're on. We're on the side of making profits. We're on the side of people owning private capital.' This government is not on the side of workers, without whom profits would be nonexistent and the economy would crumble. Instead, the government is on the side of the employer—the side of big business. This legislation and all those other attempts that have gone before are clear indications that this government cares nothing about the rights of the workers and nothing about the obligations of employers. Labor offer a clear alternative. We are on the side of the workers, the average Australian trying to make ends meet in the so-called economic boom. 
One of the major elements of this bill is the use of the corporations power, section 51(xx) of the Constitution, to override state legislation. The bill in its present form will create legal complications in cases where current state legislation covers regulatory matters affecting unfair dismissals. The states are concerned by the federal government's attempt to override properly functioning laws that are part of state legislation. The Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations has made a pre-emptive strike, in that the budget has already allocated $16.8 million to employ 12 new commissioners to handle the expected increased workload as the federal government assumes the states' responsibilities in these matters. This legislation has not been passed, yet the budget contains money to allow that process to be implemented. It is ironic that the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and the Prime Minister—who are among the most ardent states righters—should be introducing this legislation to take control of policy away from the states and centralise it in the federal government.
There is also a serious concern that the complexities and confusion that do occasionally arise from conflicting and overlapping jurisdictions would be made worse if this bill were to pass. An example of what the overlapping of state and federal industrial laws could result in is that a state award employee of a constitutional corporation with a claim for unfair dismissal and withholding of wages would need to lodge claims in both the federal and state jurisdictions—one for the unfair dismissal component and the other for the wage component. Clearly, this will result in a more complex legislative system, as was stated by Professor Andrew Stewart. In writing about the complexities of the Workplace Relations Act, he said:
They are very hard for ordinary workers or managers to understand, necessitating legal advice for even the simplest procedures. Instead of simply empowering the Australian Industrial Relations Commission (AIRC) to deal with certain claims and providing broad guidance as to how to do so, as most State laws do, the legislation seeks to regulate each step of the process in ever-increasing detail. As is generally the way when Parliament tries to anticipate and counter every eventuality, this level of detail simply creates potential gaps and uncertainties for litigants and their lawyers to exploit. 
This complexity will increase the number of unfair dismissal claims that are settled outside the court, because of the time and expense incurred by both employers and employees in preparing submissions to the Industrial Relations Commission.
In a submission to the Senate inquiry, the Australian Industry Group claimed that figures show that the number of unfair dismissal cases settled at the conciliation stage increased from 53 per cent in 1995-96 to 75 per cent in 2001-02. If this were the unintended consequences of this legislation—that is, that claims are settled by conciliation—it would be welcomed by this side of the House. 
As this legislation seeks to broaden the jurisdiction of previous legislation passed by this House relating to unfair dismissals,I will paraphrase some of the arguments that I have used previously in this debate. Firstly, the industrial relations laws in Australia are formulated on the basis of a master and servant relationship, whereby the employer has the ultimate authority to hire and fire and has the absolute advantage over his employees. This advantage is strengthened in this current period of soft employment opportunities, when unemployment has been in second gear at between six and eight per cent for the last six years. Indeed, the Treasurer said in his budget speech that unemployment was steady at six per cent. Does that mean steady as she goes? Does that mean the government is happy with six per cent? It seems to me that the government is happy with the six per cent and it is making no effort to reduce it.
Another major problem is that over this period we have seen a steady erosion of long-term full-time employment and the term `job security' has been replaced with the term `casualisation of the work force'. We regularly see in our newspapers headlines such as `Biggest work rate fall in seven years', which was in the Sydney Morning Herald in April this year, and `Jobless rate tipped to rise as work dries up', which was in the Sydney Morning Herald in May this year.  Australian Bureau of Statistics figures show that, between 1984 and 1999, there was an increase of over 117 per cent in casual employment, while at the same time there was only a 19 per cent increase in the permanent work force. In 1984 casuals made up only 15.8 per cent of the work force. By 1999 the figure had risen to over 26 per cent. The drip-down effect of this casualisation is that in many industries the labour market is based on short-term contracts with increasing periods of unemployment. In many cases, this leads to a reluctant withdrawal from the work force of many workers, with associated increased reliance on the social security system. 
In many cases, Australian workers also face the double whammy effect of high living costs and low wages, leading to an increased number of working poor, as an article in a local paper in my electorate indicates. The headline of this article in the BlacktownAdvocate says `Families in poor state'. This article makes the same point as I am making. It says:
Growth in the numbers of “working poor” in western Sydney is outstretching the resources of Anglicare, one of the region's biggest welfare providers.
It quotes a spokesman for that organisation, who says:
“We are scratching the surface of what is a growing crisis in the west”...
Further on, it says:
Mr Coller said despite public perception, growing numbers of callers were not welfare-dependent but hard-working families struggling to make ends meet.
He blamed the growing yet hidden poverty affecting families on the inflated cost of living in Australia's most expensive city. 
He also said:
“Over 40 per cent of a family's income goes towards housing costs, the highest in history.”
It is not always wise—and this is the other point that members on the other side overlook—for a worker to challenge his or her dismissal. Irrespective of any financial settlement they may get, the word is passed around that they are a troublemaker and they sometimes find it difficult to get another job. Faced with these stark realities, few employees these days are prepared to challenge the authority of their employer.
