The federal government is, however, relentless in its pursuit of this political agenda. What the government is trying to introduce now is totally unnecessary other than for one particular reason—the political reason of having direct control over the wages and working conditions of the Australian work force.
The Labor Party is opposing this legislation for a number of reasons. Firstly, there has been a lack of consultation with the states. Secondly, we believe that insufficient attention has been given to costing and administrative arrangements. Thirdly, this bill reduces rights for workers with unfair dismissal cases by reducing the amount of compensation that can be awarded to an unfairly dismissed employee of a small business—that is, a business with fewer than 20 employees—down from 26 weeks pay to 13 weeks pay. Fourthly, this bill seeks to extend the qualifying period of employment before an unfair dismissal action can be brought by an employee of a small business—up from three months to six months. You might think that is reasonable. However, as Dr Richard Hall, a senior research fellow with the Australian Centre for Industrial Relations Research and Training at the University of Sydney, points out:
That argument would be valid if it were not for the widespread practice of using probationary employment terms. Probationary employment arrangements are designed precisely to ensure that employers can exercise the flexibility to quickly and easily dispense with a new employee should they regard them as unsuitable.
The bill also seeks to narrow the scope of an employee made redundant by his or her employer to mount an unfair dismissal claim and to reduce the amount of back pay available where reinstatement is ordered by requiring the AIRC to take into account income earned from other employment. There could be an argument that, where a dismissed employee immediately finds full-time employment, his or her claim for unfair dismissal compensation could be mitigated to some extent. However, there is a need to bear in mind that the employee then starts in a new position and loses many of the entitlements he or she may have had with the previous employer.
We see this bill as yet another attack on the working men and women of this country. It is yet another attempt by this government to take away the rights of workers instead of addressing the real problem facing Australian workers: the lack of full-time employment. I think we have all had a number of people coming into our electoral offices who are qualified and willing to work hard and yet who cannot find employment. It does not matter whether the unemployment rate is six per cent, seven per cent or three per cent; the fact is that there are many highly qualified people out there who are willing to work and cannot get employment. The government does not appear to want to address this. It seems to take the approach that if the theoretical unemployment rate is low, or reasonably low, then everything is okay. But I will read a letter from a constituent. This is the sort of thing I am confronted with, and I am sure others are too. The letter reads:
I am writing this letter to bring to your attention my disgust in hearing this week about the Telstra outsourcing scandal, in which Telstra admitted to granting IT projects to Indian workers. I am hoping that your input will put a stop to this behaviour by an Australian company, which have acted without any consideration to the effect on its own countrymen. 
As an unemployed IT professional, with a Bachelor of Technology Degree, and 3 years of industry experience, I cannot begin to tell you how disheartening it is when I hear that Australia's largest publicly listed company, Telstra has been allowed to overlook available talent within its own country, in favour of Indian software houses.
Not only do I view this situation as a blatant exploitation of a developing nation, on the part of the Australian Government, but I also believe that the Government is jeopardising the future of our nation. I am a 25 year old Australian citizen, and see myself (and my peers), as the future of this country. The Government's policy of outsourcing to these “sweatshops” in India sends a clear message to young professionals like myself: that the Government no longer values our contribution to the IT industry.
This is the issue that the government should be addressing: qualified people cannot find employment in Australia.
The government like to use the OECD reports when it suits them, including in the budget speech. In March this year, the OECD's economic survey of Australia stated:
OECD assessments consistently show that Australia's employment protection legislation is one of the least strict in the OECD area ... Australia's strictness of EPL ranks particularly low with regard to procedural requirements in the case of individual dismissal and on the criteria used in the compensation given for unfair dismissal.
So this legislation will further weaken our employment protection legislation and drop us further down the OECD list. It is an unworkable piece of legislation that will result only in complexities and incomprehension. It is a boon for lawyers, who will grow fat on the fees that they will be able to charge. There is no real reform agenda here. If the government were serious about reform in the unfair dismissal area, it would sit down with the stakeholders—employees, employers, unions, state governments and the opposition—and try to work through these issues. Instead, it simply tries to ram this legislation through, knowing full well that it will not pass and that, even if it did pass, it would not work anyway.
No amount of spin doctoring can save this legislation or the other bills in this area that have been introduced by this government. No matter how many times the government tries to tell us that black is white and night is day, it still will not improve this flawed bill. Labor believe in protecting workers from unscrupulous employers and so we will be voting against this bill, as we will vote against any bill that seeks to reduce the rights and freedoms of working men and women in this country.

name: Schultz, Alby, MP
text:
—I rise to speak on the Workplace Relations Amendment (Termination of Employment) Bill 2002. In 1996 this government was elected on, amongst other things, a platform of reform of the Australian business environment—reform, I might add, that was desperately overdue and reform that has been embraced by the business community. The results of the reform of Australia's taxation system speak for themselves. It is important to note that not one state premier has ever attempted to give back the GST revenue provided by the Commonwealth. Quite the contrary—the states have never been as happy as they are now.
Now the time has come for this government to implement something else that is long overdue: reform of Australia's current system of unfair dismissal legislation. This government has attempted to simplify and create certainty around Australia's unfair dismissal legislation through this parliament time and time again, and time and time again the Labor Party has opposed this legislation. You have to ask why. Why does the Labor Party constantly oppose legislation that, according to many commentators, would provide for a single, simplified workplace relations system? The answer is obvious. For too long the Labor Party has been running a campaign of obstructionism as a result of its own policy vacuum. The Labor Party is out of touch with what Australian business wants. This is not surprising when you look at the list of former union bosses on that side of the chamber. The unions are intent only on protecting their own future rather than cementing the future of everyday Australians. One only has to look at the decline in union membership that has occurred over the last two decades to see where that sort of mentality is placing the union movement in this country. 
According to the CPA small business survey, whose findings were released on 13 March last year, 62 per cent of Australian small businesses believe the current industrial system to be complex and 42 per cent of Australian small businesses might not know how to properly comply with the current requirements. Is it any wonder then that businesses are asking the government to implement its reform policies? These are policies that make good sense for business and good sense for Australia.
The Workplace Relations Amendment (Termination of Employment) Bill 2002 will amend the Workplace Relations Act 1996 to extend the operation of the federal unfair dismissal system to reduce the confusion that comes from the current system of different laws in each state. The passage of this legislation will ensure that 85 per cent of Australian workers are covered by the federal unfair dismissal laws. The bill proposes amendments that will impact on employers with fewer than 20 employees.
Compliance with the unfair dismissal laws presents major challenges to small business. Many business owners that I have spoken to in my electorate of Hume have indicated to me that they have to dedicate significant resources in their businesses to compliance with the unfair dismissal laws. These are resources that would be best used in allowing the business owners to do what they do best; they are resources that should ensure the profitability and longevity of small business. Large businesses often employ human resource practitioners to ensure compliance with unfair dismissal legislation. This is a luxury that small business cannot afford. Businesses that operate across a number of states and territories face even more challenges, as there is no continuity in current unfair dismissal legislation between the states and territories.
The measures contained in this bill will reduce the compliance burden on small businesses in terms of both time and money. The results of this will be a small business community that is not hamstrung, a small business community that is encouraged to prosper and a small business community that is encouraged to employ new workers. On that point, many small businesses have opted to employ family members rather than face the very real and costly imposition of unfair dismissal action by an employee. That obviously is another contributing factor to the level of unemployment in this country.
In my working life before I came into this place and this profession, I worked in both small business and large business. As small business owners, my wife and I were constantly concerned about the prospect of having to dismiss employees because the business may have been going badly and a reduction in costs may have been needed to ensure that it remained viable. We were also concerned about the possibility of dismissing a person for inappropriate behaviour or lack of commitment to a position that we, as small business people, were paying for out of our own pockets and on which we depended for the future profitability and viability of our business. 
That in itself should send a stark message to the Australian Labor Party and others in this place and in another place who simply seek to justify the reforms contained in this part of the workplace relations bill in the interests of allowing people to do what they do well. I am talking about people getting on with the job of running a successful small business, making a contribution to the economy of their town and district, and to the country as a whole. They should be able to do so in the knowledge that they do not have to spend enormous amounts of money on legal fees and on other aspects of defending their right as employers to run their businesses in a fair and justifiable way, not only looking after the future of loyal employees but also, more importantly, remaining viable and staying in business. 
When I was managing an export abattoir looking after 800 people I was placed in a very difficult situation from time to time. My supervisors and foremen had to undertake actions to dismiss employees for abuse of workplace arrangements and in many instances abuse of the awards they were employed under. It got to the farcical situation where if you wanted to talk to somebody about their attitude in the workplace, you had to take a diary and a witness with you and record every warning of the individual concerned in order to have some concrete evidence to take to the Industrial Relations Commission if that dismissal was challenged. 
Things have moved on from there. The Commonwealth and the states have now introduced unfair dismissal laws. Many dismissals have been unjustified and have occurred at the hands of the small minority of small businesses who abuse the system. I do not have any problems with that; nor do I make any criticism in that area. But the unfair dismissal laws have created an enormous amount of uncertainty for small business. More importantly, they have been a financial and time consuming imposition on small business owners which they cannot afford. In many instances, small business owners have had to defend dismissals that they should not have been forced into defending. 
I will relate to you, Mr Deputy Speaker Lindsay, an incident that I am well aware of. A person working for a small business in a small rural town was addicted to a particular type of illicit drug and was using the drug on the job. At times, because of the after-effects of using that drug, it was creating problems with the customers of the business. The employee was warned on a number of occasions. The owner of the business found a container of illicit drugs on the premises and, after doing an investigation and quizzing the employee, found that the drugs were the property of the employee. The employee was dismissed and, without prolonging the story too long, it went to unfair dismissal. The employee's unfair dismissal claim against the employer was successful. That was a justifiable case of fair dismissal which ended up costing the employer, who at the time was employing only two people because that was the extent of the business and its capability to employ. The employer then had to work extremely hard to make up the money that the action had cost him in legal bills. 
The measures contained in this bill will reduce the compliance burden on small businesses both in terms of time and money. The results of this will be a small business community not hamstrung, and encouraged to employ new workers. Put simply, this bill means that all employees covered by the expanded federal system will be prevented from bringing an unfair dismissal action under state unfair dismissal legislation. There will be some employees covered by the expanded federal system who can currently bring applications under state laws but who will not be able to bring an application under the federal system. The federal system clearly defines for businesses those employees who will be excluded, such as those who have not fulfilled the three-month qualifying period, apprentices, and non-award employees who earn over $81,500 per annum. These employees will be unable to bring an action for unfair dismissal in the federal system despite the fact that they may have been able to bring an action under state legislation. 
All states already exclude various categories of employees, therefore there will be a relatively small number of employees who will fall into this exclusion group. This will of course depend upon the current scope of exclusions in that state. Under the new clearer and expanded system, businesses can be certain as to which unfair dismissal laws apply to them and it will allow them to reduce the time, money and effort they put into human resource management practices and termination management.
This government made a specific election commitment to exempt businesses with fewer than 20 employees from unfair dismissal laws, to encourage small businesses to employ staff without the fear of a burdensome unfair dismissal claim. Current ABS statistics show that there are about 500,000 businesses which have fewer than 20 employees, but current federal laws cover only approximately 170,000 of these businesses. Quite obviously this means that the extension of unfair dismissal laws to cover an additional 230,000 small businesses will mean a boost to employment growth in the small business sector and, in turn, more jobs for Australians.
Under the new expanded federal system the definition of a small business employer has been made consistent with the definition of small business used by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, to assist in monitoring the impact of changes to the unfair dismissal laws on employment growth in the small business sector. This amendment creates a two-way street for claimants and small businesses involved in unfair dismissal claims by providing a simplified, fair and transparent environment for all involved. Small businesses can feel more at ease when dealing with unfair dismissal claims because the amendment will provide mechanisms which will not only cut down on groundless cases making it to court, at considerable cost to the taxpayer and small businesses, but also provide an element of accountability on the part of the claimants.
In dealing with applications that are beyond the commission's jurisdiction or applications that are without jurisdiction, frivolous, vexatious or lacking in substance, the commissioner will be able to dismiss the application without holding a hearing. Further to that, any decision to hold a hearing must also take into account the cost to the small business owner of attending the hearing. Keeping in mind that employees, like small businesses, must also be accountable for their own actions, this amendment requires that when the commissioner considers a claim for unfair dismissal any compensation will be reduced by an appropriate amount if that employee's conduct contributed to the dismissal, even though the conduct on its own was not sufficient to justify dismissal.
This is all comforting news for small businesses who, in most cases, find themselves crumbling under the pressures of unfair dismissal actions taken against them. It also causes people to give much more serious consideration as to why they are making an application for unfair dismissal in the first place—and the repercussions of that claim on themselves and the business they are claiming against. Let us keep in mind though that the bill includes an amendment—item 9 of schedule 3—to emphasise that the primary remedy for unfair dismissal is reinstatement. This amendment clarifies the existing position in the Workplace Relations Act that reinstatement is to be the primary remedy for unfair dismissal; that is, the commission is not to award compensation for unfair dismissal in lieu of reinstatement until the commission has considered whether reinstatement is appropriate. 
In addition to this amendment a further amendment has been proposed which will ensure that windfalls are not inadvertently received by employees who are reinstated. This change to the current system will mean that the commission will be required to take additional sources of income into account when making an order for back pay following the reinstatement of a dismissed employee. Income included is any earned during the period between dismissal and reinstatement and any income the employee is to earn in the period between the making of an order for reinstatement and the actual reinstatement.
To assist employers to avoid consuming unfair dismissal claims during periods of downturn in their business the government is proposing an amendment which will ensure that an employee who is made redundant will not be able to make a claim for unfair dismissal unless exceptional circumstances exist. In those cases the redundant employee will still be eligible to seek remedies for unfair dismissal. The amendments to this bill are about not just fair termination and the effects on small businesses but also keeping things fair on both sides of the fence. The measures will have the effect of reducing financial costs, increasing certainty of outcomes and resolving claims more quickly. They are critical in ensuring small businesses which employ fewer than 20 employees remain viable to the extent that they are able to continue to make a contribution to employment and operate on a much more realistic basis in a system which protects both employer and employee. I thank the House for the opportunity of making this contribution to the debate on this bill.

name: Burke, Anna, MP
text:
—Hearing the member for Hume reinforces for me why I joined the Labor Party and why, in the immortal words of the member for Werriwa, there is a them and an us—because nowhere in his speech did he refer to employees.
—You didn't listen too well.
—I listened very clearly. At the end you said there were protections in the bill for employers and employees but not once in your twenty minutes did you actually refer to those employees.
—Let us talk about the power relationship in the work force. Let us talk about who has the control and influence in the work force. Let us talk about who is the vulnerable. It is just an obscene abuse of this place, yet again, to grind down those in our society who are less fortunate and who have no power. It is members like the member for Hume who just reinforce that and make me so pleased to be a member of the Labor Party—and that we are in this place to protect people. I thought that was why some of us came into this place. It saddens me yet again to listen to a complete tirade and to be abused for having worked in the work force for a trade union—as if it is somehow demeaning to want to use your life for the good of others. I thought that was why the majority of people entered parliament. If you ask Liberals who have come into this place, they generally say that they are seeking to assist society and others. Somehow it was demeaning when I chose to do that for a trade union! 
But the interesting thing that the member for Hume failed to point out is that I not only worked for a trade union but also worked for the employers; I worked as an industrial relations advocate on both sides of the fence. In my time I have had to sack people. It is not a pleasant experience, but it has to be done on occasions—when it is justified. Nothing in this bill talks about justification; the bill just talks about taking away rights—the rights of the people who have already been abused. If there were measures in this legislation that would protect those on both sides of the fence, that would be fine. But again it is all one way.
I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak on the Workplace Relations Amendment (Termination of Employment) Bill 2002 because it is important to the operation of unfair dismissal laws for millions of Australian employees. I would happily be talking about job creation. But this bill does not talk about job creation; it talks about sacking people. I am not sure how sacking people creates jobs.
This bill seeks to broaden the Commonwealth's coverage of employees subject to the unfair dismissal provisions of the Workplace Relations Act to include all employees of companies and Commonwealth employees, leaving out only state government employees and those employed by nonincorporated businesses within a state jurisdiction. This attempt by the government is being put forward against the wishes of all state governments. So much for consultation and respecting the federal nature of Australia. So much for respecting states' rights. So much for the lauded views of various ministers of industrial relations from the Liberal side who say, `Really, government should get out of the way of businesses and let them get on.' This government has brought in more legislation and stepped into more Industrial Relations Commission exercises than any other government on record. It has been more proactive in sticking its nose into the business of employer-employee relationships than anybody. So much for saying, `Leave the playing field to businesses so that they can get on.' That again is not what this bill is about.
This legislation will reduce the rights of those who are swept into the Commonwealth jurisdiction. Indeed, it is my understanding that the New South Wales Liberal opposition spokesperson on industrial relations matters has expressed his support for New South Wales retaining its own industrial relations system. Those who become subject to the provisions of the Workplace Relations Amendment (Termination of Employment) Bill 2002, if it passes, will have reduced rights with the potential for further reduction if other unfair dismissal legislation is passed in this parliament.
Some groups of employees in the community will not be affected by the passage of this legislation; that is, those employees who are currently subject to the unfair dismissal jurisdiction of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, such as Commonwealth employees and those who work for corporations and are federal award employees and, most importantly for my state, Victorian employees. The reason for Victorian workers will not be affected is that former Premier Jeff Kennett decided in 1997 to disadvantage millions of ordinary Victorians employed by making them subject to the Commonwealth workplace relations law. I am pleased to say that the state government will be redressing that in the near future.
It needs to be remembered that the current fortunate circumstance of having Labor governments in all states was not always the case and that there were once Liberal governments in a number of states that did not act, as Jeff Kennett did, to divest themselves of their responsibilities in relation to industrial relations matters—and a good thing too. It is a good thing because workers in states that did not make this move are better off. But for many Australians working in states other than Victoria and the Northern Territory the passage of this bill will reduce potential remedies for being unfairly dismissed. Importantly, the provisions of this bill—along with the ironically titled `fair dismissals bill'—seek to reduce the rights of those who have already been treated unfairly. These provisions apply to people who have been dismissed in a harsh, unjust or unreasonable manner; these provisions apply to people who have done nothing wrong. For these people, who have already been treated unfairly or harshly, the current Liberal government wishes to provide reduced legal remedies. 
It astounds me when the government talks about the terrible nature of what a manager has to do. But that is what managers have to do—they have to manage, and they have to do so responsibly and reasonably. Employees have to be responsible and reasonable too. But people get sacked unfairly. On any day, just on a whim, a manager might decide, `Oh well, that person does not suit any more,' and then that person is out the door. That happens; it happens a lot. Such people need protection because, as I say, in the power vacuum, they are the ones without protection. We sit in this place listening to all the speeches from those opposite and notice that somehow they invest powers in an employee. The current legislation does not provide employees with a great deal of protection. The onus is on the person who has been sacked to demonstrate unfair dismissal; the onus is not on the employer. Please know the legislation that you are coming in here to discuss.
This bill has been investigated by the Senate on numerous occasions and, in particular, by the Employment, Workplace Relations and Education Legislation Committee. The report makes very interesting reading, and I note particularly the contribution of the Labor senators. But one sentence from the majority report, prepared by the Liberal senators, really jumped out at me. It states:
It is acknowledged that there is continuing controversy about the extent to which it may be justified, the claims of business to be seriously impeded in its recruitment of employees by the threat of unfair dismissal claims.
Too right there is controversy about such claims. I for one do not see the logic behind the argument that it is an impost on business, particularly small business, to have remedies for those who are dismissed unfairly—dismissed in a harsh or unjust manner—and that somehow, by having those remedies, it is an impost to employing people. That is just ludicrous. It has never been justified or demonstrated, regardless of how many ministers have tried to tweak numbers to do so. In the Financial Review, back on 16 April, an article by Charles Power stated:
The full Federal Court of Australia ruled in the Hamzy case (concerning casual exemption laws) in December 2001 that there was no evidence that the laws inhibited employment, remarking that, `Employers are used to bearing many obligations in relation to employees (wage and superannuation payments, leave entitlements, the provision of appropriate working places, safe systems of work, even payroll tax).
Yes, businesses can cope; people can walk and chew gum at the same time. I have been `Cohen Browned'; I can walk and talk and do all those things—and the majority of business owners can do them too. In saying that, we require remedies against unfair dismissal legislation. I recognise that the huge majority of businesses will not dismiss somebody in an unfair manner; they do not do so. Most businesses act responsibly. But on occasion there are rogues, and that is why we need protections. The majority of people do not go out and kill others, but we have protections in case it happens. But that does not reduce the need for appropriate remedies for those who happen to work for one of the small proportion of employers who operate in an unfair, unjust and harsh way. 
As I have said, I found the report produced by the Labor senators to be compelling. The second paragraph of the report reads:
It should be noted that the bill will not achieve the government's stated aims. There will be no increase in jobs, the bill will actually increase the industrial relations costs borne by business because many who choose to use the state system will now be forced to operate in two systems, a unitary system will not result, and workers will be discouraged from working for small businesses because it offers them less security and fewer rights.
Small business is one of our growth areas of employment. We do not want people to be put off working there because they may not have rights if they are dismissed. This is an assessment that I concur with. However, my concern relates to the impact that this bill will have if it is passed, rather than whether the government will achieve its aim. I am worried about the Australian workers who will have reduced legal protection against unfair dismissal.
This bill will cut in half the level of compensation available to an employee of a small business of fewer than 20 employees who is unfairly dismissed. This is a reduction to 13 weeks pay by way of compensation for being unfairly sacked. The ironic part of this is that it talks about the size of the business, not the capacity of the business to pay. If we talk about anything to do with industrial relations—organising pay rises and all the rest of it—it is about the capacity of the business to pay. This could be a very profitable small business that employs five people but has a turnover in the billions. It is an absolutely ludicrous assessment to say that a small business cannot afford to pay just because it has few employees. It might be the nature of the business that it does not need many employees. It just does not stack up in any logical manner.
The bill proposes to extend, from three to six months, the period for which an employee must be employed by a small business before they can seek any redress if unfairly dismissed. A number of people come into my office and say, `I took on this contract. I signed this thing, then I was gone in three months because there is this loophole there and because there is no protection.' That happens to a lot of employees. We have to remember that those people need greater protection—because they have probably finally got back into the work force, and people who keep getting these revolving jobs will never get into stable employment. Whilst I think unemployment is still unacceptably high, the greatest issue regarding the unemployment rate at the moment is the long-term unemployed, and this will not help those people.
The bill further disadvantages those who are found to have been unfairly dismissed by reducing the amount of back pay they are entitled to if an order for reinstatement is issued. The reduction comes from the bill forcing the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to take into account money earned through other employment during the term of the illegal dismissal. That is the thing I find most ludicrous and obscene. In my electorate of Chisholm, there were people locked out of their workplace by their employer for six months for no really good reason. They were in the middle of their enterprise bargaining negotiations. Those negotiations were falling apart a little, but it was nothing dramatic. One day, not too long before Christmas, the manager came along and locked out those workers. Not a brass razoo was offered to those employees. We never talk about those things. We never talk about lockouts by management. Those people were unemployed for six months, and they could not seek any redress through social security benefits from Centrelink. There is no provision for that because, technically, they were employed, even though they did not draw a cent of wages for six months. They were also sent a legal letter by the management of ACI saying that taking another job was a de facto resignation as it implied that they were not seeking to come back to their employer at Box Hill. It was obscene, unfounded and unjust. People lost their homes, and their marriages broke down. Imagine having no form of income for six months. We do not hear any mention of that on the other side of this chamber. 
In an article dealing with the issue of unfair dismissals, by Michael Bachelard in the budget supplement of the Australian yesterday, it was noted:
State unfair dismissal regimes under the current batch of Labor governments tend to be more generous to workers than the commonwealth regime both in the way they are formulated and the way they are administered.
So there can be no argument that, by imposing a scheme of industrial law that has reduced protections and has less generous terms of resolution than currently exist for millions of Australian employees, people will be better off. They will be worse off. They will have fewer protections. Many employees will have less or no access to remedies if they are sacked unfairly, and those who are able to apply to the Industrial Relations Commission will be treated less well than they would have been had this bill not been passed.
The movement of such a large number of cases to the federal jurisdiction will undoubtedly have a significant impact on the operation of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. This is simply unavoidable when considering that unfair dismissal claims made to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission are expected by the minister to rise by about 75 per cent if this bill is passed. Around 150 unfair dismissal claims are lodged with the Australian Industrial Relations Commission each week now, so the projected number of claims lodged is estimated to rise to about 260. This will necessitate significantly increasing resources to the commission. To cope with this increased load, $16.8 million has been placed in the budget over four years to employ an additional 12 commissioners. I will be fascinated to see who ends up being on the commission bench because, if the current rate of skewed appointments by this government is anything to go by, it is going to be a commission stacked with people with a one-sided view of the world. This is a significant resource going in to ensuring that workers who have been unfairly sacked are worse off than they otherwise would be under existing state unfair dismissal regimes.
There is clear logic for opposing this bill, as its impacts on millions of workers are solely intended to limit their rights. This bill is intended to limit the rights of workers. The most important thing for members to remember when considering this bill is that those it removes rights of redress from are people who have done nothing wrong—people who have already been treated unfairly, harshly and unjustly. It is somehow implying that these people are bad people because they got sacked and that it is bad that we cannot sack them more easily. You should be better managers. You should have better workplaces. You should ensure that the system is there for dealing with these things. As I say, the majority of businesses do not sack people harshly, unfairly and unjustly, but some do. That is why workers need continuing protection and continuing strong legislation at the state and federal level. This legislation is bad legislation and will not assist employees or employers.

name: Ticehurst, Kenneth, MP
text:
—I rise to support the Workplace Relations Amendment (Termination of Employment) Bill 2002. The coalition government has been working towards a simpler, fairer workplace relations system based on a more unified set of laws, and I commend the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations for introducing this legislation before the 40th Parliament. The Workplace Relations Amendment (Termination of Employment) Bill 2002 seeks to extend federal unfair dismissal coverage from about four million workers to seven million workers and to exclude the states from hearing most unfair dismissal cases. The government is consulting with the states on the expansion of the Commonwealth system, and the Industrial Relations Commission has allocated $17 million over four years to meet an increase in unfair dismissal claims under federal jurisdiction. The bill also introduces separate criteria and compensation for the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to apply when arbitrating a termination application from a small business employee, as well as extending the qualifying period of employment for small business employees.
As a small business man, I have a very good understanding of the impacts unfair dismissal laws have on small business and I would like to speak on the benefits this bill will bring not only to small businesses but also to the employees of small businesses. Statistics show that more than 70 per cent of all new jobs are created by small business. In my electorate of Dobell, job creation is a key strategic issue being addressed by all levels of government.
The legislation defines a small business employer as an employer of fewer than 20 people, including the employee who was terminated and any long-term casuals with 12 or more months of service, but not including short-term casuals. Unfair dismissal laws place a burden on the thousands of employers who can create new jobs. This is a proven fact. A less complex system would mean more jobs. As the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations mentioned in his second reading speech, having six industrial jurisdictions makes as much sense as having six railway gauges. Surveys have shown that many employees and employers do not know whether federal or state law applies to them. This confusion, caused by overlapping federal and state unfair dismissal laws, can result in workers failing to seek redress or lodge applications.
The national trend—and this is something that is of concern to me in my electorate of Dobell—is an alarming increase in the employment of casual workers as opposed to permanent employees. Casual workers have no job security and no access to paid leave or holiday leave; they are not guaranteed an income and they have little opportunity to borrow money for a house or even a car. After six months employers tend to put people on a call-up system, so they do not even know when they are working from one day to the next. These are the sorts of issues that face employers. The cost of unfair dismissal claims can be horrendous on a small business. 
Employment insecurity can be linked to social problems. Secure employment is a highly interrelated characteristic of the community. Job security, and therefore a dependable income, satisfies a person's basic needs and allows them to contribute better to their community. As a small business man I understand that without good staff a business does not run well at all. An employer relies on employees to produce income for his business. People—particularly members opposite—need to realise that an employee can only be paid out of profit. If a business is not profitable, the employer cannot pay staff. A business owner would not invoke legislation to remove a member of staff who is doing a good job; however, the same business owner may give careful consideration to employing people because of the ramifications of the current law. Some of these laws have been abused. People can disrupt a business and cause a great deal of unnecessary expense to a small business. A small business does not have sufficient funds to run legal battles, so they settle out of court. This can cost a business $10,000, $20,000 or $50,000. That is more than some companies make in profit in a year. This is the main impediment to employing: having to face legal action which can really bankrupt a business. 
The bill provides for a three-month qualifying employment period, unless at the relevant time the employer was a small business employer, in which case six months of qualifying employment is stipulated. A six-month qualifying period is a more appropriate balance between the interests of employers and those of employees. I believe this will assist in redressing the employment disincentive to small businesses. In addition, it is proposed that the Industrial Relations Commission be allowed to dismiss an application for an unfair dismissal remedy on the grounds that the commission believes the application is beyond its jurisdiction or that it believes the application is frivolous, vexatious or lacking in substance. The commission would not be required to hold a hearing when making an order.
The legislation also proposes to limit the maximum compensation awarded to a small business employee to three months salary or, in the case of non-award employees, to half the current compensation limit—meaning a limit of $20,400. These provisions create a more cost-effective, streamlined process. Not surprisingly, the Labor Party continue to argue that the government is trying to take away the rights of workers—just as they opposed the Howard government's legislation to prevent union bosses charging small businesses compulsory union fees. The fact is that this legislation provides a balanced system for both employers and employees and a process that would lessen complexity, lower costs and provide more certainty for both employers and employees. With this legislation the government seeks to redress a burdensome and complex law that is destructive for employment growth.
We just heard the member for Chisholm say that she did not see the argument being put forward in this new legislation. Then she gave us an example of a six-month lockout by a company in her area. No doubt that would be a large business. What she was trying to do was justify a strike. If people are being locked out of a business, it is not because they want to work and it is not because they want to generate funds for the employer so that the employer can pay them. As Barry Cohen, a former minister in the Whitlam government stated in one of our Central Coast newspapers recently, the problem with federal Labor and their ability to make legislation relates to the fact that there are no businesspeople there. They come from law backgrounds and union organisations—they come from staff positions. There is no small business person on Labor's side in this House. This is why they have difficulty understanding why employers have difficulty with the unfair dismissal laws as they currently stand.
We should not let politics get in the way of legislation that is in the best interests of Australian workers and that will promote job creation. Many employers, employees and business groups, including the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry—the peak council of the Australian business associations—have expressed support for this new bill. Sustainable employment does not result from any quick fix measures. I am proud to be a member of a coalition government that is committed to continuing the workplace reform process. I commend this bill to the House.

name: Organ, Michael, MP
text:
—I welcome the opportunity to speak on the Workplace Relations Amendment (Termination of Employment) Bill 2002. This bill deals with the important issue of protecting workers from unfair dismissal and the deprivation of livelihood. Unfortunately, I cannot support this bill. The minister has noted in his second reading speech that having six separate industrial jurisdictions in Australia makes no sense and is confusing. On that basis it is only reasonable to simplify the current system by expanding the Commonwealth's legislative territory, particularly in regard to unfair dismissal laws. We have heard how this is proposed to be achieved—by allowing Australian businesses and government employees to be covered under the one federal industrial relations law when former employees lodge unfair dismissal claims. This bill also introduces separate qualifying period criteria and a compensation scale for the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to apply when arbitrating a termination application from a small business employee. Furthermore, at its best, this bill offers advantages for non-award employees, as they would at least be covered by this unfair dismissal legislation.
Initially, these arguments seem reasonable. Generally, we would all favour simplicity and reduced confusion. Certainty is also a vital element. Likewise, everyone favours assisting Australian business so that jobs can be created. That seems clear enough. However, when these worthwhile ideals are applied to the industrial relations arena by this government, things go very pear shaped indeed. This is because since day one this government, through the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and his infamous predecessor, have pursued an ideological crusade against trade unions and the rights of ordinary working people—working people who, at the end of the day, are only seeking to maintain and advance their working conditions, to improve their quality of life. These are hard won rights which have been defended and consolidated by workers and trade unions over a long period of time. In fact, they can be traced back to legislative protection for the eight-hour day introduced in 1856. The fight has continued since then to cover a raft of improvements to workers' salaries and conditions, such as sick leave, workers compensation, holiday pay, penalty rates, overtime payments and unfair dismissal protection. These are the very same conditions of employment that the government seeks to erode in order to satisfy its ideological addiction. 
It is clear that the minister's dogmatic approach has clouded the government's judgment and distorted concepts of equity, fairness and freedom of association as they are applied in the Australian workplace and as they apply to unfair dismissal. It is not a coincidence then that the minister's second reading speech fails to mention any benefits that this bill will provide for employees—for workers—but he does tout the benefits corporations and employers are set to reap from this bill if enacted in its present form. It is telling that the minister has seen fit to boast that this bill `halves the amount of compensation that can be awarded to an employee'. Is this something to gloat about? Is this something to be proud of? I do not think so. 
This is not the simpler, fairer system the minister has promised Australian workers and employers. Instead it is a meaner, tighter, more restrictive system. The minister's second reading speech further states that federal unfair dismissal laws are `generally less burdensome to employers' than equivalent state laws. There you have it; this is what this bill is all about. In other words, present state laws are fairer towards employees than the regime proposed in this bill. We must remember that these state laws have, over time, been enacted to protect workers—to protect employees. Why have such laws been deemed necessary? Because history has shown that employees do need protection from that small group of unscrupulous employers who have abused notions of fairness, decency and trust in their dealings with Australian workers. Workers have been unfairly dismissed. That is a fact. They do need protection from these abuses. As a result, over time state legislation has been enacted to provide equity and justice within the workplace to assist workers in dealing with unfair dismissal. Whereas in the past workers held concerns that their state protective measures would be repealed or watered down, now the federal government is entering the fray and seeking to undermine the state laws. 
Workers have reason to be concerned about this government, for this is where the main anti-union, anti-workers' rights attacks are coming from. It is quite clear that this bill will reduce an area of workers' rights and entitlements—hard won rights and entitlements, which the minister views as a burden on employers and corporations. A vote for this bill is a vote for a global reduction in the ability of workers to access effective unfair dismissal remedies and receive just compensation for unfair dismissal. It is not just the application of this bill in the federal arena that is alarming; it is also that this bill threatens many employees who are currently protected by state laws—by better and more just state laws. The minister himself calculates that three million extra employees will be brought under the federal government's unfair dismissal regime if this bill is passed—three million workers who will be worse off under this bill. In total it will cover approximately 6.8 million, or 85 per cent, of Australian workers. 
This bill is not focused on simplicity, as the minister would have us believe; instead, it is focused on reducing workers' rights and on reducing their level of protection against unfair dismissal. It is patently objectionable because it feigns clean and concise simplicity but will deliver neither fairness nor equity to Australian workplaces. The only thing that is clear is that the government is constrained by its own logic and is unable to deliver legislation that is fair to both employers and employees. In fact, the government seems to be confused about where it wants Australia to go in relation to unfair dismissal laws. 
On the one hand, this bill proposes an expansion of Commonwealth power to cover small businesses that would otherwise be covered by state unfair dismissal legislation. On the other hand, through the ludicrously titled Workplace Relations Amendment (Fair Dismissal) Bill 2002, small business employees are prohibited from lodging valid unfair dismissal claims. Just which way is this government taking Australia's industrial relations system? Here it is clear that the government and the minister are torn between reducing the rights of employees in one instance and abolishing the rights of employees altogether in another. Either way, the direction the government is going with this bill is clear: we are seeing a reduction in workers' rights, a reduction in hard won workplace conditions, and the removal of equality, regardless of the size of the business you work in or who you work for. 
The Australian Greens believe in a more progressive way. Conditions of employment, including sick leave, holiday pay, penalty rates and protection against arbitrary and unfair dismissal are non-negotiable and must be nurtured and improved—not neglected. The Greens believe that these conditions of employment are a clear-cut example of what sets this country apart from the Third World. These conditions must be retained and enhanced for the benefit of all workers and all employers. Most importantly, the Greens believe that workers' rights and entitlements do not have a major impact on employment growth, especially when they are applied uniformly across the nation. Reducing workers' entitlements does not create jobs. 
I suggest that the government look to other areas in seeking to lower the unemployment rate. Some of the money that goes into directors' bonuses could easily create scores of jobs, and business should take a lead in this regard. More seeding grants from this government could give small business a leg-up into export markets. Increased spending on education has the potential to massively increase our intellectual capital and create jobs. But, no, this government's logic is flawed and its priorities are skewed. We now know that the federal government has the money to pay for these positive ideas, yet it stubbornly refuses to do so. Instead, this government is rusted on to its budget of neglect and is proposing to spend an additional $16.8 million over four years to enable the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to implement this new federal unfair dismissal scheme. 
The government states that it has the best interests of working people at heart, yet such a statement does not hold up to much scrutiny, and this bill is evidence of it. History shows that employees need protection from unscrupulous employers who abuse the notion of fairness. Employees are, in many instances, vulnerable and powerless. Protection from arbitrary and unfair dismissal is a key part of protecting workers' rights, and I condemn the distorted concepts of equity, fairness and freedom the government is trying to apply to the Australian workplace through this bill—for this is a bill which, as we continue to see from this government, yet again seeks to reduce the rights of working people. For this reason, this bill must be condemned.

name: McArthur, Stewart, MP
text:
—I am delighted to participate in the debate on the Workplace Relations Amendment (Termination of Employment) Bill 2002 because of my longstanding interest in industrial relations matters. This is a manifestation of the long arguments between those supporters of a centralised wage-fixing system and those who support freedom of association where employees and employers can set their own conditions and, more importantly, where employers can employ who they wish and not employ those they do not want. This struggle flows from Federation in the Harvester case of 1904 and the High Court's decisions to ratify arbitration and conciliation and centralised wage fixing.
During my time in the parliament there have been some gradual changes. Even those on your side of the parliament, Mr Deputy Speaker Wilkie, have managed to move towards a less centralised system—the Hancock report in 1985 indicated support for enterprise negotiations. The manifestation in the final outcome that the public at large understood on industrial relations was the waterfront reform. Minister Reith, having introduced industrial relations reform in 1996, was able to use the changes in the legislation to bring about major changes on the waterfront. Those changes encouraged the use of individual contracts and meant that there was a dramatic change in productivity on the waterfront through increasing the reliability of people in the stevedoring industry to turn the ships around. Productivity improved markedly by more than 25 containers per hour. Those possibilities were attacked by those on the other side of the parliament. They said it would never happen and that we were taking away workers' rights.  
On our side, we say it is a fundamental right of small businesses to employ staff and, more importantly, if they are unhappy with those staff, to dismiss those staff in a genuine and thoughtful way. This very important legislation is an answer to this dismissal problem. Those opposite say that, once somebody is employed, they have the right to retain that employment no matter what. This emanates from Keating's attempt at an unfair dismissal regime. The matter has been debated extensively here in the parliament, and even some of those opposite—the member for Brisbane and others who have a bit of an understanding of this argument—would agree that the Keating government's proposal on unfair dismissal was a proposition that was thought up quickly based on ILO propositions and, in general terms, has never really worked. We are suggesting, yet again, that the unfair dismissal proposal, especially for small business, should be incorporated in the legislation and should have a national perspective. We have a situation where each state has its own jurisdiction on unfair dismissals. This legislation, which hopefully will be passed by the Senate, will bring in a national system using the Commonwealth's corporation powers under the Constitution.
We now have this proposition before the parliament, and I noted in this morning's press: `Abbott faces challenge on sacking laws'. The New South Wales Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Della Bosca, says that he would strongly oppose the bill because it would `cause greater confusion for employees and employers'. This proposal is being debated in the parliament, and the New South Wales Labor government is attacking it before it has even got off the ground. George Williams, a professor of law at the University of New South Wales, in the AustralianFinancial of 17 February, had this to say:
Using the Commonwealth's corporations power in addition to its other powers, the Bill would increase the coverage of the federal regime from 3.9 to 6.8 million employees ...
This legislation would increase the federal coverage to 85 per cent of Australian employees—up from 49 per cent. At the moment, about half of Australian employees are covered by the federal jurisdiction. The states have different sets of laws for unfair dismissal. The few workers who would not be covered would be state public servants and workers in partnerships and non-corporations. In his second reading speech, the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations stated that the bill: 
·	extends the standard qualifying period for employees' access to unfair dismissal provisions from three to six months;
The minister is saying—and I agree entirely—that after six months an employer can evaluate the performance of his or her employee and say, `Look, we've come to the end of the road and I think we should part company.' The bill also:
·	allows the commission to deal with some claims `on the papers'—that is, without a hearing;
The commission or the court can look at the unfair dismissal claim without going into all the rigmarole and court action and make a judgment. It also:
·	halves the amount of compensation that can be awarded to an employee;
My information in the electorate of Corangamite is that an unfair dismissal case costs the employer between $5,000 and $7,000. No matter what is done, no matter what good grounds the employer has, that is what it will cost in payments and for the court hearing. The bill also: 
·	streamlines the criteria for determining whether a dismissal was unfair; and 
·	refines the penalty provisions for lawyers and agents who encourage unmeritorious claims.
All of us on this side and those on the other side—even the member for Blaxland—have had experience of employees who have made vexatious claims. They think that they can see the pot of gold—the $5,000 or $7,000—and have proceeded with a claim because they know they are almost sure to get the money. I have given the background to the bill and the reasons for putting the bill up. This matter has been under discussion since 1999, which is when the former minister, the Hon. Peter Reith, announced his intention for a national scheme.
This government is continuing to reform industrial relations and initiated the dramatic change in 1996. I have been active in preparing the groundwork with others since 1985. Peter Reith did encourage some reaction from the other side, even from the member for Blaxland and others. He did a fantastic job in reforming the waterfront and bringing about a legislative change to Australian industrial relations.
As the member for Blaxland would know, his good friend Chris Corrigan, the managing director of Patrick Corporation, talked about productivity increases and increase in earnings by his employees. In the Institute of Public Affairs Review, he stated:
... many of those workers who so vehemently opposed the reform agenda are now earning as much or more than they were five years ago. Through a bonus system, linked directly to productivity, our best employees earn in excess of $100,000 per year. Most average around $75,000 a year.
With those dramatic reforms on the waterfront we can see that the workers are better off. They are earning more predictable money on the job and do not have to work overtime, and they are more productive, more reliable and have greater security of tenure. Both parties are better off. So much for the fear tactics of those opposite who said that the world would come to an end at the waterfront if the Reith reforms went through and changes were brought about in that hotbed of industrial relations activity. The government, the opposition and the Democrats should continue to bring about reform in the industrial relations area.
I will bring to the House's attention some activities of the royal commission which actually happened in my electorate. Those opposite say that the workers are always on the right side in everything they do. Certainly, the royal commission did not portray this evidence. There were problems on all sides, with employers, employees and unions. I agree with that. Royal Commissioner Terrence Cole found that:
... (CFMEU) shop steward Gary Carter threatened to take industrial action against employers to coerce them to refuse employment to persons who were not CFMEU members.
You had a situation where this particular union organiser wanted to make sure that this was a CFMEU site. The evidence goes on:
The 6 foot 6 inches tall, 22 stone Carter admitted in evidence that his job was to ensure that no non-unionised labour was to work on building sites. Evidence in the Commission on the 21 of February 2002 included the following description by the CFMEU's Carter of events conducted at the Lorne sewerage works—
in the heartland of Corangamite, as the member for Blaxland would be interested to know—
`Then you pointed to the sewerage pit and you said, and I quote, “That pit is only half full.” Did you use those words?' 
`Yes.'
`By that, you conveyed that there was something worse for him in store if he didn't comply with what you wanted?'
`Well, he was sort of bragging a lot, you know like, “I'm not scared of you or the union,” ...
`You put him in his place?'
`I'd had enough of him, so I told him there was plenty of room in the pit for him, if that's where he wanted to go ...'
`By the end of the first week of your period at Lorne, there was a hundred per cent union membership on site?'
`There was a hundred per cent union membership on all sites I went to after the first week.'
Commissioner Cole has found that Mr Carter and Brendan O'Connor, another CFMEU official, had engaged in unlawful conduct, forcing employers to refuse employment of non-union labour.
There we have it: a classic `no ticket, no start' situation in the heartland of Corangamite, indicating that unions are concerned over this unfair dismissal law because they want to retain control of everything—they want to retain control of the membership of these work sites. We on this side wish to open up the industrial relations situation to encourage employees and employers to work more cooperatively together. So, in this small area of unfair dismissal, there has been a move by the government to ensure that we get the Commonwealth to have one set of regulations.
Look at the situation with the dismissal of injured workers: the states have different approaches. In Victoria, South Australia, Western Australia and Tasmania, tribunals do not have automatic jurisdiction to order reinstatement or compensation. New South Wales has another set of arrangements, where its tribunals specifically have legislative authority to deal with such matters. So there is a hodgepodge of arrangements all around Australia in relation to unfair dismissal. I quote from Robert Guthrie's article in the December 2002 issue of the Journal of Industrial Relations:
Return to work provisions have been developed on an ad hoc basis and it is time for a unified approach.
The article went on to say:
... myriad of approaches to rights of dismissed workers in various States ... general need ... greater uniformity between States ... should be Federally sourced ...
What reasonable, sensible person—even among members opposite—could argue against a set of arrangements, run by the Commonwealth and supported by the Corporations Law, which all employees and employers around Australia could fully understand? Of course, the member for Blaxland is a friend of Della Bosca, and they are not going to allow that to take place. They are locked in the past—they are locked into state run organisations when it suits them—and they do not want to bring about a change. You would be surprised to know that even Mr Bill Shorten of the Australian Workers Union had this to say:
It is ridiculous there are more than 130 pieces of State and federal legislation pertaining to industrial law ... we believe the ALP with its coast to coast governments is in a unique position to improve legislative uniformity ...
That was quoted in the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry publication, Modern workplace: modern future—a blueprint for the Australian workplace relations system 2002-2010. It is a very good document, and I will refer to it again in a minute. There was Mr Bill Shorten, a doyen of the labour movement, agreeing with the government.
I think it is important that we try to get unfair dismissal under federal jurisdiction, because it will lead to less confusion. It is interesting to know that many employers do not know whether they are under state or federal jurisdiction. If you are out there in small business you are not sure about a lot of these fine-print industrial laws. You are out there trying to make a dollar and employ people. It was interesting to see that, in a Yellow Pages survey, one-third of small business employers said that they did not know whether they were under the federal or the state unfair dismissal system. Most of them are pretty genuine. They have small businesses of 10, 15 or 20 people; they know those people by their first name; they work with them day and night, year by year; and they are often long-term employees. They would like to know exactly what regime they are working under. It is interesting that the OECD survey recommended a change as well. In their economic survey of 2001 they had this to say: 
The overall success of industrial relations reform ... depends on the harmonisation of Federal and State legislative.
—You get rid of the states. Della Bosca in New South Wales has a few problems with his own government: who is going to be the minister, who is going to be in the cabinet and who is going to run the state under that long history of Labor governance? So they are not going to make a change. The member for Blaxland would be very supportive of that because he is a well-known New South Wales member.
Finally, I turn to the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry's publication, which I mentioned earlier: Modern workplace: modern future—a blueprint for the Australian workplace relations system 2002-2010. It is a very high-quality document. I want to quote a couple of their proposals for the longer run. They have an interesting proposition: A snapshot of Australia's industrial system 2010. That is not so far away. They have a few ideas as to where the system should be and where the Senate might help with more thoughtful legislative programming so that, by 2010, we would have a number of good outcomes. They have listed 30, but I will refer to just a few:
1. Australian businesses and employees would continue to aspire to, and achieve, higher standards of living.
Nobody could argue with that.
2. Unemployment would be lower, and remain structurally lower even during periods of economic downturn.
Again, both sides of the parliament would agree with that aspiration.
3. Jobs would be more readily available for new entrants or employees returning into the labour market. There would be significantly fewer impediments to hiring new staff.
We on this side of the parliament would say that the impediment to the hiring of new staff is the fear of an unfair dismissal claim. Employers are very reluctant to put somebody on if they know that, if the particular set of arrangements with that individual does not work out, it is going to cost them $5,000 to $7,000 to terminate the arrangement.
4. Policies which reduce the cost of employment would be given the highest priority by governments.
We would all agree with those aspirations. In the last bit of their snapshot of 2010 they have this to say:
28. There would be a rationalisation and harmonisation of federal and state industrial relations arrangements on acceptable terms that eliminates or at least minimises regulatory content and duplication.
There you have it: they are saying that that could happen by 2010. The ideal position would be that other states do as the Kennett government did in Victoria and allow the federal system to control state industrial arrangements and that Australians should work under one national system. I think that all sensible people opposite would have to agree with that. They have been great centralists in their time. I am sure that the member for Blaxland is a great centralist. He would like to have everything run from Canberra. Why doesn't he agree with a set of arrangements that will mean that every Australian, be they in Queensland or Western Australia, will know their rights and responsibilities under a set of employment contracts? We have a situation where various states—be they Western Australia, New South Wales or Victoria—continue to argue the case that they are now under Labor governments. At No. 29 the ACCI report says: 
29. Rights against capricious termination of employment would be maintained but in a system with lower cost and speedier resolution of disputed terminations. Employers would have more confidence to engage and dismiss on performance and suitability grounds. Both employers and employees would be more familiar with their rights and responsibilities.
I think that encapsulates the thrust of this legislation and the philosophical view of the minister, myself, government members who support this bill and those who have spoken previously. We are suggesting that the unfair dismissal laws be harmonised throughout Australia and that there be changes to encourage employers to put on more people. People need to be confident that if a set of arrangements do not work out—and it happens in the best of families—and employees and employers do not get on for one reason or another they can part company without undue cost and undue inconvenience.
I do accept the view that there are some employers who do not do the right thing—and that could be handled in the normal course of events in an unfair dismissal. The government and the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations accept that there could be a genuine payment for unfair dismissal in circumstances where an employer did the wrong thing. We do not have an argument with that, but we are concerned about this pot of gold mentality—that is, that if you terminate your job you are sure to get $5,000 to $7,000.
I commend the legislation and I commend this attempt by the minister. I hope that the Democrats, particularly Senator Murray, will support the legislation. It is sensible and fair legislation and brings in a new era of commonality to unfair dismissal legislation. (Time expired)

name: Hatton, Michael, MP
text:
—I am utterly delighted to follow the member for Corangamite in this debate on the Workplace Relations Amendment (Termination of Employment) Bill 2002, but he has stolen some of my lines. Of course, they have been inverted and overstated, but he has stolen some of my central themes. His contribution was a complete revelation to me. I will admit to the fact that I am from the New South Wales Labor Party. I will also admit to the fact that I am from the centre unity faction, which is in fact the right wing of the New South Wales Labor Party. Unlike many, I have been in that faction since I joined the party at 15 years old. I have not varied on my road forward. I have not switched in terms of that, and I think I have been on the right and correct road. 
I will also admit to the charge launched at me by the member for Corangamite—that is, that I am a centralist. Yes, I am a centralist; I always have been. I believe that, constitutionally, we have a significant problem that, having got a federation, we have to deal with the problems in that federation. Historically, the Australian Labor Party has tended towards a centralist approach to things. It is also called a Commonwealth approach to things; that is, the Commonwealth government, the Australian government—yes, a central government but a government for the whole of the continent. 
When the Commonwealth government got a guernsey in 1901, it had power over only three things: customs and excise, post and telegraphs, and defence. Historically, those who went on to make up the Liberal Party in 1906 or 1907—the fusionists; that grab-bag from the Victorian protectionists and the New South Wales free traders who saw their future in, quite rightly, being the anti-labour parties—were about states rights, and states rights above Commonwealth rights. So the Commonwealth's job was to get a mob of colonies together that became states and to then say to them, `There is an overarching set of priorities for this country. There are things that need to be done that can't efficiently be done at state level because there is too much bickering, too much lack of conjunction between the states and there are too many different standards.' 
The central motif of the relevant minister, the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, Mr Abbott, in relation to this bill was to use the metaphor of railway gauges. He argued that this bill will in fact bring six disparate sets of railway gauges together. On his use of that metaphor, I remind him that it was a Labor federal Prime Minister—the former member for Blaxland Paul Keating—who actually put the work in place to integrate our rail system Australia wide.
So I admit to being a centralist in terms of being an Australian federalist who believes that there is a strong role to play for a strong, active and significant federal government and that things cannot be done by simply leaving it to the individual states. I will not resile from that, and I am quite proud of it. But I am shocked to find that the member for Corangamite is an authoritarian centralist. With the operation of the new guard under Campbell in the thirties, the move towards authoritarianism and fascism became a problem in New South Wales and in other states. So I am shocked to find that the member for Corangamite, who I thought was fundamentally a liberal and open character—particularly during social activities when he is extremely liberal and open—could embed within his breast the canker of authoritarian centralism.
I thought he was a fundamental states righter. I thought he was within the camp of the member for Bennelong. I thought that he elevated states rights to the situation we had under Malcolm Fraser's new federalism, which was all about reinforcing the states—although there were a few in the Liberal Party, particularly the member for Bennelong, who thought that Malcolm was a secret centralist and was not really about keeping the states on their elevated road to governing this country.
This is particularly important given that authoritarian centralism, in terms of being a collector, was apparent when the federal government was being forced to take over those excises which the states had—and there was a case involving tobacco excise which the member for Corangamite would remember. Since the uniform income tax act came in in 1942, which was more than 50 years ago, the federal government has—and the Treasurer seems to have a bit of problem understanding this given his answer two days ago with regard to these questions—collected all income tax in Australia. The states no longer exercise that power. Several Prime Ministers have actually threatened the states that, if they are really going to create a problem, they could go back and start utilising the constitutional power that is theirs, but they have not done that.
The great collector is the GST. The federal government collect the goods and services tax. It is a federal government tax collected by the Commonwealth and disbursed to the states in exactly the same way that, since 1942, income tax has been collected by the Commonwealth and disbursed to the states. The Treasurer will not admit that. He says, `This is a set of state taxes.' That might line up with the theory the government like, but this mob of unreconstructed states righters only have a particular line to run. They will look to say, `Oh well, maybe the Commonwealth should have some power here.' And where will they find it? In unionism; in the dreaded idea of people associating together—poor, common, ordinary workers who choose to join together in a union in order to protect themselves from the overweening power, or the potential overweening power, of an employer.  
We know, by the way, that states righters are also association righters, and so it is okay for the Australian Medical Association to get together and act as a union, because they are a professional association. They have a number of members, no doubt, from the Liberal Party and the National Party and so on. But they are a different kettle of fish, because they are supposedly professionals. They are not those people down on the shop floor who actually gather together in unions. They probably almost did not survive that.
—The member for Parramatta has just indicated that he was a member of the BLF. He may still be in the BLF, or he may have only been a member for a short time while going to university. Who knows? The sense of shock I have at the revelation that there is an authoritarian centralist in the federal seat of Corangamite is softened—and so his attack on states rights is softened—by the fact that this is an entirely ideological bill that takes an ideological approach against ordinary Australian workers. 
The one thing I will concede to the member for Corangamite is that vexatious cases are brought against employers. When people see a bucket of money at the end, whether that bucket of money has $7,000, $10,000 or $20,000 in it, they can run vexatious cases. People running small businesses, including my mates who run small businesses, commonly complain that they have had problems in that area and that their safety and certainty have been compromised.
