That is a problem for them because they have to go through costly court processes, and so they would like to see that resolved. But they also note that the situation is not the same now as it was when the legislation was first introduced in 1994, because the initial legislation relating to dismissals was changed. The legislation relevant to this debate has been unchanged, by and large, except for some changes that the former member for Flinders, Mr Reith, got through. Essentially, this government is now complaining about its bills, as amended. It wants to go the rest of the way. 
This government is hands off and does not believe in central Commonwealth activity—or, in fact, in almost any activity whatsoever. When this government came to power, it had a bit of an audit. We all know that wonderful, thick, yellow covered book, the National Commission of Audit report. The government asked the auditors to have a look at all of the processes of the Commonwealth government and come back with recommendations on the appropriate role of the Commonwealth in relation to services provided by the Commonwealth. Given that it wrote the script, it is not surprising that the government accepted the recommendations. And the key recommendation, as I have voiced in other speeches, was simply this: the Commonwealth government of Australia—and, for the benefit of the member for Corangamite, that is the centralist government of Australia, or the government which has that tendency; the Australian government; the overarching government—should not provide one single direct service to an individual in Australia. It should not provide anything. Anything to be provided should be provided by the states that constitutionally provide health, education, policing services and so on. Anything that the Commonwealth had which might mirror any of that in any way should be pushed over to the states.  
That recommendation was made in 1996, at the end of the 20th century and coming up to the changeover to the 21st century in 2001. And that is the one thing the member for Bennelong has got correct since he came here in 1974—he identified correctly when the millennium clicked over. The Commonwealth government sought to hammer down ordinary people and to change things in such a way that it would not have to be actively involved in solving problems with the environment, such as the problem of the Murray-Darling Basin. We have, of course, not seen any active involvement in that issue. We know the genesis of that, and the problems that have had to be sorted out by the states. The Commonwealth has done a little bit, but you will not find much from this government in the current budget to deal with water and salinity. 
This government talks big and delivers little. It thinks that the job of the federal government in the 21st century is simply to audit and set benchmarks: go in and have a look at what the states are doing and say, `This is what you've been doing. We've already set up benchmarks for what you should be doing. We'll give you a tick or a cross, and we'll make that report to the Australian people. Then we've done our job.' That is a lazy way of going about things. It is supposedly a states rights way of going about things, but it is a lazy, inconsequential and minimalist approach to the problems this country has.
Let us go to authoritarian centralism, as displayed in the comments by the member for Corangamite. I was shocked to see that he was intimately involved in the preparation of the basis for these materials. He has admitted in the House today that in 1995, in conspiracy or in conjunction with the then member for Flinders—
—Way back in 1985? It does go right back. The Bills Digest covers all of your activities then, nefarious as they were. You were involved right from the start in trying to do in ordinary workers. Although the government talks up the states, it really has something against them. The member for Corangamite is quite right in one sense—he made the allegation and I will admit to it: I am a friend of John Della Bosca. In fact, John Della Bosca and I are in probably the largest unofficial faction in the Labor Party: the De La Salle Brothers faction. Not only did we both go to De La Salle schools but John was in fifth class when I was in fifth form at the same school. Michael Lee, Steve Hutchins and John Della Bosca used to play handball down the bottom of the yard while Michael Forshaw and I were up the other end with the fifth form boys. So he is a friend of mine and I have known him for a fair while.
John Della Bosca has done a great job as a state minister and he also did a great job as the General Secretary of the Australian Labor Party. In conjunction with Peter Sams, who was Secretary of the Labor Council of New South Wales and also secretary of the Greenacre branch of the Australian Labor Party for many years, he fought like crazy at state level when Liberal governments came in—and particularly when this crowd came in and tried to rip apart the capacities of Australian workers—to protect New South Wales workers from the depredations of the Commonwealth government in the industrial relations area. They knew at their very core—and the workers of New South Wales had some intimation of it—and even fought against federal Labor governments on the issue that, if all industrial relations power were centralised in Canberra on the basis of a uniform system, you could be at the mercy of a Commonwealth government run by states righters who are actually authoritarian centralists when it comes to trade union matters. Those people could then seek to enforce that under the aegis of a bill like this, or the original of this—the workplace relations bill before it was split into the 12 disciples that have run back and forward through this parliament, building up towards a double dissolution. 
John Della Bosca and Peter Sams knew intimately that, even with a Labor government in Canberra, you could not always trust the Commonwealth when it came to making sure that states rights were looked after. They had a deep appreciation, I am sure, that if you shake hands with a federal conservative government, a Liberal government, on industrial relations matters in the federal area—especially in regard to the Workplace Relations Amendment (Termination of Employment) Bill 2002, which talks about unfair dismissal laws dealing with anyone in a corporation and not, as the act currently says, `and is also covered by a federal award'—when you take your hand away you had better make sure you count your fingers, because you could be a few short. The reason for that is very simple. The determined authoritarian centralism at the basis of this bill is an attack on Australian workers and unionists simply because they are unionist.
The fascists had it quite right. If you created a state in which ordinary people could not act collectively because they could not bind together in a union and which was dependent upon the Duce, the leader, and the corporations that ran the country—and that is the nature of authoritarian fascism—then the vast bulk of the people could be disassociated from each other because their common bindings, whether through the Catholic Church in Italy or through unions, could be broken and sundered. The atomised nature of modern society would ensure that a fascist ruler, together with fascist corporations, could rule what they called `the united state'. That is a fundamental of authoritarian fascism.
We have a very similar approach here with the authoritarian centralism of this government in this area. They do not believe in belting the corporations on the back of the hand much; they do not believe in constricting them much. We have seen case after case of supposedly self-managed, self-assessing, self-regulating corporations either immolating themselves on the stock market, as AMP recently has, or simply falling to pieces, as HIH did before its march to the Industrial Relations Commission. We have seen that ordinary people who had investments in or insurance with companies like HIH have had their life savings whittled away. The capacity to get better conditions and earn larger amounts of money will never be assured by a uniform federal industrial system run by a group which does not believe that people have any right to join together in unions but wants them apart and controlled.
I am even further shocked by the admission from the member for Corangamite that all of this stuff kicked off way back in 1985. I am shocked that it could be so deeply embedded in an otherwise reasonably liberal and open person—well, that may be an overstatement; I do not know. But I can say that the fundamental right of Australian people to get together to protect themselves by forming an association, a union, and fighting for their rights and for better industrial conditions is a core part of the working movement that I have been a part of all my life—the industrial wing of the working movement of which we are the political wing. 
We will fight in this place, as we have fought at state level, to try to protect the rights of workers and get a better deal and a better life for them. We utterly and completely reject the kind of authoritarian centralism that is evident in this bill. It is a reasonable assertion—even from someone who is a centralist in the sense of supporting a strong, powerful, flexible and engaged Commonwealth federal government—that there are times when our federalism needs to be protected from the depredations of a conservative government such as this and the attempted ripping and paring away of what minimal rights are left to ordinary working people.

name: Johnson, Michael, MP
text:
—I am delighted to follow many of my coalition colleagues in speaking on the Workplace Relations Amendment (Termination of Employment) Bill 2002. Like all of them, I understand the critical importance of this bill in improving the lot of small business men and women of Australia. It was also interesting to sit here and listen to the member for Blaxland speaking on this bill. He is certainly one member of the opposition who has some very good ideas. Regrettably, on this bill and this subject his ideas are much diminished; but it was interesting to hear his commentary on Labor politics, Labor factions and his friendships and associations with those in his party.
More importantly, I want to talk about this bill because this bill is important to our country and to those in our country who are in a position to employ our fellow Australians. This bill is all about making it easier for small businesses the length and breadth of this great country to operate successfully and to contribute to the national economy. This bill is vital because it is all about making it easier for employers to hire more Australians. It is about jobs, jobs and more jobs. 
The bill seeks to amend the Workplace Relations Act 1996 to extend the operation of the federal unfair dismissal system by making greater use of the corporations power. It seeks to improve the operation of the federal unfair dismissal laws as they impact on small businesses. It seeks to make a number of other significant operational improvements to the way the unfair dismissal laws operate. In his second reading speech, the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, the Hon. Tony Abbott, outlined the purpose of the bill. The purpose is to extend federal unfair dismissal coverage from about four million to seven million Australian workers, thereby excluding the state jurisdictions from hearing most unfair dismissal cases, and to provide a single dismissal jurisdiction for companies and small businesses. 
The bill also introduces separate criteria and compensation for the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to apply when arbitrating a termination application from a small business employee as well as extending the qualifying period of employment for small business employees. This is going to be extended to six months before an application for a remedy can be made. The bill attempts to prevent an unfair dismissal application arising where the termination was made due to operational reasons. An example might be in circumstances of redundancy. The bill also attempts to limit compensation payable by all businesses by having the commissioner consider any contributory conduct of the employee, whether the employee may have benefited from a redundancy payment and what earnings an employee may have earned in any other form of employment. The bill intends to broaden the jurisdiction of the Workplace Relations Act termination of employment provisions to provide a sole avenue of redress for unfair dismissal applications for employees of companies and businesses. 
Under the dual nature of federal and state industrial legislation, state award employees have sought redress for dismissals perceived to be unfair via their state laws. However, this bill proposes for federal unfair dismissal provisions to cover the field, as it were, and will reverse current Workplace Relations Act provisions which have so far protected the role of state termination jurisdictions. While the Workplace Relations Act has attempted to preserve a role for the state industrial systems, these provisions will be amended to facilitate the very intent and purpose of this legislation.  
One of the consequences of the current legislative regime is that identical cases are handled differently merely because they fall into different jurisdictions, resulting at the end of the day in what can be classified as inequitable treatment for both the employees and the employers concerned: for instance, rules governing eligibility based on casual employment status, probationary status, out of time limits or on the level of the applicant's wage hearing from jurisdiction to jurisdiction. In addition, the factors that tribunals must consider and the relative importance they are required to give to them in determining the fairness of a dismissal where the relief is warranted and the form and level of such relief vary depending upon the legislative framework and related case law that may be applied. Other factors such as application fees and penalties also differ and, quite frankly, there is no reason for this. 
Employers and employees are also confronted by the complexity of overlapping jurisdictions, and this certainly creates confusion. The May 2002 Senate report on the provisions of bills to amend the Workplace Relations Act 1996 found that many employers were unsure as to whether federal or state dismissal laws covered their circumstances. From speaking to the many small business owners and operators in my electorate of Ryan, I can certainly confirm the views of that 2002 Senate report. I can certainly confirm in the House that inconsistent positions only add to confusion and result in greater expense. Members of the Ryan Small Business and Employment Advisory Committee that I established last year to give me advice, input and feedback on the experiences and concerns of small businesses have also stressed this point very strongly. They do not like the current regime. They want it changed. It impinges on their capacity to hire more people. This committee that I have set up exists for the purpose of giving me an opportunity to report to the parliament and to those in a position to make a difference on how to improve the position of businesses across the country. I am delighted to know that the advice I have been given by the members of the Ryan Small Business and Employment Advisory Committee sits very squarely alongside the intent and the purpose of this legislation. 
Many employers will also not know the actual jurisdictions in which they are eligible to lodge a claim. Such complexity weakens efforts by government agencies and employer organisations to educate and inform businesses about how to handle and prevent unfair dismissal claims. Some employees—perhaps the most vulnerable—confused by the complexity, may also fail to seek redress or to lodge an application in time, with the result that injustices that the law has been established to prevent will go ahead unremedied. This uneven coverage is not desirable, and this parliament wants to do something about it. 
The amendments contained in this bill would expand the federal jurisdiction dealing with harsh, unjust or unreasonable dismissals so that it covers all employees of constitutional corporations in addition to employees currently covered under other constitutional heads of power. My colleagues on this side of the parliament alluded to that earlier. Presently the corporations power is not used to its full extent. The federal unfair dismissal legislation only applies to employees of constitutional corporations who are covered by afederal award or agreement. To ensure the effective operation of the new arrangements, the amendments would prevent employees within the scope of the federal unfair dismissal jurisdiction from accessing remedies under comparable state unfair dismissal schemes. However, the interaction of federal unfair dismissal laws with other Commonwealth, state or territory laws would largely remain unaffected. An example of this might be the anti-discrimination laws in the various state jurisdictions.  
It is estimated that the number of employees covered by the expanded system will increase from approximately 3.9 million to around 6.8 million. So it is a pretty significant piece of legislation that this government seeks to pass. More Time for Business, the 1997 government response to the 1996 Small Business Deregulation Task Force, identified business and community concerns that termination of employment provisions were an employment disincentive for small business. The government's report found that these provisions have a disproportionate and detrimental impact on small business in terms of human resource administration procedures, representation at commission hearings and lost business and commercial opportunities while defending claims. This is something that has come through very strongly in the meetings that I have had with members of the Ryan Small Business Advisory Committee.
This might be an appropriate time for me to inform the House of one significant commercial entity in the electorate of Ryan. The managing director of that business has taken the initiative and time to write to me, only a couple of days ago, on this very point. He sent me a fax, in which he gave me some information about his business and commented upon the themes and topics that this bill addresses. I would like to put this company, Pillow Talk, on the record. It is a family business which employs approximately 220 people. The company has warehouses in the suburbs of Darra and Sumner Park in my electorate. The managing director makes the very important point that employers, at the end of the day, do not sack good people; indeed, they are looking for good people. This bill will go a very long way to encouraging that.
If the regime is not changed, all we will have in this country is a legislative framework that is conducive to mediocrity. This government is not about that. I know that my colleagues on this side of the House are very much about improving the status of those who are in a position to employ people. I would like to put on the record a paragraph of the fax from Mr Heath Goddard, who is the managing director of Pillow Talk. I will not read all of his fax but, in a very important paragraph that I want to put on the record for this House to consider, he says:
In our discussions with many business colleagues we have found unfair dismissals to be a most vexatious issue. And while it seems to be of no interest to most of the country's senators, we would urge you to continue to pursue the matter.
I am delighted that he alluded to `most of the country's senators'. Of course he knows that the senators of the coalition very keenly support this bill. He goes on to say:
It often galls when an employee decides, on a given day, simply to leave with all the training and experience we have provided at substantial cost, just walking out the door. But if the reverse is the case, if someone is not pulling their weight, we are obliged to enter a legal minefield full of technical and procedural traps if we wish to seek a termination. There is simply no balance.
This is coming from someone in our community who has a business which employs 220 fellow Australians. He is giving sustenance to their families and to our community and he needs all the help he can get. This government can be in a position to help small and medium sized businesses employ more of our fellow Australians. I would like to think that everybody in this House, and in this parliament, would be very supportive of that position. So I call on the opposition to support this bill, support the amendments, and ensure that we help fellow Australians who are seeking jobs and give them the best opportunity possible. 
I mentioned earlier the Ryan Small Business and Employment Advisory Committee which I have formed. I want to go on a bit about that because their points are very consistent with the intent of this bill. The House will be interested to know that, in the April meeting of the Ryan Small Business and Employment Advisory Committee, it was strongly indicated to me that small business employers would be more likely to employ new staff, and more likely to employ staff on a permanent basis, if they were not concerned—or unduly worried—about the prospect of unfair dismissal claims. This is a theme coming from the community, the electorate and those who are at the coalface of business in this country.
Let us do something about it. I call on the opposition to support this bill. Let us give fellow Australians who are seeking jobs the opportunity to walk into jobs. Jobs are there for fellow Australians. Employers want to take on more Australians and all they need is the support of this parliament and the support of the opposition. So, if you listen, you will realise that this is what the small business community in this country is saying. I commend the bill to the House and I call on the opposition to do the right thing for all the country's job seekers and pass this bill.

name: Dutton, Peter, MP
text:
—I am going to speak this afternoon in great support of the Workplace Relations Amendment (Termination of Employment) Bill 2002. As my friend the member for Ryan noted quite rightly, it provides a firm basis from which small businesses—and business in general across the country—can move forward when they consider employing new employees. Indeed, that is very much what most of this government's agenda has been about: providing a secure future for all Australians and providing a future with a sound and solid economy and a very secure base on which small business can operate. As we all know, on Tuesday night the Treasurer handed down the budget—the sixth successive surplus budget of this government—and it underpinned our intention, desire and drive to provide for a secure economy. The bill that is before the House today is all about that as well.
As you would note from Mr Abbott's second reading speech, the bill has three objectives. The first is to improve federal unfair dismissal laws for small business, the second is to improve federal unfair dismissal law generally and the third and most important is to widen very significantly the federal law's coverage. My friend the member for Ryan also made a very good point in relation to the intention and the motivation of small business in this debate. He pointed out that the representative from Pillow Talk said to him that nobody in small business or in business in general has any intention or desire to sack a good, hardworking, well-intentioned employee. People in small business know that it is very difficult to find good and valued employees. The economy is in a position at the moment which is supporting small business and business in general. We have kept interest rates down and we have provided a platform for small business and business right across the country to prosper as best they can. It is a very good point that needs to be made. It is an important point when you start to look at the motivations of the respective parties in this debate. If what we are about in this bill is increasing the ability of small business to employ extra employees and to further prosper the Australian economy and make a happier environment for their employees and their families, then we need to look at the motivations. 
If we look at the motivations of the Australian Labor Party in this debate, it is very interesting. Their links to the union movement are well known. If we look at the example of Centenary House, for argument's sake—a corrupt deal that was struck between the then Labor government and other parties—we see that it was a disgraceful situation and it highlighted in the most serious way the ties that the Australian Labor Party have with the more militant aspects of the trade union movement in this country. When we look at the motivation of the Labor Party in relation to this bill, those ties and the influences from the militant dictators of some of the union movement become very apparent. It is worth noting in this debate that that is the case. Why on earth would a serious political party in this country—the Labor Party, in this instance—oppose such commonsense legislation? If you move around your electorate and have any contact with business on a day-to-day basis, as many of us do, you would understand that it is a great desire—probably the principal aim—of many people in small businesses to fix up the unfair dismissal laws, to try and create some sort of system of uniformity, a unitary system across the country, instead of the separate situation and laws that operate in each of the separate states at the moment. It would provide, in their own words, a vibrant situation where they would be willing and able to put on more employees.
When we came to government, the unemployment rate was somewhat higher than the 6.1 per cent it is at the moment. This government are very proud of the fact that we have created over 1.1 million jobs in the time in which we have been in government. We have seen real wages grow by almost 11 per cent over the last seven years. If you contrast this performance to that of the Labor Party, who claim that their lot in this place is to drive the way of the battler and of workers, it is a stark contrast. Under 13 years of Labor, there was a paltry 2.3 per cent growth in real wages. Compare that 2.3 per cent to 10.6 per cent. There was an unemployment rate when Labor were in power of 8.6 per cent. It is now 6.1 per cent. There was a climate under the Labor Party where small business was smothering. They were smothered by interest rates that were over 20 per cent for some people in small business, and it was an environment and a climate in which they could not reasonably operate.
This government have been about providing a climate which is conducive to growth and which really does create the prospect of further employment. It remains one of the key aims of this government to see that unemployment rate lower even further. That could be done if the Labor Party in the Senate supported this bill, because the Australian Democrats have indicated support. I understand that Senator Murray—during a committee process—and other senators from the Australian Democrats have indicated that they believe that a sound system of workplace relations in Australia would be a unitary system which provided uniformity across the country.
We call today very seriously upon the Australian Labor Party, on behalf of all businesspeople in Australia and prospective employees of their businesses, to support this bill in the Senate. With the support of the Democrats and hopefully of the Labor Party, this bill will see the light of day; it will not be knocked back again. Putting the politics of the issue aside, we seriously call upon the Labor Party to reconsider their position in relation to this bill, because they are hurting those that they claim to represent. Those that they claim are the closest to their hearts are the ones that they are hurting the most by their position in relation to this bill. It is an untenable position because they are depriving many thousands of young Australians of jobs. Small business make that very clear. I sent recently to my electorate a small business report. It was sent out to all the small businesses in Dickson. I was trying to gauge feedback on what the most important issues were to those small businesses. The messages from the people who have sent back their responses, and also from my small business doorknocking through the electorate, are very clear. 
Small businesses are very happy that we have now been able to pay off $63 billion of the $96 billion of Labor debt. We have also contributed very positively by reducing interest rates. They say that has not only been of benefit to them in their home mortgages—saving them in the vicinity of $10,000 a year on a mortgage of $100,000—but also saved them a considerable amount on their business overdrafts. It provides a situation where they are not paying 20 per cent, as they were under Labor; people are now paying half, or less than that, on their business overdraft. This puts them into a cash flow position where they can go forward, expand their business and provide more jobs to young Australians.
Small businesses say that the second most important issue to them is that we do something about unfair dismissal laws. That is the very bill that we are talking about today, and the one that we have been frustrated on, time after time during the term of this government, by the Australian Labor Party. Small business people say to me, `Why hasn't your government done something about the unfair dismissal laws?' The answer is very simple, as we have outlined already: the Labor Party, in an obstructionist and politically opportunistic way, have blocked us at every turn in the Senate. They continue to do that. They must heed the call of these small business people who want to continue to expand their businesses, want to employ more Australians and want their businesses to prosper further. If the Australian Labor Party listen to those calls instead of being dictated to by the union movement, they will do the right thing and pass this legislation.
In my view, the Australian people are very sick of political opportunism. They are sick of the cheap political opportunism we see on a day-to-day basis from the Leader of the Opposition and those who sit opposite. The Australian people know that those who sit opposite us in this chamber are tied by chain and shackle to the labour union movement, because they are the ones who have driven them up through the political process. We know that those people who sit opposite, without exception, have no small business experience. We have heard the Minister for Small Business and Tourism talk about the former senator who was the only Labor senator with small business experience. He was the only link between the Australian Labor Party and small business, because he actually had a small business background.
—Former Senator Cooney.
—That is right, it was Senator Cooney. What a great man. It seems that any understanding of small business that the Labor Party had, however minuscule it was, has now all but vanished. The Australian Labor Party need to get out from under the union movement, they need to stop listening to and heeding the demands of the union bosses and they need to listen to the message that is very clear from small business right across Australia, including in my electorate of Dickson. I think people are very aware of that political opportunism. They are aware of the comments that have been made by the Leader of the Opposition in relation to this debate and in other debates. They understand that the comments of, and the stance taken by, the Labor Party have nothing to do with good policy and with providing for a safer and more secure future for the small and family businesses in this country. 
The Prime Minister has quite rightly said on many occasions that small business is the engine room of the Australian economy. Those of us who come from small business backgrounds understand very clearly how important small business is to the future prosperity of Australia. When you look at what the Australian Labor Party have to offer small business and what the coalition government have offered small business over the last six years, it stands in stark contrast. If you look at my home state of Queensland, you will see the taxes and slugs that have been put onto the Queensland people by the Beattie administration and you will understand what desperately poor economic managers the Labor Party are. Time after time—in Victoria, in South Australia and in New South Wales; indeed, right across the country—we have seen the maladministration of many state Labor governments. If the Labor Party were to return to federal government then pity help not just young families but also small business right across the country, because the Labor Party have no understanding, concept or grasp of where small business is coming from.
As I have said before, how could they be expected to? When you glance across at those opposite, read their CVs and understand where they have come from, you realise that they have a plethora of union hacks that have come up through the movement with very little, if any, real-life experience. They do not have the experience that people on this side have in small business and they do not understand how difficult it is to make a small business prosper. Supporting this bill is one way that the Australian Labor Party could demonstrate to the Australian people that they are starting to hear the message. They can no longer reasonably expect to have any credibility if they do not start to listen to the messages of those that count.
I spoke before of the situation in Queensland and the way in which the Beattie Labor government are slugging small business in that state. We have heard recently from many business leaders and small businesses across Queensland in relation to the ambulance tax. That has been a disgraceful squandering of public moneys. Originally it started as a tax which would be collected from small businesses through rates. The Beattie government was howled down, and Peter Beattie bowed to that pressure. He has now decided that the annual $88 ambulance tax will not be charged to those people who use the service but will be imposed upon people right across Queensland who have an electricity account. So we see yet another demonstration of Labor having no understanding of the demands on small business. Under the proposal as it was first put by the Labor government, small businesses who may have two or three separate electricity accounts are going to pay that tax two or three times. That is a disgraceful and shameful position to put small business in. Once again the Labor government, driven by union ideology, expect small business to pick up the shortfall.
On the front page of the Courier-Mail today there was the headline `State raids assets for cash'. This article talks about extraordinary dividends being paid by the two electricity companies in Queensland. These are special one-off dividends paid to the Beattie Labor government because they are broke. We hear Peter Beattie talking about jobs, jobs, jobs but he has not provided any. What he is about is providing jobs for the boys and jobs for his friends; he is not about providing jobs or providing a situation where small businesses in Queensland can prosper. 
The situation for small business in Queensland, in relation to both the bill that is before the House now and the taxes and imposts that are being put upon small business, cannot continue. We are going to go down the same track as Victoria, to a state of absolute annihilation of the economy. Queensland has always had a prosperous economy and all Queenslanders have been very proud of that fact. But we now have a government that is running blind. We have a government in Queensland that really has no idea what it is doing in relation to the management of the Queensland economy. It is a point that needs to be made and it should rightly be put as part of this debate, because the debate is about trying to give small business an avenue for prosperity and future growth. If you are slugging businesses in Queensland with all of these taxes and imposts, small businesses will be too scared to put on new employees and you will then have a situation where small business grinds to a halt.
If the Labor Party had any idea of what small business was about and was trying to provide for the future prosperity of Queenslanders—indeed, of all Australians—it would support this legislation and retract from its time-honoured tradition of slugging those with whom it has the least ties; that is, small business and the business community. Premier Beattie needs to get the message that he must stop listening to people like Bill Ludwig and the heavyweights of the union movement and start governing for all of Queensland. He has not done that. If we look at some of the tax imposts that are going up in Queensland at the moment, we see things like new taxes on poker machines that are going into the sports stadium—
 (Ms Corcoran)—Order! I would invite you to get back to the bill.
—It is all tied in with a lack of drive and support from the state government for small business. If we are talking about job creation in the state of Queensland and in this country, Premier Peter Beattie should stop talking about and looking for ways to raise taxes and slug small business; he should be calling on the federal Labor Party to support this legislation. If he were not obsessed with trying to balance the budget, the money from which has been spent on everything but economic development in Queensland, we would have a situation where small business could be supported and could drive the economy, as it has traditionally done.
It is a very sad time for all Queenslanders. I think that Queenslanders are now starting to become aware of just how desperate Beattie and Terry Mackenroth are to balance the books in Queensland. Queensland families, those in small business and, indeed, all Queenslanders face extra fees for motor vehicle registration—all sorts of imposts are being imposed upon us. We need to be about job creation. We need to support this bill, which will provide for a fairer climate in which small business can go forward, earn money, engage additional people and support the small business communities which support them. I say to the House today and to the Labor Party that they must support this bill. (Time expired)

name: Cobb, John, MP
text:
—I have always been and always will be a very big advocate of small business. That is because most businesses in my electorate employ fewer than 20 people. Small businesses in Parkes are the bread and butter of the communities they exist in. We must make it as easy as possible for small businesses and potential small businesses to establish themselves and operate. We must identify and remove the threats and possible hurdles that inhibit business growth and development. This morning I attended a seminar with Australians and people from the EU on regional development and small business. The common thread was that we have to identify the impediments to the successful development of small business in country communities in particular, deal with those impediments as a government and make it easy for the small operator to start a business or to operate one. 
A thriving small business sector means a thriving community. Small business, certainly in my electorate and in country regions like ours, is the template by which the moral, economic and social fabric is judged. If small business is doing well, you can rest assured that the community is also. It is a principal belief of the coalition government that small business must be helped, because it does provide that template by which the whole community operates.
Here we are again arguing with the opposition in order to pass sensible, streamlined measures to help small businesses. In its simplest form, the Workplace Relations Amendment (Termination of Employment) Bill 2002 will extend federal unfair dismissal coverage from about four million to seven million Australian workers. It will then exclude the state jurisdictions from hearing most unfair dismissal cases and provide a single dismissal jurisdiction for companies. I think anyone would have to say that is not only that good for business but also straight-out commonsense. It will improve the operation of the federal unfair dismissal laws as they impact on small business and will improve the way those laws operate.
I would like to address the individual amendments under those broad aims that will specifically benefit the small business sector. Firstly, by extending the operation of the Commonwealth unfair dismissal system, a single system will operate for the vast majority of employers and employees. Currently, there is a great deal—an enormous amount—of confusion amongst employers about overlapping laws that differ from state to state. This is an attempt to remove the element of confusion and create a single simplified system. ACCI Chief Executive, Peter Hendy, said:
Any benefits we have derived from a federal and state-based system are long gone and we think they should be amalgamated into one system.
Expanding the Commonwealth unfair dismissal system is a step in the right direction. It is a step towards simplifying our current system and minimising the confusion of employers over who they have to refer to and the different laws that exist. The majority of businesses and their employees will be incorporated into one single system. No longer will businesses be confused about which set of laws apply to them. We will be able to instil business confidence by creating one system that is easy to understand and easy to operate. Businesses will be able to cut the total time spent on termination management. You have to have been a small business person to realise the complexity and the absolute terror for an employer in a small business situation when faced with the red tape of having to deal with unfair dismissal claims. Obviously the opposition do not realise this or they do not care about the people employed by these employers. These changes will let businesses know where they stand.
There are also new businesses. If there is complexity in dealing with unfair dismissals for those already in the employment industry, if there is complexity for those who already have a small business—especially one that employs fewer than 20 people—stop and think for a minute how incredibly complex it must be for someone who is thinking about starting one. When you start a new business you are never too sure about exactly what you want and what you are going to get. What kind of deterrent is it for somebody who has by nature got the get-up-and-go and the guts to save enough money to start up a business if they know that, within six months, they could be brought to their knees by unfair dismissal claims brought by people they employed—people they did not know too much about when they started off? That is the biggest bar to starting off a business that exists in Australia today. 
We want to extend to six months the qualifying period after which a terminated small business employee can seek relief. This is a way of cutting down on the number of unnecessary and unjust dismissal claims. There are people who actively try to exploit the system; without doubt they get treated well, by and large, by the courts. A six-month qualifying period gives businesses, especially somebody who may be thinking about starting a new business, some degree of confidence about the people they choose to employ. Stating that people must be employed for a six-month period in order to qualify for unfair dismissal relief makes it harder for them to exploit the system. We are promoting business confidence by proposing to allow the commission to deal with some claims on paper or without a hearing. Think about the expense and time that an employer who is starting a new business, or who has an existing one, has to go through to deal with this.
Many unfair dismissal claims are groundless, but they still have a devastating effect on small business. It is not just the cost; it is the time involved and the sleeplessness that anybody who has ever had to deal with this will understand. Under these proposed changes, if an application is without jurisdiction or is frivolous, vexatious or lacking in substance, the commission will be able to dismiss such an application without holding a hearing. This is not complex. This is the sort of commonsense that should always apply when such regulations are made.
Through this bill we are seeking to halve the amount of compensation that can be awarded to an employee within a small business. In the case of non-award employees, compensation would be limited to $20,400. We are advocating streamlining the criteria for determining whether a dismissal by a small business is unfair. Finally, we are refining the penalty provisions for lawyers and agents who encourage unmeritorious claims against small businesses.
All of these amendments are part of a greater campaign to work with small business to reduce impediments to their growth and development and to encourage them to get going in the first place. These measures will reduce financial costs to small business; increase certainty of outcomes by limiting the amount of compensation an employee can access; and allow claims to be resolved quickly and with a minimum of fuss.
Australian Bureau of Statistics figures indicate that there are some 500,000 small businesses in Australia that employ fewer than 20 people. There could be more than 500,000 were it not for this huge black cloud that hangs over the heads of everybody who looks into the complexities of business and realises what they would be taking on under the current employment provisions. There could be a lot more than 500,000 small businesses if we bring forward this very simple, very commonsense change to the act.
The amendments spelt out in this bill mean that we can protect more of those businesses and that we can encourage far more of them to start. If there is one thing I believe, it is that Australians who have the guts to have a go on their own and start a business—mostly young couples who have got the acumen, the work ethic and the courage to save the money—should have it made easier to do so, not harder by threatening to send them broke because they simply would not be able to deal with vexatious claims by employees, let alone their overall viability for the future. 
As I have mentioned, my electorate of Parkes is driven by small business, particularly when you take farming into consideration. Unnecessary claims are a burden they simply cannot endure. In the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry's `Blueprint for the Australian workplace relations system', their `Vision 2002-2010' is:
A workplace relations system that empowers employers and employees across the nation to work co-operatively and make decisions in their shared interests that lead to more jobs, higher living standards and a better future.
That is what we are trying to achieve as a coalition government. We have a duty to protect the small business operator. By doing that we will protect the jobs of thousands of people around Australia; by doing that Australia will become a much stronger place.
In most cases, small businesses do not have staff dedicated to dealing with human resource issues, particularly dismissal. The owner is the jack-of-all-trades who deals with just about everything, including employee relations. He simply does not have the resources to employ a litany of lawyers and legal firms. Small businesses simply do not have the time or the means to represent themselves, and yet they are forced to do so or they are forced to take on costs that simply are untenable for them. They are forced to seek professional advice, adding to costs and placing a huge burden on them. Small business must be made an exception. The rules that govern big business—who, if they do not have their own permanent employees, employ big companies to represent them—cannot transfer down to the little guy. As a government, we have to take into account the limitations placed on small business and the long-term effects of unfair dismissal proceedings. The opposition not wanting to pass this bill is not about protecting the jobs of workers; in fact it is the reverse. Surely the more solid small businesses are and the better job they can do, the more jobs will be out there in the first place.
There are always going to be exceptions to the rule, and in the case of unfair dismissal laws small businesses are certainly that exception. They deserve to be and they need to be for the sake of everybody, especially country people. This bill spells out the exemptions the government seeks to make. This has never been about limiting the right of the individual; it is simply about protecting one of the largest and most important sectors of our community. Without small business, there would simply be no employment in country towns and gradually they would wither away. I remember years ago my mother telling me that Napoleon once called the British a nation of shopkeepers. I choose to interpret that to mean that they were a nation of self-employed, of small businesses. Britain, a nation of self-employed people—or small businesses that employ fewer than 20 people—was the strongest country in the world at that time, and it defeated the largest army in the world. If we want to be the strongest nation that we can be then the more small businesses, the better we are and the better the people who work for small business are. So let us give it a go for a change and try and pass a bill that is in everybody's interests.

name: Lindsay, Peter, MP
text:
—The substance of the Workplace Relations Amendment (Termination of Employment) Bill 2002 has been before the parliament on a number of occasions. Earlier in the debate I listened to the contribution from the member for Chisholm. She was passionate in her views and articulated them well. The member for Chisholm, though, misunderstands the position of the government. She said that she was not hearing in government members' contributions—for example, that of the member for Hume—any reference to the rights and the interests of employees, that it was all related to big business and to employers. I can understand that she might have thought that, but she has misunderstood the government's position very badly. I will explain that in a moment. 
I am very disappointed that the Labor Party have been unable to recognise and give the government some credit for the work that has been done in industrial relations in this country since the Howard government came to office. It has been a landmark change. Some would argue—and, I think, correctly argue—that the changes that we have made in industrial relations have been more significant than those made in the taxation system for the benefit of the nation. There have been some landmark changes, but there need to be more. The country can do better; it is only when the country does better that everybody does better. I might just pause for a moment and welcome students from St Aidans school in New South Wales. 
It is in the interests of workers in this country to have a strong nation, to have a strong business sector and to have an economy that is very vibrant. It is only through the partnership of the government, through employers and employees together, that the nation can be as strong as it possibly can be. What the Labor Party seem to not recognise with this bill is that it is an impediment to employers to face these very difficult problems related to dismissing employees, so they do not employ people if they can avoid it.
I have managed and owned a small business for 25 years. I know exactly how small business people think in this regard. I ask the Labor Party to understand that most businesses are not politically motivated. For most businesses, their biggest single asset is their people, their staff. The last thing that you do is sack a person, because they are your best asset. But if there is a need to dispense with the services of an employee, there needs to be a system that does not come back and bite you as an employer. So we need to solve these problems that are there, that are very real. The member for Parkes correctly said that with the passage of this legislation there would be more people employed in the economy and and that we would have a much more vibrant economy. I have seen many instances in my time, and have had many worries myself, in relation to the very difficult decision to terminate somebody. The member for Chisholm recognised that; she has worked on both sides of the fence. To her credit, she told the parliament that that was the case.
This bill is much more about what is good for the country than what is good for the trade unions, the boss or the government. It is high time that this parliament spent some time thinking about our country. It is high time that the other place across the Members Hall had some regard for what is good for the country. It is high time that the negative `we'll vote everything down because it's politically good' attitude ceased. In the case of this bill, that has been the track record of the opposition, who are going to vote it down.
I recognise that some members of the opposition believe in the arguments that they put forward. I listened to the member for Greenway, who has had a decent view on these things. But it is time to move out of the past and time to move forward because, if this bill were passed, it would be a historic first step towards a single and more responsive industrial relations system. That is terrific. That is why I am taking the time this afternoon to support it. These are landmark changes that are being proposed, but they are landmark changes that can only do good for the country, for employers and for employees. These days our economy does not consist of discrete and insular sectors; we operate in a global economy. 
That really comes home to me in relation to my son. He feels that the world has no borders. As a dad who is used to traditional things, I have realised that the world has moved on and you have to think in terms of today's thinking rather than yesterday's. My son's girlfriend is in Brazil, of all places, and he is in New South Wales. But that is the way of the world these days—the world is an open, almost borderless place. The way we do business and run our economy has to be responsive to what is happening in the world. More than that, businesses that operate across jurisdictions have to be competitive. For example, businesses in New South Wales have to be competitive with businesses in Queensland. The current notion of our industrial relations system, operating with a federal system and the state systems, is something that we really need to think deeply about.
This bill addresses that. This bill proposes a system to do away with state jurisdictions in this particular matter. All of us have had the problem of dealing with one state jurisdiction having one set of laws, the state across the border having different laws and then the federal government having different laws again. If you stood back from all this and looked at the landscape, you would really have to say, `What a silly system. What an inefficient system. Why don't we have just a single set of laws in industrial relations in this country?' There are all sorts of reasons as to why this is so, and there are all sorts of agendas and all sorts of people wanting to protect their patch, but again I appeal to all of those involved in these issues to think about our country, to think about what is best for our country and to think about how well we can do.
There is no clearer example than, again, something that the member for Chisholm raised: the former Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business and his mission to make Australia's waterfront more competitive. She spoke about it in terms of dogs and balaclavas. I understand why she said that, but she really should rise above it and look at the results of that very difficult time and at just how Australia has moved to be competitive with the world. At the same time, the workers on the waterfront actually did better out of it. Yes, there were too many workers on the waterfront and too many sweetheart deals—and that has all been cleaned up—but those who are left are very happy in their jobs. They are well paid, they work hard and they produce output for the country. That is all of us working together.
On the one hand, Peter Reith will go down in history as probably the most hated and despised minister for workplace relations but, on the other hand, he will go down in history as the person who had the grit, determination and foresight—
—The workers' friend.
—The workers' friend—I thank the minister. Peter Reith will go down in history as having produced a better outcome not only for the country but for the workers on the waterfront and, of course, for our farmers, as the member for Dawson will know.
The bill will certainly assist small business—there is no doubt about that. I want to give the parliament a very sobering example of where I have seen this happen with a business known to me in Townsville. This business had an employee who, ultimately, misappropriated $93,000 from the business. When it was discovered, the employee was terminated with some help from a lawyer. But the employer was then sued by this employee for unfair dismissal. 
Can you believe that we have laws in this country that would allow a person who misappropriated $93,000 from a business to sue for unfair dismissal? That is what we currently have—and that is a nonsense. Indeed, in this particular case the business could not recover from so much money being misappropriated and it failed. It had to close its doors. The proprietor is now living in very sad circumstances and is very disillusioned with the laws of this country. It is a horror story. That is why we have to be mindful of businesses which have fewer than 20 employees. These are businesses that do not have dedicated human resources managers—they do not have the staff.
I know what it is like to run a business with fewer than 20 employees. The manager does everything. You do not have time to be concerned with, or get up to speed on, all the nuances of industrial relations. It is very difficult when it comes to terminating an employee. That is why the benefits in this particular bill will certainly help small business and, because of that, small business will employ more people—they will not want to be dismissing them or terminating them.
The trade unions in this country need to come to a realisation that that is exactly what will happen. It is in their members' interest to support this particular legislation. But no, the Australian Labor Party takes its orders from the trade unions and it gets up publicly with a fear campaign and in its own interests—not in the country's interest—it says, `We are going to vote this down in the Senate.' We see so many examples of the government's legislative program being voted down in the Senate, not for reasons of principle but for reasons of politics. I find that quite sad. There will be a realisation, as the government becomes stronger and stronger because of its stand on principle and on doing the hard things, that that is the way forward for the Australian Labor Party.
The benefits apply particularly to this jurisdiction. I am very pleased to see that we are going to extend the qualifying period for employees of small business from three to six months and allow the commissioner to deal with some claims on small business on a no-papers basis—that is, without a hearing. That is code for it saving a lot of money for the business. It will halve the compensation that can be awarded as an employee of a small business, streamline the criteria for determining whether a dismissal by small business was unfair and refine the penalty provisions. I am particularly interested in the last point:
Refining penalty provisions for lawyers and agents who encourage unmeritorious claims against small business ...
I see that from time to time as well where employees who make wrongful claims about their employer, and the employer is forced to defend them. But the lawyers say, `If you defend this, it will cost you more money than if you do not defend it. Just pay up and get on with life.' There has to be some impediment to that, and this bill certainly provides that impediment.
I am going to finish my contribution there because I know the member for Dawson is eager to support the government's position. I would like her to have the opportunity to do that before question time begins. I strongly support this legislation and I appeal again to the Australian Labor Party to please think in the national interest about to the benefits of this bill.

name: Kelly, De-Anne, MP
text:
—I would like to thank the member for Herbert for his generosity in giving me time to speak about the Workplace Relations Amendment (Termination of Employment) Bill 2002 before question time. This bill seeks to: 
·	extend the operation of the federal unfair dismissal system by making greater use of the corporations power ...
·	improve the operation of the federal unfair dismissal laws as it impacts on small business
·	make a number of other improvements to the way the unfair dismissal laws operate ...
Why are we concerned about this? Firstly, I would like to go the annual report of the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations. In 2000-01 the Australian Industrial Registry received 8,090 unfair dismissal applications under the Workplace Relations Act—an increase of 7.8 per cent compared to the previous year. How significant is small business in Australia? In Australia there are 1,000,075 private sector, non-farm small businesses. In fact, they account for 96.4 per cent of all business in Australia. I want you to think about that—96.4 per cent. In other words, the overwhelming number of businesses in Australia are small businesses. They employ well over three million people—in fact, they account for half of all private sector, non-farm employment—so their contribution to Australia's economy is significant.
The most interesting insight into the difficulties that the unfair dismissal laws have for small business is contained in Don Harding's report published by the University of Melbourne, The Effect of Unfair Dismissal Laws on Small and Medium Sized Businesses 2002. Mr Harding found that there were a number of impacts on the human relations and personnel decisions made by small business as a result of unfair dismissal laws. The report notes:
·	11.6 per cent of businesses reported greater use of fixed term contracts;
·	21.3 per cent reported that they employ more casuals and fewer permanent staff ...
Remember that this is the biggest sector of business in Australia—
·	20.7 per cent reported that they employ more family and friends; and
·	26.6 per cent reported use of longer probationary periods.
These numbers relate to employees in the small business sector. As we have just established, the small business sector is one of the largest sectors in Australia. How many people does it employ? I will look at businesses by their number of employees, starting with casual employees first. Table 6 of Mr Harding's report shows that, for those businesses that employ between one and five employees, the number of casual employees is over 570,000. This makes it the largest sector of any business by number of employees. By contrast, businesses with over 100 employees employ in total only 33,000 casual employees. It is the one-to-five employee businesses that employ the bulk of Australians. Again, in the one-to-five employee sector, the report shows that there are 430,000 Australians employed part-time by these very small businesses—one might almost say they are microbusinesses. In the one-to-five employee sector, the report shows that there are 1,119,000 full-time employees. Again, not only is small business the most significant business sector in Australia; the microbusiness sector is the greatest employer of Australians.
Mr Harding goes on to look at the lower bound of cost impost from unfair dismissal laws. What is the cost of these laws that have been back to the Senate and rejected by the Labor Party time and time again? Let us have a look at the cost for the lower bound; Mr Harding has taken the worst possible case, in a conservative sense, so the costs are at a minimum. The total cost for microbusinesses with one to five employees is $436 million a year. That is the cost of the refusal by the Labor Party to allow this legislation through the Senate. The average cost per full-time employee—and again we are looking at microbusinesses with one to five employees—is $365 per full-time employee per year. That cost decreases for businesses with 100 or more employees to a cost of $158 per full-time employee per year. 
For an opposition that prides itself, as the member for Greenway said, on representing battlers in Australia, the saddest dimension of the refusal of the Labor Party to allow this legislation through is the impact or the burden on the unemployed. If we look at those who really pay the price for the Labor Party's intransigence—and Don Harding has examined this in a great deal of detail—they are not only the small businesses but also those who fail to get jobs. He goes on to say:
First, as discussed in earlier sections the laws result in unequal treatment of people who are equal except that one person is a marginal job applicant while the other person is a marginal job incumbent. Moreover, the young are over-represented as job applicants, while older people are over-represented as incumbents ... some of the people who are treated unfairly are those about which society should have great concern, namely the long-term unemployed, the less literate and those who have difficulty with formal modes of supervision and communication.
As he said in his report, `society should have the greatest concern' for certain groups, as should the Labor Party if they really represented Australia's battlers. But it is only rhetoric with you—and I refer to the Australian Labor Party. The people detailed in this report as those who suffer the burden of your refusal to pass this legislation are the long-term unemployed, the less literate and those who have difficulty with formal modes of supervision and communication. They are the ones who bear the burden of your refusal to pass this legislation. What does it cost per year for small business to have to suffer the Labor Party's intransigence? It costs $1.3 billion. That is a figure that resonates in another way, because the total cost of all the work programs in the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations in the last financial year was $1.3 billion. That funding had a tremendous result, I might say, with unemployment down to about six per cent. You impose this cost—
 (Hon. I.R. Causley)—The member for Dawson will address her remarks through the chair.
—Yes, indeed, Mr Deputy Speaker. The Labor Party imposes this cost on small business. The government spends this amount to get people into work, and you impose the burden on those in Australia who are most vulnerable. It is significant that the states, which support these unfair dismissal laws, are huffing and puffing again about it. I notice in today's Australian that, while the minister is making an earnest effort again to put this legislation before both houses, the state ministers for industrial relations are going to try to block it. The Australiansays:
The Labor states could consider manning a constitutional challenge to prevent Workplace Relations Minister Tony Abbott stripping them of their power to hear unfair dismissal cases.
...	...	...
A spokeswoman for the NSW Industrial Relations Minister John Della Bosca said NSW would strongly oppose the Bill because it would “cause great confusion for employees and employers.”
How can you be confused about paying $1.3 billion a year and putting a burden on those in the community least able to bear it? How can you be confused about that? Fortunately, I do not think the minister for workplace relations has too much to be concerned about, because I noticed the Australian also said:
Flinders University law professor Andrew Stewart said he expected a constitutional challenge would be mounted ... But he said such a challenge would be unlikely to succeed. 
There is more huff and puff from the Labor Party and the states and more of a burden for those in the community who can least afford it: those who are least literate, those who are long-term unemployed and those who are least able to work in the workplace under supervision. They are the ones who bear your burden. Out of interest, if we could get jobs for those 77,000 Australians who are denied work because of the Labor Party's intransigence in passing this legislation, the reality is that our level of unemployment would drop from 6.1 per cent to 5.4 per cent. That is what the Australian Labor Party is imposing on the most vulnerable people in the Australian community. Those seeking lower paid work and those who are the least literate are bearing the burden of your intransigence. Unemployment could be lowered from 6.1 per cent to 5.4 per cent if the Labor Party would pass this legislation. Again, the Labor Party hypocritically places a burden on the Australians least able to bear it.
