The debate may be resumed at a later hour and the member will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed. I would remind her, when she continues speaking, to address her remarks through the chair and resist the use of the words `you' and `your'.

name: Smith, Stephen, MP
text:
—In 1996, when John Howard got himself elected as Prime Minister—
—The member for Perth will refer to officers of the parliament and members of parliament by their titles.
—In 1996, when the Prime Minister, Mr John Howard, the member for Bennelong, got himself elected as Prime Minister, his slogan was `for all of us'. Now we know that, under John Howard, Medicare will be for just some of us. This has been John Howard's longstanding— 
—The member for Perth!
—This has been the Prime Minister's longstanding public policy ambition. The package which the Prime Minister and the Minister for Health and Ageing delivered a couple of weeks ago, underlined in the budget papers, will lead to the destruction of Medicare and the effective end of bulk-billing for Australian families. It will see a two-tiered health system: a second-class safety net for the poor, for pensioners and disadvantaged people, and everyone else will pay their way. As the then Leader of the Opposition, the member for Bennelong, John Howard, said in 1987 with his formal election commitment, `Doctors will be free to charge everyone else what they like.' The government's package will lead inevitably to the destruction of Medicare and to the end of bulk-billing for Australian families. 
It is important in this area to understand the history. Medicare was introduced in 1984. So far as bulk-billing rates were concerned in 1984, you could either say it was a walk-up start or they were effectively 50 per cent. Under Malcolm Fraser's last remake of Medibank—Malcolm Fraser's model 2, 3, 4 or 5—pensioners were bulk-billed. But from a walk-up start of effectively 50 per cent, bulk-billing rates increased in every year under the Hawke-Keating Labor government, to a peak of 80 per cent shortly after we left office. In every year since the election of John Howard as Prime Minister, bulk-billing rates have fallen. From the last set of official statistics available, we know that bulk-billing rates now sit at 69.6 per cent—an 11 per cent decline over the period of this government's office, an 11 per cent decline over seven years.
Importantly, what do we know about that decline? We know that essentially over the last 18 months, half of that decline has occurred—a sharp decline. A month after the government's re-election in November 2001 the health department advised the new minister for health, Senator Patterson, that unless the government took dramatic steps there would be a dramatic decline in bulk-billing, and the department could not advise the government where the next stable level of bulk-billing would be. So it is 69 per cent and in dramatic decline.
We also know that those bulk-billing rates vary around the countryside. There are clear differences depending upon where you live: metropolitan areas, outer metropolitan areas, and rural and regional areas. As a rule of thumb you can say that the average bulk-billing rate in metropolitan areas is around 75 per cent; in outer metropolitan areas it is somewhere between 60 per cent and 70 per cent; and in rural and regional areas it is somewhere between 50 per cent and 60 per cent. But they do vary. On the December 2000 figures, federal electorate by federal electorate, for the first time in as long as I can remember, one of our rural and regional electorates had a bulk-billing rate which started with a two: 29 per cent. And it does not occur by itself. It occurs as a result of neglect, attrition and stealth, with the government keeping the screws on the Medicare rebate, keeping the screws on Medicare until, after seven years in office, the Prime Minister gets the opportunity not to fix the problem but to put in a classic John Howard fix.
What is the analysis of the government's measure? The government does three things in its package of measures—the so-called fairer Medicare package. The first thing it does is pay a financial incentive to doctors to bulk-bill only pensioners and concession card holders—in effect, a de facto means testing of Medicare, destroying the fundamental principle of universality. Universality of health care is quite a straightforward thing. Many people do not understand the notion of universality, but they do understand the notion of all Australians, irrespective of where they live, irrespective of their wealth or income, having access to quality health care. The underlying, fundamental principle of Medicare and the underlying, fundamental principle of Medibank—its precursor—was to make health care available to all Australians in a quality way, irrespective of where they lived and irrespective of how much money they had in their pocket. We all made our various contributions to funding that system through the taxation system, through a progressive income tax system and through the Medicare levy. What the government does, in achieving John Howard's objective, is corral bulk-billing to pensioners and concession card holders only. 
The second thing the government does in its package is to give the AMA what it has always wanted: to split a doctor's charge or copayment from the patient rebate. At the moment, when you go to see a doctor who does not bulk-bill you might be charged the average current rate, $40. You pay the $40 and subsequently you get reimbursed $25.05—85 per cent of the schedule fee. The government's process would enable the government to pay directly to the doctor the $25.05—the rebate—and simply charge the customer, the client or the patient the difference, splitting the fee. That is a longstanding aspiration of the AMA. Why? Because it can have its cake and eat it too. The inevitable consequence of that change, which is currently unlawful, can only lead, bit by bit, visit by visit, to doctors charging Australian families more for the health care they have come to depend and rely upon.
Who are the families who will be whacked by that? You cannot get a concession card for health care purposes in Australia if your family income is $32,300 or more. If you are sitting on $35,000 to $50,000—the ones who get the $4 milkshake and sandwich tax cut—your doctor's fees will go up, bit by bit, visit by visit. It is not just the Labor Party saying this. The AMA, in its statement when the details of the package first emerged on Easter Monday, said that it is inevitable that doctors' fees will go up. 
The third change introduced by the government is to say, `Now that we know that there will be gap fees, we will allow people to privately insure for gap fees when those gap fees get to $1,000'—for the first time allowing out of hospital insurance so far as doctors are concerned. That will only be inflationary, and it is the first step in introducing into our GP primary preventive care system an American-style health system. 
What are the consequences of the government's package that the Prime Minister says will fix the problem? Firstly, we will end up with a second-class safety net for pensioners and poor people; secondly, bulk-billing will be effectively removed from Australian families bit by bit, visit by visit and they will pay more and more for the health care that they have come to rely upon; and, thirdly, we will have effectively a three-tiered health care system with private health insurance being made available for the gap that you pay for a doctor. That can only of itself be inflationary and will only lead to doctors saying to themselves, `I know that some of my patients have got private health insurance, so as a consequence I will increase my fees even more.'
I saw the Minister for Health and Ageing out there the other day saying, `These are terrible, shocking, nasty Labor Party lies.' The problem for the minister is that we are not running a scare campaign; we are running a fact campaign. We are not making misrepresentations; we are making the truth known to the Australian public. The problem for the government is not just us. The AMA is out there saying that it is inevitable that costs will go up. When the four doctors groups—the AMA, the Australian Divisions of General Practice, the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners and the Rural Doctors Association of Australia—formally met to consider the package, they said: 
The Government's Medicare Package does not adequately address the issues of access and affordability. 
The Government's Package will fail to support quality accessible patient care for Australians. It will bring about a two-tiered system of care.
Catholic Health Australia said:
This package disproportionately hits the hard-up and the sick and erodes the value of the Medicare entitlement for people without concession cards.
Families and people on meagre incomes will find bulk billing elusive ...
The Australian Consumers Association said:
In the wake of these measures, the collapse of bulk billing will accelerate and even more people ... will not be able to afford to go to the doctor.
ACOSS said:
The concept that bulk billing should only be for pensioners and health care card holders will lead to many of those patients being treated as second class citizens ...
In the published opinion polls, we find one in 10 Australians saying, that the changes might be better for them or better for the nation, and nearly five in 10—one out of two—Australians saying `We can work out these changes: not only will they be bad for us, they will be bad for Australia.' 
Why is there this response to these measures? There is a response to these measures because Australians know that when it comes to Medicare and bulk-billing they cannot trust the member for Bennelong. They cannot trust Malcolm Fraser's Treasurer, they cannot trust the Leader of the Opposition in the 1980s and they cannot trust him now as Prime Minister. Remember when he got himself elected in 1996. For all of us his two great misrepresentations are: the `never, ever GST' and `We won't touch Medicare.' But go back and remember the history. The Whitlam government introduces Medibank. The Fraser government with Howard as its Treasurer sets about destroying it at the first available opportunity. Labor introduces Medicare in 1984, and John Howard spends all of the eighties seeking to destroy it. 
What did John Howard say from opposition about Medicare? In the eighties he said that Medicare was a `miserable, cruel fraud', a `scandal', a `total and complete failure', a `quagmire', a `disaster', a `financial monster' and a `human nightmare'. He said that he would `pull Medicare right apart' and `get rid of bulk-billing' and that it was an `absolute rort' and `raped the poor'. In his formal election commitment in 1987, he said:
Bulk billing will not be permitted for anyone except the pensioners and the disadvantaged. Doctors will be free to charge whatever they choose.
We know what happened in 1987. That promise was recycled in Fightback in 1993 in almost exactly the same terms. We know what happened in 1993. When the member for Bennelong, Mr Howard, got himself re-elected as the Leader of the Opposition and went to the people in 1995-96, he knew that he had to fold his cards on Medicare and patiently wait until he had an opportunity. In 1995-96, he said:
We're not going to contemplate altering the universality of Medicare. I mean, that is fundamental, and we're also going to keep bulk billing.
His shadow health minister, Dr Wooldridge, said:
Universal bulk billing stays. 
On the Sunday program in 1995, Laurie Oakes asked Mr Howard:
Do you guarantee that Medicare would not be touched under a Coalition government?
Howard: We absolutely guarantee the retention of Medicare. We guarantee the retention of bulk billing ... 
Oakes: You see what people will worry about that: `The retention of Medicare' is exactly the phrase Malcolm Fraser used about Medibank. He promised the retention of Medibank, and it went.
Howard: ... Yes, well you're questioning John Howard and nobody else, and I'm giving a guarantee that it is not going to be changed. I'm giving a guarantee about bulk billing.
In 1995-96, he said: 
We're keeping Medicare full stop. There's no doubt about that. Let's have that absolutely crystal clear, we are going to keep Medicare lock, stock and barrel.
In the coalition's 1996, 1998 and 2001 election commitments, John Howard formally committed himself again to no change to Medicare and no change to bulk-billing. Government members variously said:
As part of Medicare, a Coalition government will unequivocally retain bulk billing ...
In 1998, they said:
The number of bulk billed services has increased significantly ... More Australians have access to free medical services than at any time ...
So he folds his cards on Medicare and patiently waits. He patiently waits; just as he did with the GST, he now does with Medicare. Australians know that they cannot trust a word that John Howard says about bulk-billing or Medicare. They know they cannot trust the word of the member for Bennelong, the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, says about Medicare or bulk-billing. They now know that there is an absolute and complete contrast between the Liberal Party and the Howard government and the Labor Party. John Howard is returning to the scene of his public policy crimes of the 1980s to destroy Medicare, to restrict bulk-billing to pensioners and the disadvantaged and to allow doctors to charge everyone else what doctors feel like. That is where he wants to take Medicare and bulk-billing. We are quite happy to have that fight. We are quite happy to have that fight every day now, here, in the Senate, in the parliament and in the community, day in, day out, until the next election. 
We will fight tooth and nail the government's proposals to destroy Medicare and end bulk-billing for Australian families. When the Leader of the Opposition stands up tonight, he will outline to Australians a measure of public policy responses which will address the work force shortage issues in outer metropolitan and rural and regional Australia, will recognise the legitimate aspiration claims for increased incomes so far as general practitioners are concerned and will strike out with a first instalment for a Labor government—just as it created and built Medibank and Medicare—to rescue Medicare again, to restore bulk-billing for Australian families and to have that stark contrast at the next election. It is quite a simple choice for Australians and their families: vote for the Liberal Party and let them destroy Medicare; but, if you want to save Medicare, restore bulk-billing to respectable rates and have a decent, universal, affordable health care system where you do not have to worry about how much money you have got in your pocket when you are worried about whether you should take your kids to your local doctor, vote Labor. The Leader of the Opposition will outline that comprehensively tonight. (Time expired)

name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
text:
—Only the most fervid mind of the opposition could believe that a $917 million injection into the health system in Australia is somehow the destruction of Medicare. It is a $917 million injection into the system, and the opposition somehow believe that this is destruction. As I will point out, it is far from that. The topic that is raised by the honourable member for Perth this afternoon is one which is entirely based on a furphy. One of the difficulties for the opposition, as on many other subjects, is that they cannot actually agree about what they are talking about. If you look at some of the quotes from earlier this year about what universality and Medicare mean, you can see the inconsistency which is once again being displayed by the opposition. Like on so many other subjects throughout the course of this government, the opposition are trying to walk both sides of the street and are completely divided as to what they actually want. We have the Leader of the Opposition in a radio interview on 5 March this year saying this: 
And so, unless you address the fundamentals of this issue and get a commitment to restore bulk-billing, then bulk-billing will continue to decline. You say to me, it was never intended to be universal. It was.
That was the Leader of the Opposition. On 16 April the member for Perth said this:
... a false premise that universality means 100 per cent bulk-billing outcomes. It does not, it never has and it was never expected to.
So on the one hand we have the Leader of the Opposition holding out the suggestion that somehow universality of bulk-billing means 100 per cent, yet, on the other hand, the member for Perth—the opposition shadow spokesman on health—saying that it does not, it never has and it was never expected to. This inconsistency in the opposition is endemic. For the information of the member for Perth and those who are listening to this debate this afternoon, Medicare was built on three principles: universal access to the Medicare rebate, including bulk-billing; free treatment for every public patient at a public hospital; and subsidies for pharmaceuticals through the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.
In relation to universality, the member for Perth went back to 1984. Let us look at what the then health spokesman for the Labor Party, Dr Neal Blewett, said when putting Labor's plan together for the New Health Plan, as it was entitled, in 1982-83:
Doctors will be free to choose their method of bulk-billing the patient. They can charge the patient nothing and recover 85 per cent of the schedule fee directly from the public fund. It is expected that doctors will use this bulk-billing procedure for pensioners, low-income patients, the chronically ill and those in need.
That is what Dr Blewett's vision was in 1982-83 for the Medicare scheme which was introduced subsequently. What did Dr Blewett say after it had been introduced? Let us go to 1987. The then Labor minister for health in this parliament said this:
What we have mostly in this country is not doctors exploiting bulk billing but compassionate doctors using the bulk billing facility to treat pensioners, the disadvantaged and others who are not well off or who are in great need of medical services, which was always the intention.
The intention is quite clear from the words of Dr Blewett both prior to the introduction of the Medicare scheme back in 1982-83 and subsequent to its introduction when he was the Commonwealth minister for health. So there is confusion for a start in the minds of the opposition about this issue.
Secondly, if you look at bulk-billing at the present, you can see that about seven out of 10 general practitioner services are delivered at no cost to patients. Indeed, for those people over the age of 65—the elderly or the seniors in our community—close to eight out of 10 general practitioner services to patients are provided at no cost to the patient. So when we talk about bulk-billing, we can see that, so far as the data is concerned, a great number of people in Australia are in receipt of bulk-billing. 
What is this package announced recently by the Prime Minister and the Minister for Health and Ageing about? It is a $917 million package of measures to strengthen and make fairer the Medicare system in Australia by doing three things: firstly, making the Medicare system and health generally more affordable; secondly, making it more accessible for Australian families; and, thirdly, making health services more available. This is a triple A approach to Medicare and the health system in Australia. 
How do we make it more affordable? We provide incentives in the budget to general practitioners to bulk-bill those seven million Australian concession card holders, and the incentives will vary according to the geographical location of the practice. There will be up to $22,000 for those doctors in rural and remote areas of Australia in order to provide them an additional incentive to bulk-bill.
It is easier, I suppose, for people who live in urban areas of Australia, where bulk-billing is more readily available, than for the people out in rural parts of Australia who might have to drive an hour or an hour and a half to get to the nearest town and the nearest doctor. If they then face the situation—I am sure the honourable member for Maranoa will point this out in his comments—where they have to wait three or four days or until they are going to town next time, they have to fund the Medicare rebate in the meantime and then spend all that time driving to find a Medicare office in order to get that rebate back. This measure is directed towards improving bulk-billing for those concession card holders throughout Australia. This will make Medicare more affordable, particularly to those seven million Australian concession card holders.
The second point is that the legislation is about making the system more accessible—more accessible in terms of the illustration I have just made. When someone goes to the doctor now and they pay their bill, they then have to go and process that rebate claim at a Medicare office. They have to take the time to do it and if they cannot do it then they are out of pocket until they get the rebate paid and then they have to go to the extra effort and take the extra time to go and make that claim. So, under these proposals to make Medicare more accessible for ordinary Australian families, what we are proposing is that when a person leaves the doctor's surgery they have no more to pay and they have nothing more to do. I believe that ordinary Australian families will welcome this measure to make Medicare more accessible to them.
The third element of this package is to make Medicare more available to Australians. We know that one of the reasons for—indeed, the main reason—
—I rise on a point of clarification, Mr Deputy Speaker. Do you mean that there will be no need for Medicare offices?
 (Mr Jenkins)—There is no point of order. The honourable member for Rankin should be very careful to not do that on other occasions.
—What I was saying was that the third element of this package is to make health services for Australians more available. We know that one of the primary reasons for a bulk-billing service being provided is related to the number of doctors and general practitioners in a particular area. If you have more doctors in a particular area then you have a greater likelihood of competition bringing about bulk-billing.
That is why we are making more doctors available through this package over a period of time by providing more university training places—which the minister for education has announced—by providing more training specifically in rural areas for students and bonding those students to those areas, and by providing more practice nurses who can do part of the work of general practitioners throughout Australia. 
This package of measures is actually addressing not only the short-term issues but also the longer-term issues by providing for a larger medical work force in Australia. These measures include: another 234 public medical school places, increasing the annual intake by 150 of GP training places for general practice registrars and funding more practised nurses in general practices in areas in which we have work force shortages.
It is these three contexts, the triple-A approach to strengthening Medicare, which is what this government are about—making Medicare more affordable, more accessible, more available. That is what we are doing. What you see in the budget is overall an increase in funding, from $29.7 billion to $31.2 billion in the current year. Indeed, since this government came to office we have had a 65 per cent increase in expenditure on these matters.
In addition to that, the states are responsible for the public hospital system in Australia. What we are offering them, what we have put on the table, is a $42 billion package to assist them in running their public hospital systems over the next five years. That is a $10 billion increase in funding.
—How much?
—It is a $10 billion increase—a 17 per cent increase—from the Commonwealth to the states of Australia in order to fund their public hospital systems. On top of that is the money being received by the states from the goods and services tax, which all goes back to the states. In this financial year, some $31.7 billion from the goods and services tax is going directly back to the states so that they can fund their public hospitals and other services.
But we have actually seen over the last decade or more 14,000 beds taken out of the public hospital system by the states throughout Australia. The honourable member for Mitchell is from New South Wales. There have been 6,130 beds ripped out of the public hospital system in New South Wales. We are putting an extra $10 billion in but we are saying to the states, and we are saying this in the interest of every taxpayer in Australia, that we want some transparency from them as to how they use that money. We have had a situation where states have ripped public hospital beds out of the system, where they have not properly accounted for the money which goes to the states from the Commonwealth to help them run their public hospital system.
We are saying, `We'll give you $10 billion extra over the next five years of the Commonwealth-state health care agreement but we want some transparency from you. We want you to match the growth that we are putting into the system because, after all, these are your public hospitals, you are responsible for them and we do not want to see a situation where you are just running down services or cost shifting on to the Commonwealth to pay for other things when you are saying that you need this for health.' That is something which we are quite keen to see in place.
We heard a lot from the honourable member for Perth this afternoon about what the Australian people think. It reminded me of a passage in a book which I am sure some members in this place have read, Recollections of a Bleeding Heart. It is Don Watson's book about former Prime Minister Keating. There is an interesting little reference to the member for Perth in the book. It says this:
Stephen—
that is, the member for Perth—
believed politics had to be played by the polls. Whatever the focus groups are most impressed by, repeat. Whatever the focus groups say they want, say you'll give them; say you're committed to it. Whatever they don't like, you don't like either. 
And of course in his speech this afternoon we heard the honourable member for Perth saying, `Well, this is what the polls are saying; this is what the focus groups are saying.' We see this from the Labor Party: no stance on principle, whether it is over border protection or GST or, more recently, whether it is in relation to a whole series of measures. These are matters over which the Labor Party simply put the finger up and try to test which way the wind is blowing at a particular time. They do not have any commitment to any fundamental beliefs and values about where they want to take Australia into the future. They have no sense about having to build on programs, like we are doing with this legislation.
They are trapped in some sort of 1970s view of Australia so that some program that was introduced in 1970 somehow has to stay there set in concrete forever and a day. We heard it in question time this week about education; we heard it in question time this week on Medicare—well, in the only question we got from the opposition so far as Medicare was concerned, despite the feigning of concern generally about the issue.
What are they going to do? They said this week that the tax increase of $2.4 billion was not enough. So I presume that tonight the Leader of the Opposition is going to announce that there will be more tax increases if Labor are elected. They say that they are going to put more money into Medicare. So what have we got? Where are they going to take the taxes from? Are they going to rip off the private health insurance rebate on ancillaries? So, if you have private health insurance to take your child to the dentist, or to the physiotherapist because he or she has sprained an ankle—or your elderly parent has this insurance to cover glasses so that they can read better or drive down the street and enjoy their life—is the Labor Party going to rip away the rebate on those benefits tonight?
What we will have tonight is a tax hike from the Labor Party. Labor is not a party of reducing taxes; it is a party of tax hikes. That is what we see every time in states right around Australia. That is what the state Labor health ministers have been suggesting and, no doubt, that is what we will hear from the Leader of the Opposition tonight.

name: Sawford, Rod, MP
text:
—It is an oft-stated cliche that there is nothing more important than a person's health. But, when it comes to this House, only one side takes that seriously, and that is the Labor side. The coalition has never believed in universal health care. Medicare was always begrudgingly supported, for electoral purposes only. Polling minister—what a joke! There is no more classic example than the current Prime Minister. He has got form, he has had form and, in this budget, the coalition begins, yet again, another planned demolition by frontal attack on Medicare. You can only understand the coalition by looking backwards. What a pity that the Prime Minister fails to realise that life is to be lived forwards. In 1987 the current Prime Minister said what he believed then and what he believes now:
Bulk-billing will not be permitted for anyone except pensioners and the disadvantaged. Doctors will be free to charge whatever fees they choose.
On Medicare the coalition have not changed with the times. They are still in that 1987 time warp. Great leaders do not just change with the times; they change the times. When it comes to health the Prime Minister is incapable of that. Nine years later, in the 1996 election, he said:
We're not going to contemplate altering the universality of Medicare. I mean, that is fundamental, and we're also going to keep bulk-billing. We absolutely guarantee the retention of Medicare. We guarantee the retention of bulk-billing. 
I would hold my head down if I were on the other side.
We're keeping Medicare full stop. There's no doubt about that. Let's have that absolutely crystal clear, we are going to keep Medicare lock, stock and barrel.
Yeah—and pigs might fly! It is more like Medicare flaming and burning lock, stock and barrel. When it comes to the coalition, George Orwell's famous essay Politics and the Englishlanguage always comes to mind. But, on this occasion, here is an Orwellian quote from Animal Farm:
But the pigs were so clever that they could think of a way around every difficulty.
That is the quote that sums up the government's attitude to Medicare and their dealings with the Australian electorate. Here is another, from Muhammad Ali, that sums up the Prime Minister: `The man who views the world at 60 the same as he did at 30 has wasted 30 years of his life.' The Prime Minister's view on health is an anachronism, and everyone on this side and on that side knows it. Ask Michael Wooldridge, the former minister for health, for confirmation of that.
This budget and the government's plans for Medicare will actually make people sick. The handpassing of the billion-dollar liability to the states will ensure that. The government rip out $918 million from funding for health care agreements and—surprise, surprise!—there is $917 million for their Medicare package. What is that—a million for Kay Patterson? Medicare is means tested, but the 30 per cent private health insurance rebate is not. I am of an age where I can remember what happened to ordinary people who became seriously ill before Medicare. Let me cite a few examples of what it was like for ordinary people.
In the mid-50s my father became seriously ill and required drastic surgery. He was unable to pay hospital and convalescent bills. Threatened with court action, he was forced to sell his only asset, a block of land. During his convalescence, and unable to pay for private insurance, he waited hours upon hours for attention at a public hospital. Even later the local doctor's surgery was no better. There was a clear distinction between the treatment for people who could pay and the treatment for people who may not have been able to pay. I experienced it myself with my own parents in the waiting room. I had won a scholarship which gave me five years health membership. We all had an appointment at 9 o'clock in the morning to see different doctors. I was seen at half past nine. I returned to get my parents at 10, but they were still there; at 11, still there; at 12, still there; at one, still there; at two, come back tomorrow. That is what happens when you get a two-tiered system like the one the coalition plans to put in place.
Let us return to that billion-dollar handpass to the states. That will, of course, lead to longer waiting lists in our state public hospitals for elective surgery, and unbelievable pressure on emergency departments as a result of the abolition of bulk-billing. Waiting all day to see a doctor will again become the norm, just as it was in my parents' time—and it will not be much better in the local GP's waiting room either. Health Minister Patterson has admitted that there will be no control over the fees doctors charge their patients. As the AMA has said, that means that, for the 13 million Australians without pensioner concession health care cards, the cost of seeing the doctor will increase. Spelling that out in more specific detail, the President of the AMA, Kerryn Phelps, said:
What will need to happen is that for doctors to continue to bulk-bill their concession card holders they're going to have to charge their non concession card holders more in order to meet the cost of running their practices. 
How come that is not obvious to the government? Or is it? However, what she does not say is that concession card holders will wait and wait—just as my parents waited—to see their local GP, while priority will be given both subtly and not so subtly to the user who pays. Bit by bit, visit by visit, cost by cost, wait by wait, the price to see a doctor will increase and, in one way or another, all Australians will pay more.
Since Medicare was introduced, doctors have never been allowed to bill Medicare as well as charge patients directly—it has been either one or the other. But the Prime Minister wants that to change to what he believed in 1987; that is, `Doctors will be free to charge whatever fees they choose.' And of course we remember the coalition health policy of 1992. Remember the quote `Bulk-billing will no longer be available for the rest of the population'? That is the government's truth; that is where it is; that is its home; that is its ideology. That means that 13 million Australians will be denied bulk-billing. Concession card holders should now prepare themselves for second-rate attention, for that is surely what they will get—just as my parents' generation received so many years ago.
Bulk-billing in my electorate of Port Adelaide was around 90 per cent and it is now around the mid-eighties. That is a testament to the professionalism and the integrity of the GPs in my electorate. However, it also underlines that the current Medicare system needs to be upgraded. Labor recognises that, and tonight our leader, Simon Crean, will outline our commitment to the retention, upgrading and repackaging of Medicare to suit the challenges of today and tomorrow.
—What about the next day?
—Mark my words, member for Maranoa: the Australian public will respond positively to Labor's plans; they will reject the government's two-tiered system; and they will, after what has been a period of international distraction, focus on the domestic issues about which they care passionately. Fair-minded Australians will support services to all Australians. And pre-eminent in all public services is Medicare—its universality and its retention. The Australian reported yesterday that only one in 10 Australians believe that they will be better off if the government's plans are implemented—one in 10. As far as GPs are concerned, 60 per cent say that they will not take up the government's package and do not believe that they will be better off. The government's package will be rejected in the Senate.
Australians may note that health did not feature until page 11 of the budget coverage yesterday in the Australian and not until page 8 in the Advertiser in Adelaide. The commentary was thin and it was absolutely zilch today. But that will not change their view. They will support Labor's plans for Medicare, not the government's. They will support a future for Medicare, not a trip down the Prime Minister's anachronistic and antiquated memory lane.
After the economic indicators of interest rates, inflation and unemployment, health is a pre-eminent issue that concerns Australians—and the fundamental plank is Medicare. That fundamental plank will be retained, improved and kept under Labor—no matter what those on the other side do. Some might say, as G.K. Chesterton did, that the Labor Party is getting into hot water on a number of fronts. But, as Chesterton said, at least it keeps you clean. Perhaps we can take some faith from Buddha, who said that there are only two mistakes one can make along the road to truth. The minister talked about truth; he would not know what truth was. The two mistakes that one can make along the road to truth, according to Buddha, are not going all the way and not starting. Not going all the way rejects the universality of Medicare; not starting reflects the PM's 1987 position on Medicare, which he adheres to today. Unlike the government, Labor will not make those two mistakes. 
Wiser people than any of us here have said and written through the millenniums that the true prosperity of a nation is measured by how children, the aged and the sick are treated. That will be the focus of Labor, and it will be the right focus because Medicare matters—Medicare matters.

name: Scott, Bruce, MP
text:
—I rise this afternoon to speak on the MPI brought forward by the Labor Party. The matter of public importance introduced by the Labor Party is:
The Government's destruction of Medicare and the dramatic decline in bulk billing to the detriment of Australian families.
The government reject outright this MPI. In this debate, we have had pathetic performances by two members of the other side of the parliament.
With our A Fairer Medicare package, the government's focus is on the long-term future health care needs of all Australians. This stands in stark contrast to the record of the Labor Party when they were in government. All they have been doing is running a scare campaign. That is all they seem to know how to do—although they have been running another campaign, and that is for a new Leader of the Opposition. So, tonight when we hear the Leader of the Opposition outline his vision for Medicare, I shall be wondering what the next Leader of the Opposition will have to say when he is in the seat on the other side of the House leading the Labor Party. So tonight's announcement will probably be a very temporary policy position. We will be listening. We want to hear from the opposition. They seem to run two campaigns: a scare campaign and a new leadership campaign. That is all they seem to be capable of. 
I will place some real facts on the record about this government's A Fairer Medicare package. The universality of Medicare will be retained.
—Absolutely.
—Absolutely, as the minister at the table, the Minister for Children and Youth Affairs, acknowledges. All Australians will still have access to the Medicare rebate, and this will not change. This is in stark contrast to the scare campaign being run by the other side of the parliament. There is no means test. There will be no means test. As is the case now, doctors will remain in control of their bulk-billing practices and can choose to provide care at no cost to the patient, regardless of whether or not they hold a Commonwealth concession card—another myth that the Labor Party are peddling around all of the country is now dispelled.
There is nothing in the package that should cause doctors to increase their fees. The A Fairer Medicare package will increase transparency, affordability and convenience for patients—as the Minister for Ageing outlined in his address this afternoon. There is nothing in the package which should increase pressure on emergency departments in hospitals. Why? Because the government is spending $917 million over four years—
—How much?
—The government is spending $917 million of additional money over four years to make attending GPs more affordable. How could an injection of $917 million possibly be gutting Medicare, as the Labor opposition want to promote?
—More money for Maranoa.
—I want to touch on the issue of rural Australia in a moment, because this is an element we are not hearing about from the Labor Party. We have not heard anything from the opposition about rural Australia and GPs in rural Australia. 
—They don't know where it is.
—No. They would get lost if they went out there—there is no question about that. Contrary to the claims made by the Labor Party, contrary to the whining and the scare campaign of those on the other side, bulk-billing will not be restricted to families, with two children, earning less than $32,292 a year. It will not, as they have said, be denied to people earning in excess of this in any year. People who are not concession cardholders, and families who earn more than $32,292 a year, will have access to bulk-billing. Doctors will continue to be able to provide care at no cost to patients, regardless of whether or not they hold a Commonwealth concession card, as is the situation today. The coalition government is acting in the long-term interests, the best interests, of all Australians. That is why it delivered this Medicare package. This is A Fairer Medicare in every sense of the word. There are measures in this package that will make a real difference in rural and regional and outer metropolitan areas of Australia—areas totally neglected by the Labor Party in their 13 years in government.
I will outline some of the initiatives that are going to make a real difference in outer metropolitan, rural and regional areas. This package contains a number of initiatives to attract doctors to rural and remote areas where there is an insufficient supply of doctors today. That is one of the reasons bulk-billing rates are declining in some rural and remote parts of Australia. Our way of addressing this is to make sure we get more doctors out there. We have introduced positive measures, new initiatives, to increase the supply of doctors. It is a supply and demand situation, and we understand that, because the members on this side of the parliament are in touch with our constituents. We know the real concerns out there, and we are doing something about them.
More doctors will be provided where they are needed most by increasing the number of places in medical schools around Australia by 234 every year and by increasing the number of GP training places by 150 every year. Those are extraordinary numbers, yet we never hear the opposition talking about the positive way in which we are addressing the issue of the shortage of doctors in outer metropolitan, rural and regional areas. The opposition had 13 years to address issues such as this when they were in government but, as we so often heard, they were going to do it the next year, the 14th year, or in the 15th year. But, luckily, the Australian people woke up to the way that they were running this country.
The issues of Medicare, health care and the supply of doctors to rural, regional and outer metropolitan areas are being addressed by this government in a positive way that will see to the long-term future need for doctors to provide health care in these areas. The incentives that will be paid to doctors to bulk-bill Commonwealth concession cardholders will be substantially higher in rural and remote areas—another incentive for the doctors in these areas to bulk-bill. These incentives range from $3,500 per GP in urban and outer metropolitan areas to around $22,050 in other rural and remote areas. As a matter of fact, I looked at the figures for my own electorate of Maranoa just to confirm what we had been saying as a government.
—What is your bulk-billing rate?
—The member for Hunter has some rural constituents, so I think he ought to be out there telling them what this government aims to do to bring more doctors into the rural areas in his seat of Hunter. I would be interested to hear whether the member for Hunter is out there telling his people the truth about what this government is doing to bring doctors into the Hunter region. In my electorate of Maranoa, doctors can receive up to $6.30 per concessional patient if they participate in the GP access scheme.
—What about low-income families?
—I went to one of my larger towns—the town of Emerald, which is specifically mentioned in the minister's release—where there is a young population and where there is an extra $6.30 per patient as an incentive to bulk-bill. That is not something that is available here. I am wondering whether tonight we will hear from the very temporary leader of the Labor Party that they are going to pay $6.30 per patient to those doctors who participate in the GP access scheme. We will all be listening to see whether there is even a mention of rural Australia in his Medicare package tonight. I am almost out of time. There is a whole lot more I could outline in relation to the incentive programs—
—You have run out of things to say! What is your bulk-billing rate?
—because there is so much to talk about, in a positive way, with regard to what we are doing as a government—in stark contrast to the whining, whingeing and complaining from the other side of the parliament. I say to them, and to those with outer metropolitan and rural seats, that they should be out spreading the government's positive message. (Time expired).
 (Hon. I.R. Causley)—Order! The discussion is now concluded.

name: Slipper, Peter, MP
text:
—I move:
That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Development of off-base housing for Defence at Adamstown, Newcastle, NSW.
The Defence Housing Authority proposes the progressive development of off-base housing to provide 72 new residences at Adamstown, New South Wales. The role of the Defence Housing Authority is to provide suitable housing to meet the operational needs of the Australian Defence Force and the requirements of the Department of Defence.
The Defence Housing Authority satisfies Defence accommodation requirements by a mixture of construction off-base with a view to retaining the properties or selling them with a lease attached; construction on-base to accord with Defence operational or policy requirements and/or if such construction is the most cost-effective for all concerned; direct purchase with a view to retaining the properties or selling them with a lease attached; and direct lease from the private rental market. All of these methods are utilised in locations such as Newcastle; however, owned assets in Newcastle are in relatively short supply. Constructed housing delivered through bulk procurement contracts is the most effective provisioning option readily geared to Defence requirements. Building in a desirable location such as Adamstown also maximises the potential return to the Commonwealth. 
This proposal will involve developing a former Army Reserve site at Adamstown situated some six kilometres south-west of the Newcastle central business district. The vacant site occupies an area of approximately 5.25 hectares. It is proposed to construct 72 individual residences comprising 60 four-bedroom detached dwellings and 12 three-bedroom townhouses. The new residences will be fully compliant with current Defence and community standards. The proposed project will have a positive effect on the local economy during the construction period, both through persons working directly on the site and through the many more persons working off-site supplying material, plant and equipment. In the Newcastle market, construction of 72 additional dwellings to partly meet Defence housing requirements is not expected to affect either the sale market or the rental market for residential accommodation. The estimated cost of the proposal is $21.6 million.
In its report the Public Works Committee has recommended that this project proceed, subject to its recommendations. The Defence Housing Authority accepts those recommendations. I thank the Public Works Committee for its work in relation to this matter. Subject to parliamentary approval, competitive tenders will be called for construction to commence in June next year. The development will proceed in two stages, with delivery of all completed houses expected by September 2004. I commend the motion to the House.

name: Grierson, Sharon, MP
text:
—On behalf of the citizens of Newcastle, I am pleased to support this motion. The $21.6 million housing development will be welcomed in our city, where housing land is in short supply. Adamstown is, as the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration said, an established suburb that is very well located. It has great community spirit and access to all the facilities Newcastle offers. Like many inner city suburbs, it has experienced declining population, leading to some reduced services, such as bank closures. But this new development of 72 family houses will, we hope, assist in boosting demand in that area and thereby will lead to the reinstatement of services in Adamstown.
I acknowledge and praise the work of Mr Matt Chambers from the Defence Housing Association in his consultation with the community, but I note that the Public Works Committee recommends that Defence Housing Australia ensure that adequate direct community consultation is in place for such developments in the future. Some concerns have been expressed that the process was perhaps not run as directly through the people themselves as it could have been. I also commend and thank the Public Works Committee for visiting Newcastle and allowing the community to speak directly with them about any concerns they had about this development. 
Again, this is a very welcome measure. We welcome the fact that Defence families will occupy those houses in the future, at least at first. Certainly the economic investment will also be much welcomed, as unemployment is still an issue in Newcastle. We hope that, although it is still on exhibition, this project will continue and will be given final approval by Newcastle City Council. 
Question agreed to.

name: Abbott, Tony, MP
text:
—in reply—In summing up this debate on the Workplace Relations Amendment (Termination of Employment) Bill 2002, I thank all the members who have participated. I particularly thank the many government members who have used the debate on this bill as an opportunity to restate their strong commitment to entirely exempting small business from the operation of the unfair dismissal laws and to state, and state again, the fact that the unfair dismissal laws as they stand do very serious damage to small business. As the recent report by the Melbourne University Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research showed, the unfair dismissal laws as they stand cause $1.3 billion of additional expense to small business every year. The unfair dismissal laws as they stand have cost 68,000 jobs for ordinary Australians. I thank all members of the government who have spoken on this legislation.  
I also thank members of the opposition, in particular the member for Barton, the shadow minister for workplace relations. He has, as he always does, put a great deal of work into his contribution. I do want to take up three points that the member for Barton raised in his contribution. The first point that I wish to take issue with is his claim that this bill, if passed, will involve the Australian people in substantial extra costs. I must say that I found this point a little bit surprising from someone who has wide experience of industrial law as a practitioner. As the member for Barton would know, the Commonwealth normally coappoints state commissioners to the federal tribunals. If state commissioners can hear the additional unfair dismissal cases that may well come before the federal tribunal, costs may be reduced; but the fact is that, in order to hear federal matters, state commissioners need to be released by the state jurisdictions. Certainly the government cannot take state cooperation for granted on this matter; and, given that we cannot take state cooperation for granted, a responsible government makes a responsible budget provision for any extra costs that might be involved. But certainly there should be no extra cost to the economy at large as a result of this bill, if passed.
The second point made by the member for Barton that I would like to take up was a recognition of the desirability of giving the federal tribunal the ability to dismiss matters without merit without requiring the attendance on the tribunal of the respondents. I welcome this statement from the member for Barton, and I certainly would be happy to talk further with him about the form in which he would be prepared to support any such measure, because this is something that the government would like to progress. This is something that could very much improve the practical situation of small business as it deals with unfair dismissal claims.
The third and most important point that I take up is the commitment that the member for Barton repeatedly made in his speech to a more unified national system. But, having made that commitment repeatedly, he made it very clear that, while he wanted a more unified national system, he did not want it now and he did not want it in this way. It was a distinctly Augustinian approach, I thought: Lord give me chastity but not just yet.
It certainly is deeply desirable that Australia move as swiftly as possible to a more uniform national system of workplace relations regulation. I have said it before—let me say it again—that six separate industrial jurisdictions makes as much sense as six separate rail gauges. If we are ever to be a truly national economy, we need a truly national system of economic regulation, and that certainly includes a truly national system of workplace relations regulation. When the day comes that we achieve this, certainly it will create much greater convenience and significant cost savings to business. 
The same Melbourne University Institute study that I referred to earlier revealed that fully one-third of Australian businesses are not aware of whether their workplace relations arrangements come under state or federal law. If business is unaware of what the true jurisdictional situation is, how much more is that likely to be the case with ordinary workers, the people who are bringing these applications? It will be a great boon to business and a great boon to workers if they are able to understand clearly that there is one system, inevitably a federal system, under which workplace practices, workplace relations, are governed. 
There are three ways in which we might bring about a uniform national system. The first is by referendum. I think all of us in this House would understand the difficulties of proceeding down that path. The second is by referral. The third is by what I have previously called legislative encroachment. The member for Barton was most anxious that we should proceed to a more unified national system by way of referral. The problem is that he wants to bring about a more unified national system by a means which guarantees that that more unified national system simply will not happen. I think, if I may say so, that it is somewhat unworthy of a member of the member for Barton's stature and intellect to say on the one hand that he wants a more unified national system but on the other hand to demand that it proceed in a way which guarantees that it just will not happen.
The current state governments will not accept any diminution in their workplace relations jurisdictions. They will only accept a diminution on their own terms. If the only way you will accept a more unified national system is on your own terms, you are much more committed to your version of the system than you are to a national system as such. What we have in members opposite is born-again states righters. After 100 years of philosophical and intellectual demands for one national system of workplace relations regulations, they have here a golden opportunity to take a significant step in that direction. What happens? They become born-again states righters.
One of the points that the member for Barton made was that, before proceeding down this path, there should have been more active discussion with the state governments. If we wanted a referral of power, of course we would have had more discussion with the state governments. But we do not want a referral of power in this matter at this time. We simply want to exercise the jurisdiction, which the Commonwealth is constitutionally entitled to exercise under the corporations power, which gives us authority to legislate for the peace, order and good government of the Commonwealth in respect of corporations. 
Mr Deputy Speaker, I would put it to you and, through you, to the member for Barton that the only way we might one day, sometime down the track, get the agreement of the states to a referral of their workplace powers—regardless of the political colours that the state governments might wear at the time—is if their jurisdiction has been so steadily whittled away that there is very little of it left to refer.
If we are ever to have a uniform system of workplace relations regulation, it must be under federal law. We will never have a uniform system under the law of any of the states. It would be absurd for anyone to think otherwise. If there is a coalition federal government in power at the time, the uniform national system will reflect the policies and values of the coalition. If there is a Labor government in power at the time, the uniform national system will reflect the policies and values of the Labor Party. That is simply the way it is. If we accept that a uniform national system is desirable, we simply have to accept that a uniform national system will be achieved under the policies, principles and laws that are acceptable to the government of the day. That is why I think that the objections raised by members opposite to this bill are completely spurious.
The member for Barton made considerable use in his speech of the work done by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry in support of a move to a more uniform national system. I am pleased that he has paid appropriate attention to the excellent and outstanding work that the ACCI has done in this area, but I remind him of one matter which somehow in his speech escaped his attention. On page 43 of its blueprint, ACCI states: 
The scope to move towards a harmonised national system could be tested by creating, in the interim, a more uniform national system covering issue specific subject matters in appropriate areas as and when they come before the Parliament. 
That was well said by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry. It is in fact precisely that that this government is trying to achieve with the bill before the parliament right now. I commend the bill to the House.
Question put:
That this bill be now read a second time.

name: Emerson, Craig, MP
text:
—The Intellectual Property Laws Amendment Bill 2002 contains a number of provisions and Labor is quite happy to support them. The history of the Labor Party is one of supporting any legislation that advances the national interest in respect of intellectual property and improving the innovative capacity of this nation.
I want to use the opportunity that has been presented to me tonight to discuss the major differences that have arisen between the coalition and Labor in respect of this vital issue of innovation. Innovation today is one of the two fundamental drivers of productivity growth. Today's productivity growth is tomorrow's living standard. The other driver of productivity growth in the 21st century is the skills base of the Australian people. We have seen in the budget that was brought down two days ago that in relation to the skills base of the Australian people, the other driver of productivity growth, this government has now put higher education out of the reach of everyday Australians, of working Australian families. It has made higher education inaccessible, returning us to the worst times of previous Liberal governments before the Whitlam era.
Not only has the government made higher education inaccessible; it has made a couple of appalling cuts to skills formation in this country. The first of those is the cut to the highly successful transition from school to work program. I would assert that every member of this parliament would applaud the work that has been conducted in many of our schools in helping students who are looking to the next stage of their education and who consider that a vocational education may be the best way for them. In many of those schools, very effective programs have been put in place to facilitate a transition from school to work via the pathway of vocational education. But what has this government done in its budget? It has cut the school to work program. Not only that, it has rubbed salt in the wound. Everyone in this parliament and just about everyone in this country would say that the apprenticeship scheme is a good scheme and that we should be doing more about it. But what has the government done in its budget? It has cut the apprenticeship scheme as well, making savings at the expense of young children in this country, especially young children from disadvantaged areas.
Let us have a look at the priorities. When we go to the issue of intellectual property and lifting the skills base of this country, the government's priority has been to refurbish luxury apartments in Paris so that ministers jetting in to Paris will have an even more comfortable stay. It allocated more than $10 million on refurbishing luxury apartments in Paris which was funded by cutting apprenticeships and the very successful pathways programs, including programs that are operating in my electorate in schools such as Marsden State High and Browns Plains High and in the school just outside my electorate in Loganlea.
Can you imagine a worse set of priorities? This government says that it is more important to refurbish luxury apartments in Paris and it will fund that by cutting the opportunities available to young people to attain a vocational or university education. That is the callous approach of this government in relation to lifting the skills base of this country. Essentially, it puts a university education out of the reach of children from disadvantaged and middle-income areas. 
I turn to the other driver of productivity growth, which is innovation. It used to be said in the early postwar era that the imperative for Australia was to populate or perish. I say that in the 21st century the imperative for Australian manufacturing—and Australia more broadly—is to innovate or perish. One of the two fundamental determinants of future productivity growth is the capacity of a country to innovate.
What has this government done in relation to innovation? Yet again, it is a very sad story. The previous Labor government introduced a 150 per cent R&D tax concession with the specific objective of focusing the minds of Australian business men and women on the imperative to innovate. They responded very well. In fact, since the introduction of the scheme for that 150 per cent tax concession, business spending on research and development as a share of the economy rose in every year of the previous Labor government in response to the concession. The first act in the first budget of the Howard government was to cut the 150 per cent tax concession to 125 per cent. In direct response to that, business spending on research and development has fallen in each and every year of the Howard government.
You would think that they would have been alarmed at that. Labor played an important role in raising community awareness about what was going on in the Australian economy and the broader Australian community in relation to the government's appalling track record in innovation. In response to that pressure, the government introduced what it lauded as a great innovation statement: Backing Australia's Ability. The truth of the matter is that, even under the government's own figuring under its schedule of spending on the program, three years after the release of that statement only one-fifth of the scheduled expenditure will actually have been spent. Therefore, instead of calling the program Backing Australia's Ability, it is far more appropriate to call it Backending Australia's Ability, because four-fifths of the funding was allocated for the back end of the program.
But the government has not even honoured its commitments in relation to the meagre amount it allocated for the first three years. The R&D Start program was designed for smaller enterprises. There was the R&D tax concession for larger enterprises and the R&D Start program for smaller enterprises. You would think that, having announced an increase in the R&D Start program in Backending Australia's Ability, the government would at least honour its commitments. But last year the government—reluctantly, after the facts of the matter had been exposed—announced that the R&D Start program had been frozen. The government's assertion was that the R&D Start program was being overexpended and that, therefore, it had to freeze it in order to bring it back to the amount that was allocated in the budget.
Of course, we had a look at the actual expenditure on the R&D Start program in the budget that was released on Tuesday night. There is a gap between the allocated amount and the spent amount of $16 million. So it was not a freeze; it was a cut. Remember: the government's pretext was that it needed to freeze the program in order to bring spending back within the allocated amount. That was the basis of the freeze. But the government did not bring the program back to the allocated amount; it brought it back to $16 million below the allocated amount—and it has the temerity to describe this as a freeze! In fact, it was a cut. 
Labor's vision for industry policy for the future of Australian industry is that we must take the high road to high skills and high wages. We will never succeed in, and should not enter, a race to the bottom—a race in which this Prime Minister has entered most Australians. The Prime Minister, his workplace relations minister and the Treasurer have said to the majority of Australian working families that they need to compete on wages against other countries. In China, 30 million people have moved in recent times from the land into factories. Wages are low in China and they will remain low in China. This government's strategy for the majority of Australians is that we must compete in a race to the bottom against China. That can only mean one thing: low wages—low skills—and more low wages. 
In terms of the future of Australian families, why would we even seek to enter a race to the bottom with China and other countries of East Asia—let alone think, having entered it, that we would ever win? Who would want to win such a race? Labor says that such a race is futile and will depress the wages of Australian working families. But the government is committed to that race. It has brought legislation into this parliament to completely remove the wage safety net for the lowest paid workers in Australia. There is only one reason you remove a safety net: to allow people to fall through; to allow wages to go even lower. The government has embarked—
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. There is a distinct lack of intellectual property in this contribution. If the member speaking could make some vague reference to the bill that would be helpful.
 (Hon. L.R.S. Price)—I hear the point of order taken by the honourable member for Dunkley. I will listen a little bit more attentively to the speech. I call the member for Rankin.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I am speaking on the intellectual property legislation, which we support. The member for Dunkley should recognise that Labor support this legislation. As a consequence of our support, I wish to talk about the importance of intellectual property and innovation in this country. If we do not create the right intellectual property environment, we will not be able to innovate.
—I don't think he understands the position.
—That is right: the member for Dunkley is obviously engaged in a race to the bottom—and I think he just arrived. If the member for Dunkley could stay there at the bottom, I will continue my exposition of the importance of an intellectual property framework for an innovative country. Labor's vision is for an innovative country—a race to the top of high skills and high wages.
Let us cover the next atrocity of this government in relation to any ambition for this country to be a high-skill, high-wage country. Australia used to be a farm and a quarry. It was very vulnerable to downturns in primary commodities and very vulnerable to drought. In 1986 the former Treasurer, Paul Keating, warned of Australia becoming a banana republic. That was when the current account deficit had reached 6.4 per cent of GDP. 
The Labor government sought, successfully, to diversify the Australian industrial base—and therefore the Australian export base—so that we would not be reliant on good seasonal conditions and high primary commodity prices. The way to do that is to invest in intellectual property and to innovate. Labor did that, and it came through in the results. The growth of sophisticated manufactured exports that would insulate Australia against a collapse in primary commodity prices or bad seasonal conditions was phenomenal. Under this government, the growth in exports of sophisticated manufactured goods has slumped 60 per cent. 
—Are you excluding cars?
—I am including cars. That just shows how bad it is, because cars are a very good performer, along with pharmaceuticals and wine—all the result of Labor industry policies.
—Cars, pharmaceuticals and wine. Thank you very much for your contribution, member for Dunkley. It proves my point that, if governments invest positively in innovation and industry policy, good results come through.
But what has happened under this government? This government has failed to invest in those industries and it has failed to invest in innovation. As a consequence, it has taken Australia back to a farm and a quarry. We have the Treasurer, in trying to explain our appalling current account performance—where we have experienced the worst quarterly current account deficit on record—saying, `It's all the drought.' But we had those figures before the impact of the drought came along. 
I had a look at what was happening to our sophisticated manufactured exports and found that they have started to fall. What about high-value services—the other area that is so reliant on intellectual property and innovation? What has happened there? The figures released yesterday show that that has fallen by six per cent and our share of the global services market—our market share—has fallen. This government says, `It's because of the slowdown in the global economy.' If it is not the drought, it is the slowdown in the global economy. Our market share in these countries has fallen under the auspices of this government.
Fundamentally, the problem is that this government does not believe in investing in the drivers of growth—that is, lifting the skills base of this country—and investing in innovation. As a consequence, it has made us vulnerable and has returned us to a farm and a quarry. What that means for the future of this country is the ongoing accumulation of foreign debt—and I will finish my remarks on this point. When this government was criticising Labor and rolled out the debt truck and said, `Foreign debt is $10,000 for every man, woman and child in Australia,' it promised to fix foreign debt. It has not fixed it; it has doubled it. 
By the Treasurer's preferred measure, foreign debt is now $18,000 for every man, woman and child in Australia. Foreign debt has recently crashed through the $350 billion barrier. Each and every month that we have a trade deficit, that foreign debt goes up. How many trade deficits have we had in a row? We have had 16 trade deficits in a row. And the Minister for Trade says, `We've got a terrific trade policy.' Do you know what his trade policy is? Pray for rain. The government's trade policy is to pray for rain—because, once again, we are a farm and a quarry.
The government has no active industry policy, no active intellectual property framework and no active innovation policy. As a result, the working families of Australia have suffered a deterioration in the quality of work and a loss of workers' entitlements. The casualisation of the Australian work force is absolutely going through the roof. We have the second highest proportion of part-time workers in the work force in the Western world. Why? Because this government has entered most Australians in a race to the bottom: trying to compete on wages against China; ripping out the social safety net; ripping out protection for Australian workers' entitlements—their overtime, their sick leave, their holiday pay—and withdrawing workers' superannuation payments that were budgeted for and legislated by the previous Labor government and cancelled by this government—because that would have been something decent to do for Australian workers. It has been tearing away the social safety net in this appalling race to the bottom. 
We support this legislation, as a very tiny, modest effort, but it must stand against this government's appalling neglect and its philosophy that most working Australians should be engaged in a race to the bottom of low skills and low wages. Labor says, `No. We should enter all Australians in a race to the top of high skills, high wages and high quality of work.
Debate (on motion by Ms Worth) adjourned.

name: Crean, Simon, MP
text:
—Tuesday's budget should have improved life for Australian families. That is the test any budget should meet. But Australian families are under growing financial pressure. They are working longer hours and paying record taxes, and the last thing Australian families need is to pay more for vital services like education and health. But that is what Tuesday night's budget was all about. A civilised society demands health care based on medical need and education for all based on ability. I believe that health and education are not just about providing services to individuals. They are public goods for all Australians. We must invest in these vital services as a nation. But under the Howard government we are heading in the opposite direction. Instead of improving life for families, this budget is making things worse. It is giving Australian families a miserly $4 tax cut while destroying Medicare and charging them more for education. The Howard government failed the test on Tuesday night, and it is time for something new.
Tonight I want to announce a new deal for Australia and for Australian families:
·	a new deal to save Medicare and bulk-billing;
·	a pledge to keep higher education affordable and accessible;
·	a plan to save the Murray River from a slow, tragic death;
·	a retirement tax cut for every Australian;
·	a new deal to protect the savings of Australians;
·	an end to public subsidies of executive golden handshakes;
·	a better deal for small business; and 
·	a better way to protect Australia and our children.
Most of all, I want to give Australians a sense of hope that Australia can remain a fair and decent country that provides opportunities for all.
Saving Medicare and bulk-billing
Mr Speaker, I believe that every Australian must have the right to access a doctor who bulk-bills, and they must have the right to attend a well funded public hospital without charge. I will not say for free, because it is not free. Australians know that. They have already paid for Medicare through their taxes and through their Medicare levy. They have earned it. They should not have to pay again when they visit a doctor. Quality health care must only ever be available on the basis of medical need. It should never be rationed according to ability to pay. It should not be a two-tiered system; it should not be a second-rate system. If you want that, just look at the United States. Forty-five million people there do not have any health cover. They live in fear of serious illness. It destroys family finances, sometimes for generations. That is not the sort of health system I want for Australia. 
Mr Speaker, there is a profound difference between Labor and our opponents. We are the builders of a health system in this country; they are the wreckers. Labor built Medibank under Gough Whitlam and then Medicare under Bob Hawke because we believe that everyone should have access to affordable health care. But the Liberals have never believed in affordable health care. They want you to pay more. That is why they wrecked Medibank and that is why Prime Minister Howard is wrecking Medicare now. That is why tonight I am announcing that a Labor government will act to save Medicare and save bulk-billing. I am not going to allow Medicare to be replaced by an Americanised, privatised system where, instead of your Medicare card, doctors ask for your credit card and refuse to treat you unless you pay up front. Saving Medicare starts with restoring your patient rebate.
Tonight I am announcing that a Crean Labor government will lift the patient rebate for bulk-billing for all Australians, no matter where they live or how much they earn. We will lift the patient rebate immediately on coming to office to 95 per cent of the scheduled fee, and we will then take it to 100 per cent—an average rise of $5 for every consultation that is bulk-billed. This is not just for concession card holders but for everyone, everywhere in the country. But I go further. As we know, access to bulk-billing is declining faster in some parts of Australia than in others. To remedy this, under Labor, doctors who meet bulk-billing targets will receive additional incentive payments. Doctors in metropolitan areas who bulk-bill 80 per cent of services will receive an additional $7,500 a year. Doctors in outer metropolitan areas who bulk-bill 75 per cent of services will receive an additional $15,000. And doctors in rural and regional areas who bulk-bill 70 per cent of services will receive an additional $22,500.
—I will deal with the member for Herbert!
